english:
p: (if you are the Son of God)
q: (command these stones to become bread)
notes: P presents a fact that the temptor knew to be true. The devil certainly knows Jesus' identity. Hagner (1993) notes that this might as well be translated "since", as the devil is testing Jesus' obedience to the Father rather than questioning his identity. Q presents the subsequent command Jesus is being tempted to obey.

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ υἱὸς εἶ τοῦ θεοῦ

greek_apodoses.q1: εἰπὲ ἵνα οἱ λίθοι οὗτοι ἄρτοι γένωνται

english:
p: (if you are the Son of God)
q: (throw yourself down)
notes: As with 4:3, this conditional expresses no doubt about Jesus' identity, but is being used to manipulate, tempt, and challenge him.

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ υἱὸς εἶ τοῦ θεοῦ

english:
q:(All these I will give you)
p: (if you will fall down and worship me)
notes: In 4:3 and 4:6 the exhortations (or temptations) are direct and occur in q; in this verse the exhortation (or temptation) is made indirectly in p. Though highly unlikely, and though it did not come to pass, this was still a (remote) possibility when the devil spoke it. It was a real option for Jesus, though he did not take it. Unlike the two previous temptations, this one is a third class, using εαν with the subjunctive because ( according to Hagner 1993) it involves an actual unmet condition.

greek_protases.p1: Ταῦτά σοι πάντα δώσω

english:
p: (if salt has lost its taste)
q: (how shall its saltiness be restored?)
notes: This conditional must be read in its context of describing discipleship. The connection between salt and discipleship is that, as Marshall (1978) puts it, "a false form of discipleship may look like salt, but the gradual process of leeching leaves only a zestless pile of waste."

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν δὲ τὸ ἅλας μωρανθῇ

english:
p: (unless your righteousness exceeds that of the scribes and Pharisees)
q: (you will never enter the kingdom of heaven)
notes:
Greek: εαν μη. Nolland, Hagner, and others agree that the righteousness Jesus discusses here cannot mean that he is actually commanding the disciples to live by the letter of the law as the Pharisees do (and to a greater extent, which is nigh impossible). 
Paraphrase (to avoid multiple negatives in languages without 'unless' or 'except'): For I say to you that only if you are more righteous than the scribes and Pharisees, will you enter the kingdom of heaven.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν μὴ περισσεύσῃ ὑμῶν ἡ δικαιοσύνη πλεῖον τῶν γραμματέων καὶ Φαρισαίων

greek_apodoses.q1: οὐ μὴ εἰσέλθητε εἰς τὴν βασιλείαν τῶν οὐρανῶν

english:
p: (if you are offering your gift at the altar and there remember that your brother has something against you,)
q: (v.24 leave your gift there before the alter and go)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NIV, NLT: "if"
NRSV: See Notes
notes: P consists of two clauses: 1) offering your gift at the altar, and 2) remember that your brother has something against you. in most English translations "if" covers both of these, but NRSV introduces each separately with "when" and "if" respectively: "So when you are offering your gift at the altar, if you remember that your brother or sister has something against you, leave your gift there..." This could be a good model to follow in some languages.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν οὖν προσφέρῃς τὸ δῶρόν σου ἐπὶ τὸ θυσιαστήριον κἀκεῖ μνησθῇς ὅτι ὁ ἀδελφός σου ἔχει τι κατὰ σοῦ

greek_apodoses.q1: ἄφες ἐκεῖ τὸ δῶρόν σου ἔμπροσθεν τοῦ θυσιαστηρίου καὶ ὕπαγε

english:
p: (if your right eye causes you to sin)
q: (tear it out and throw it away)
notes:
This conditional uses figurative langauge describing a situation.
The conditional is class 3 in Mark 9:47 and class 1 here in Matthew. It could be that Mark was more focused on the potentiality of different types of sins. Mark 9:47 and its related verses come in a longer list of various possible stumbling blocks. Matthew perhaps had in view the point that sin is more common and more strictly judged than was commonly taught. It was therefore framed in his account as "determined as fulfilled" due to the context of what was being said.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ ὁ ὀφθαλμός σου ὁ δεξιὸς σκανδαλίζει σε

greek_apodoses.q1: ἔξελε αὐτὸν καὶ βάλε ἀπὸ σοῦ

english:
p: (if your right hand causes you to sin)
q: (cut it off and throw it away)
notes: See note on 5:29.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ἡ δεξιά σου χεὶρ σκανδαλίζει σε

greek_apodoses.q1: ἔκκοψον αὐτὴν καὶ βάλε ἀπὸ σοῦ

english:
p: (if you love those who love you)
q: (what reward do you have?)
notes: In this verse, q is a rhetorical question that expects the answer "No reward at all." Jesus' point is that loving those who love you is a common situation that is not unique or especially commendable. He uses it to support his command that the disciples should love their enemies.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν γὰρ ἀγαπήσητε τοὺς ἀγαπῶντας ὑμᾶς

english:
modifications in brackets
p: (if you greet only your brothers)
q: (what more are you doing than others?) [you are not doing anything more than others]
notes: See note on 5:46.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν ἀσπάσησθε τοὺς ἀδελφοὺς ὑμῶν μόνον

english:
NIV, clarification in brackets
p: (if you do) [practice your righteousness in front of others to be seen by them]
q: (you will have no reward from your Father in heaven)
english_translations:
ESV, NRSV: "for then"
NASB: "otherwise"
NIV: "If you do"
NLT: "for"
notes:
Greek: εἰ δὲ μή γε with an elided (understood) verb.
English translations express the constrcution εἰ δὲ μή γε in a variety of ways; the NIV translation shows how it is related to a conditional meaning.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ μή γε

greek_apodoses.q1: μισθὸν οὐκ ἔχετε παρὰ τῷ πατρὶ ὑμῶν τῷ ἐν τοῖς οὐρανοῖς

english:
p: (if you forgive others their trespasses)
q: (your heavenly Father will also forgive you)

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν γὰρ ἀφῆτε τοῖς ἀνθρώποις τὰ παραπτώματα αὐτῶν

greek_apodoses.q1: ἀφήσει καὶ ὑμῖν ὁ πατὴρ ὑμῶν ὁ οὐράνιος

english:
p: (if you do not forgive others their trespasses 
q: (neither will your Father forgive your trespasses)
notes: The situation described in this conditional is the opposite of 6:14.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν δὲ μὴ ἀφῆτε τοῖς ἀνθρώποις

greek_apodoses.q1: οὐδὲ ὁ πατὴρ ὑμῶν ἀφήσει τὰ παραπτώματα

english:
p: (if your eye is healthy)
q: (your whole body will be full of light)
english_translations:
ESV, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NASB: "then if"
NLT: "when"

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν οὖν ᾖ ὁ ὀφθαλμός σου ἁπλοῦς

greek_apodoses.q1: ὅλον τὸ σῶμά σου φωτεινὸν ἔσται

english:
p: (if your eye is bad)
q: (your whole body will be full of darkness)

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν δὲ ὁ ὀφθαλμός σου πονηρὸς ᾖ

greek_apodoses.q1: ὅλον τὸ σῶμά σου σκοτεινὸν ἔσται

english:
p: (if then the light in you is darkness)
q: (how great is the darkness)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if then"
NLT: "if"

greek_protases.p1: εἰ οὖν τὸ φῶς τὸ ἐν σοὶ σκότος ἐστίν

english:
p: (if God so clothes the grass of the field...)
q: (will he not much more clothe you?)
notes: P is factual, and q is a rhetorical question expecting an affirmative response: "God will indeed clothe his people."

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ τὸν χόρτον τοῦ ἀγροῦ σήμερον ὄντα καὶ αὔριον εἰς κλίβανον βαλλόμενον ὁ θεὸς οὕτως ἀμφιέννυσιν

english:
What man among you
p: (if his son asks him for bread)
q: (will give him a stone)?
notes: Although there is no conditional marker in the Greek, the sense here is clearly conditional. Jesus is asking his hearers to consider a hypothetical but commonplace scenario (a child asking for food) and an almost unthinkable response (a father giving the child something inedible and dangerous). Almost all English translations translate these verses as conditional sentences. The probability "likely" refers to the probability of p, not the probability of q (which is very unlikely to happen).

greek_protases.p1: ὃν αἰτήσει ὁ υἱὸς αὐτοῦ ἄρτον

english:
p: or (if he asks for an fish)
q: (will give him a snake)?
notes: See note at 7:9

greek_protases.p1: ἢ καὶ ἰχθὺν αἰτήσει

english:
p: (if you then, who are evil, know how to give good gifts to your children)
q: (how much more will your Father who is in heaven give good things to those who ask him)
notes: In the previous sentences, Jesus has just used rhetorical questions to highlight the fact that his listeners would indeed not want to give bad gifts to their children (e.g. a snake).

greek_protases.p1: εἰ οὖν ὑμεῖς πονηροὶ ὄντες οἴδατε δόματα ἀγαθὰ διδόναι τοῖς τέκνοις ὑμῶν

greek_apodoses.q1: πόσῳ μᾶλλον ὁ πατὴρ ὑμῶν ὁ ἐν τοῖς οὐρανοῖς δώσει ἀγαθὰ τοῖς αἰτοῦσιν αὐτόν

english:
p: (if you will)
q: (you can make me clean)
notes: Jesus is able to make the man clean regardless of his will to do so. Many commentators agree that the man is not expressing any doubt as to Jesus' power, but the conditional merely expresses his doubt as to Jesus' willingness.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν θέλῃς δύνασαί με

english:
p: (if you cast us out)
q: (send us away into the herd of pigs)
notes: The probability is listed as Very Likely and the time as Future because the demons recognized Jesus and could easily guess his intentions. However, a possible alternative interpretation (supported by the parallel in Mark 5:12) is that this is a Factual Present condition with the meaning "Since you are casting us out..."

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ ἐκβάλλεις ἡμᾶς

greek_apodoses.q1: ἀπόστειλον ἡμᾶς εἰς τὴν ἀγέλην τῶν χοίρων

english:
p: (if it is)
q: (the skins burst and the wine is spilled and the skins are destroyed)
notes:
Greek: εἰ δὲ μή γε with an elided (understood) verb. 
See note on 6:1.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ μή γε

greek_apodoses.q1: ῥήγνυνται οἱ ἀσκοί καὶ ὁ οἶνος ἐκχεῖται καὶ οἱ ἀσκοὶ ἀπόλλυνται

english:
p: (if I only touch his garment)
q: (I will be made well)
notes: The illocutionary force category is not applicable here as the woman is speaking only to herself (which is Matthew's way of describing her thoughts).

greek_protases.p1: Ἐὰν μόνον ἅψωμαι τοῦ ἱματίου αὐτοῦ

english:
p: (if the house is worthy)
q: (let your peace come upon it)

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν μὲν ᾖ ἡ οἰκία ἀξία

greek_apodoses.q1: ἐλθάτω ἡ εἰρήνη ὑμῶν ἐπ αὐτήν

english:
p: (if it is not worthy)
q: (let your peace return to you)

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν δὲ μὴ ᾖ ἀξία

greek_apodoses.q1: ἡ εἰρήνη ὑμῶν πρὸς ὑμᾶς ἐπιστραφήτω

english:
modified to reflect the Greek more literally
p: (if they have called the master of the house Beelzebul)
q: (how much more the members of his household)
notes: Jesus claims q is more likely than p. Since p is in fact a true condition, he is arguing and warning that q will indeed happen by using figurative terms.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ τὸν οἰκοδεσπότην Βεελζεβοὺλ ἐπεκάλεσαν

english:
p: (if you are willing to accept it)
q: (he is Elijah, who is to come)
notes: Q is a fact that is true regardless of p (i.e. whether the hearers are willing to accept it)..

greek_protases.p1: εἰ θέλετε δέξασθαι

greek_apodoses.q1: αὐτός ἐστιν Ἠλίας ὁ μέλλων ἔρχεσθαι

english:
p: (if the mighty works done in you had been done in Tyre and Sidon)
q: (they would have repented long ago)
notes: P did not, in fact, occur and neither did q. Jesus here uses the example of Tyre and Sidon to rebuke Bethsaida and Chorazin.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ἐν Τύρῳ καὶ Σιδῶνι ἐγένοντο αἱ δυνάμεις αἱ γενόμεναι ἐν ὑμῖν

greek_apodoses.q1: πάλαι ἂν ἐν σάκκῳ καὶ σποδῷ μετενόησαν

english:
p: (if the mighty works done in you had been done in Sodom)
q: (it would have remained until this day)
notes: P did not, in fact, occur and neither did q. Jesus here uses the example of Sodom to rebuke Capernaum.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ἐν Σοδόμοις ἐγενήθησαν αἱ δυνάμεις αἱ γενόμεναι ἐν σοί

english:
p: (if you had known what this means, "I desire mercy and not sacrifice")
q: (you would not have condemned the guiltless)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV, NLT: "if"
(NLT inverts p and q in translation)
notes: Jesus rebukes the pharisees by implying that they did not know the meaning of Scripture and therefore had condemned the innocent.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ ἐγνώκειτε τί ἐστιν Ἔλεος θέλω καὶ οὐ θυσίαν

english:
p: (if it [a sheep] falls into a pit on the Sabbath)
q: (will [he] not take hold of it and lift it out)
notes:
English translations offer a variety of structures for this conditional; for example, NIV includes "any of you has a sheep" within the scope of the conditional. The Greek has και εαν following the phrase "who has one sheep" and just preceeding the subjunctive verb "fall". Though και εαν sometimes expresses a concessive ("even if") conditonal, here it simply means "and if". 
Jesus' use of a rhetorical question in q assumes an affirmative answer.

greek_protases.p1: καὶ ἐὰν ἐμπέσῃ τοῦτο τοῖς σάββασιν εἰς βόθυνον

english:
p: (if Satan casts out Satan)
q: (he is divided against himself)
notes: A false situation which Jesus presents as possible for the sake of argument in order to show that Q is ridiculous.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ὁ Σατανᾶς τὸν Σατανᾶν ἐκβάλλει

english:
p: (if I cast out demons by Beelzebul)
q: (by whom do your sons cast them out)
notes: See note on 12:26.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ἐγὼ ἐν Βεελζεβοὺλ ἐκβάλλω τὰ δαιμόνια

greek_apodoses.q1: οἱ υἱοὶ ὑμῶν ἐν τίνι ἐκβάλλουσιν

english:
p: (if it is by the Spirit of God I cast out demons)
q: (then the kingdom of God has come upon you)
notes: P is factual, though Jesus' audience may not yet be convinced of it. Here Jesus furthers the argument beyond, "Is he casting out demons by Beelzebul or by the Spirit?" to "What does it mean that he IS casting out by the Spirit?"

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ ἐν πνεύματι θεοῦ ἐγὼ ἐκβάλλω τὰ δαιμόνια

greek_apodoses.q1: ἄρα ἔφθασεν ἐφ ὑμᾶς ἡ βασιλεία τοῦ θεοῦ

english:
q: (how can someone enter a strong man's house and plunder his goods)
p: (unless he first binds the strong man?)
english_translations:
ESV, NIV, NASB: "unless"
NRSV: "without"
NLT: untranslated ("only")
notes:
Greek: ἐὰν μὴ 'unless'.
Paraphrase (to avoid multiple negatives in languages without 'unless' or 'except', and avoiding rhetorical question): A person can only enter the strong man's house and carry off/steal his property if he first binds the strong man.
NLT: "For who is powerful enough to enter the house of a strong man and plunder his goods? Only someone even stronger—someone who could tie him up and then plunder his house."

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν μὴ πρῶτον δήσῃ τὸν ἰσχυρόν

greek_apodoses.q1: ἢ πῶς δύναταί τις εἰσελθεῖν εἰς τὴν οἰκίαν τοῦ ἰσχυροῦ καὶ τὰ σκεύη αὐτοῦ ἁρπάσαι

english:
p: (if it is you)
q: (command me to come to you on the water)

greek_protases.p1: εἰ σὺ εἶ

greek_apodoses.q1: κέλευσόν με ἐλθεῖν πρὸς σὲ ἐπὶ τὰ ὕδατα

english:
p: (if the blind lead the blind)
q: (both will fall into a pit)

greek_protases.p1: τυφλὸς δὲ τυφλὸν ἐὰν ὁδηγῇ

english:
p: (if anyone would come after me)
q: (let him deny himself and take up his cross and follow me)
notes:
Greek: εἴ τις 'if anyone'
Probability is based on the fact that most of the audience Jesus is speaking to wanted to follow him.

greek_protases.p1: Εἴ τις θέλει ὀπίσω μου ἐλθεῖν

greek_apodoses.q1: ἀπαρνησάσθω ἑαυτὸν καὶ ἀράτω τὸν σταυρὸν αὐτοῦ καὶ ἀκολουθείτω μοι

english:
q: (what will it profit a man)
p: (if he gains the whole world and forfeits his soul?)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NLT: "if"
NIV: "What good will it be for someone to gain the whole world, yet..."
notes: This verse contains two rhetorical questions (this conditional sentence, and a non-conditional sentence). The expected answer to both is "Nothing."

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν τὸν κόσμον ὅλον κερδήσῃ τὴν δὲ ψυχὴν αὐτοῦ ζημιωθῇ

english:
p: (if you wish)
q: (I will make three tents here)
notes: Parallel verses do not have a conditional connective.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ θέλεις

english:
p: (if you have faith like a grain of mustard seed)
q: (you will say to this mountain "Move..." and it will move)

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν ἔχητε πίστιν ὡς κόκκον σινάπεως

greek_apodoses.q1: ἐρεῖτε τῷ ὄρει τούτῳ Μετάβα ἔνθεν ἐκεῖ καὶ μεταβήσεται

english:
p: (unless you turn and become like children)
q: (you will never enter the kingdom of God)
notes:
Greek: ἐὰν μὴ 'unless'
Paraphrase (to avoid multiple negatives in languages without 'unless' or 'except'): "Truly I say to you, only if you change/turn and become like children, will you enter the kingdom of heaven."

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν μὴ στραφῆτε καὶ γένησθε ὡς τὰ παιδία

greek_apodoses.q1: οὐ μὴ εἰσέλθητε εἰς τὴν βασιλείαν τῶν οὐρανῶν

english:
p: (if your hand or foot causes you to sin)
q: (cut it off and throw it away)
notes: See note on 5:30.

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ δὲ ἡ χείρ σου ἢ ὁ πούς σου σκανδαλίζει σε

greek_apodoses.q1: ἔκκοψον αὐτὸν καὶ βάλε ἀπὸ σοῦ

english:
p: (if your eye causes you to sin)
q: (tear it out and throw it away)
notes: See note on 5:29.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ὁ ὀφθαλμός σου σκανδαλίζει σε

greek_apodoses.q1: ἔξελε αὐτὸν καὶ βάλε ἀπὸ σοῦ

english:
p: (if a man has a hundred sheep and one of them goes astray)
q: (does he not leave the ninety-nine on the mountains and go in search of the one that never went astray?)
notes: Jesus introduces a parable here that gets a more detailed and less conditional treatment in Luke. In this verse he asks a rhetorical question that expects a postive response.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν γένηταί τινι ἀνθρώπῳ ἑκατὸν πρόβατα καὶ πλανηθῇ ἓν ἐξ αὐτῶν

greek_apodoses.q1: οὐχὶ ἀφήσει τὰ ἐνενήκοντα ἐννέα ἐπὶ τὰ ὄρη καὶ πορευθεὶς ζητεῖ τὸ πλανώμενον

english:
p: (if he finds it)
q: (he rejoices over it more than over the ninety-nine that never went astray)

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν γένηται εὑρεῖν αὐτό

greek_apodoses.q1: ἀμὴν λέγω ὑμῖν ὅτι χαίρει ἐπ αὐτῷ μᾶλλον ἢ ἐπὶ τοῖς ἐνενήκοντα ἐννέα τοῖς μὴ πεπλανημένοις

english:
p: (if your brother sins against you)
q: (go and tell him his fault, between you and him alone)
notes: In this verse, Jesus brings up the topic of dealing with sin in the church. The specific focus continues through v.17 as Jesus builds each subsquent conditonal on the last one. He presents multiple situations and instructs the disciples what to do in each of the cases.

greek_protases.p1: Ἐὰν δὲ ἁμαρτήσῃ εἰς σὲ ὁ ἀδελφός σου

greek_apodoses.q1: ὕπαγε ἔλεγξον αὐτὸν μεταξὺ σοῦ καὶ αὐτοῦ μόνου

english:
p: (if he listens to you)
q: (you have gained your brother)
notes: See note on 18:15.

greek_protases.p1: ἐάν σου ἀκούσῃ

english:
p: (but if he does not listen)
q: (take one or two others along with you)
notes: See note on 18:15.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν δὲ μὴ ἀκούσῃ

greek_apodoses.q1: παράλαβε μετὰ σοῦ ἔτι ἕνα ἢ δύο ἵνα ἐπὶ στόματος δύο μαρτύρων ἢ τριῶν σταθῇ πᾶν ῥῆμα

english:
p: (if he refuses to listen to them)
q: (tell it to the church)
notes: See note on 18:15.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν δὲ παρακούσῃ αὐτῶν

english:
p: (if he refuses to listen to the church)
q: (let him be to you as a Gentile and a tax collector)
notes: See note on 18:15.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν δὲ καὶ τῆς ἐκκλησίας παρακούσῃ ἔστω σοι ὥσπερ ὁ ἐθνικὸς καὶ ὁ τελώνης

greek_apodoses.q1: ἔστω σοι ὥσπερ ὁ ἐθνικὸς καὶ ὁ τελώνης

english:
p: (if two of you agree on earth about anything they ask)
q: (it will be done for them by my Father in heaven)

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν δύο συμφωνήσωσιν ἐξ ὑμῶν ἐπὶ τῆς γῆς περὶ παντὸς πράγματος οὗ ἐὰν αἰτήσωνται

greek_apodoses.q1: γενήσεται αὐτοῖς παρὰ τοῦ πατρός μου τοῦ ἐν οὐρανοῖς

english:
q: (so also my heavenly Father will do to every one of you)
p: (if you do not forgive your brother from your heart)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV "if...not"
NIV: "unless"
NLT: "if you refuse..."
notes: Greek: ἐὰν μὴ 'if not', 'unless'

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν μὴ ἀφῆτε ἕκαστος τῷ ἀδελφῷ αὐτοῦ ἀπὸ τῶν καρδιῶν ὑμῶν

greek_apodoses.q1: Οὕτως καὶ ὁ πατήρ μου ὁ οὐράνιος ποιήσει ὑμῖν

english:
p: (if such is the case of a man with his wife)
q: (it is better not to marry)
notes: "If such is the case" refers back to Jesus' teaching in vs.8 & 9. If a conditional will make it sound as if the disciples are doubting Jesus, you could use an expression such as "In that case" or even "That teaching is hard!"

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ οὕτως ἐστὶν ἡ αἰτία τοῦ ἀνθρώπου μετὰ τῆς γυναικός

english:
p: (if you wish to enter into life)
q: (keep the commandments) (NASB/NRSV)
notes: In v.16 someone asked Jesus, “Teacher, what good deed must I do to have eternal life?” This man clearly wanted eternal life, so the s conditional is factual.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ θέλεις εἰς τὴν ζωὴν εἰσελθεῖν

english:
p: (if you would be perfect)
q: (go, sell what you possess and give to the poor...)
notes: In the previous verse, the young man told Jesus that he had kept all the commandments, and then asked "What do I still lack?" This shows that τέλειος "perfect" here means to keep the commandments completely. This is something that the young man wants to do, so the conditional is factual.

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ θέλεις τέλειος εἶναι

greek_apodoses.q1: ὕπαγε πώλησόν σου τὰ ὑπάρχοντα καὶ δὸς πτωχοῖς καὶ ἕξεις θησαυρὸν ἐν οὐρανοῖς καὶ δεῦρο ἀκολούθει μοι

english:
p: (if anyone says anything to you)
q: (you shall say, "the Lord needs them")
notes: Greek: εαν τις 'if anyone'

greek_protases.p1: ἐάν τις ὑμῖν εἴπῃ τι

greek_apodoses.q1: ἐρεῖτε ὅτι Ὁ κύριος αὐτῶν χρείαν ἔχει

english:
p: (if you have faith and don't doubt)
q: (you will not only do what has been done to the fig tree, but even if you say to this mountain, "Be taken up and thrown into the sea", it will happen)
english_translations: ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV, NLT: "if you have faith and do not doubt..."
notes: The probability is debatable here. Jesus is speaking to his closest disciples, who presumably have faith, but Jesus has already rebuked the disciples for "small faith" and doubting on at least two occasions (14:31; 17:20). However, the time reference appears to be gnomic rather than restricted to the moment of speech, suggesting that this statement is applicable to all who have faith rather than just to the original disciples.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν ἔχητε πίστιν καὶ μὴ διακριθῆτε

greek_apodoses.q1: οὐ μόνον τὸ τῆς συκῆς ποιήσετε ἀλλὰ κἂν τῷ ὄρει τούτῳ εἴπητε Ἄρθητι καὶ βλήθητι εἰς τὴν θάλασσαν γενήσεται

english:
p: (even if you say to this mountain, "Be taken up and thrown into the sea")
q: (it will happen)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV: "even if"
NIV: "also you can..." 
NLT: "You can even..."
notes:
Greek: καν (και + εαν) 'even if'
The conditional sentence of 21:21b is embedded into q of the conditional in 21:21a. Jesus is describing a very unusual scenario and is probably using hyperbole.
parallel_passages: Mark 11:23 (but Mark has ὃς ἂν 'whoever' rather than κἂν 'even if')

greek_protases.p1: κἂν τῷ ὄρει τούτῳ εἴπητε Ἄρθητι καὶ βλήθητι εἰς τὴν θάλασσαν

english:
p: (If you believe)
q: (you will receive whatever you ask for in prayer) (NIV)
english_translations:
ESV, NIV, NLT: "if"
NASB, NRSV: no conditional
notes: This is an implied conditional using the present participle of 'believe': "believing, you will receive" = "if you believe, you will receive".

greek_protases.p1: πιστεύοντες

greek_apodoses.q1d: πάντα ὅσα ἂν αἰτήσητε ἐν τῇ προσευχῇ … λήμψεσθε

english:
p: (if you tell me the answer)
q: (then I also will tell you by what authority I do these things)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV, NLT: "if"
NLT inverts p and q
parallel_passages: Mark 11:29 (but Mark uses an imperative: "answer me, and I will tell you...")

greek_protases.p1: ὃν ἐὰν εἴπητέ μοι

greek_apodoses.q1: κἀγὼ ὑμῖν ἐρῶ ἐν ποίᾳ ἐξουσίᾳ ταῦτα ποιῶ

english:
p: (if we say 'from heaven')
q: (he will say to us 'Why then, did you not believe him?')
notes: The conditionals in v.25 and v.26 should be understood as a pair; together they give the two possible answers to Jesus' question and the consequences of each.

greek_protases.p1: Ἐὰν εἴπωμεν Ἐξ οὐρανοῦ

greek_apodoses.q1: ἐρεῖ ἡμῖν Διὰ τί οὖν οὐκ ἐπιστεύσατε αὐτῷ

english:
p: (if we say 'from man')
q: (we are afraid of the crowd - implies 'the crowd will attack us')
notes: See note on 21:25. The parallel account in Luke 20:6 explains the fear more, as the Pharisees say they believe the people would stone them.
parallel_passages: Luke 20:6 (Mark 11:32 is truncated; no overt conditional)

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν δὲ εἴπωμεν Ἐξ ἀνθρώπων

english:
p: (if a man dies having no children)
q: (his brother must marry the widow and raise up offspring for his brother)
notes: This conditional is a sumary of Deutoronomy 25:5-6. The Saducees use this to begin a conversation about the topic of remarriage after a death, in order to challenge Jesus.

greek_protases.p1: Ἐάν τις ἀποθάνῃ μὴ ἔχων τέκνα

greek_apodoses.q1: ἐπιγαμβρεύσει ὁ ἀδελφὸς αὐτοῦ τὴν γυναῖκα αὐτοῦ καὶ ἀναστήσει σπέρμα τῷ ἀδελφῷ αὐτοῦ

english:
p: (if then David calls him Lord)
q: (how is he his son?)
notes: This is factual because Jesus has just quoted Psa 110:1 where David calls the Christ "my Lord". Jesus' question here may not be rhetorical since v.46 states that "no one was able to answer him". Hagner notes that the point of the question is to "elevate the concept of Messiah from that of a special human being to one who uniquely manifests the presence of God."

greek_protases.p1: εἰ οὖν Δαυὶδ καλεῖ αὐτὸν κύριον

english:
p: (if we had lived in the days of our fathers)
q: (we would not have taken part with them in shedding the blood of the prophets)
notes: Here Jesus is quoting the kind of thing that the Pharisees would say.

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ ἤμεθα ἐν ταῖς ἡμέραις τῶν πατέρων ἡμῶν

greek_apodoses.q1: οὐκ ἂν ἤμεθα αὐτῶν κοινωνοὶ ἐν τῷ αἵματι τῶν προφητῶν

english:
p: (unless that time of calamity is shortened)
q: (not a single person will survive) (NLT)
english_translations:
ESV, NRSV, NIV: "if... not"
NASB, NLT: "unless"
notes:
Greek: εἰ μὴ 'if not', 'unless'
The time reference here may be confusing. Although the Greek has an aorist (past) verb, Jesus is talking about the future. This is confirmed because Jesus states directly afterward that "those days will be cut short." Because "those days" are still in the future, NLT has, "unless that time...is [i.e. will be] shortened." The ESV/NRSV/NIV translation of "had not been cut short" makes this into a past time conditional, which is not correct. One way to translate this is: "If those days are not [i.e. will not be] cut short, no one will survive."
Paraphrase (to avoid multiple negatives in languages without 'unless' or 'except'): "Only if those days are [i.e. will be] cut short will any person (lit: flesh) be saved."

greek_protases.p1: εἰ μὴ ἐκολοβώθησαν αἱ ἡμέραι ἐκεῖναι

english:
p: (if anyone says to you "Look here is the Christ" or "there he is!")
q: (do not believe it)
notes:
Greek: εαν τις 'if anyone'
The probability is likely because Jesus states in the next verse that false christs will come (see also 24:4). This conditional describes what the disciples should do if or when they hear these false claims.

greek_protases.p1: τότε ἐάν τις ὑμῖν εἴπῃ Ἰδοὺ ὧδε ὁ χριστός ἤ Ὧδε

english:
p: (if they say to you "Look, he is in the wilderness")
q: (do not go out)
notes: The two condiitonals in v.26 describe situations that might arise in which people may claim Christ has come when he has not. (For "if possible in v.24, see the Non-conditional section at the end of the page.)

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν οὖν εἴπωσιν ὑμῖν Ἰδοὺ ἐν τῇ ἐρήμῳ ἐστίν

english:
Square brackets show what is elided in the Greek text:
p: ([if they say] "Look, he is in the inner rooms")
q: (do not believe it"
english_translations:
ESV, NRSV: include "if they say"
NASB, NIV, NLT: preserve the ellision
notes:
See note on 24:26a.
This conditional could be considered the same condtional with v24a having a more complex structure, but we favor treating it as its own conditional with an elided verb.

greek_protases.p1: Ἰδοὺ ἐν τοῖς ταμείοις

english:
p: (if the master of the house had known in what part of the night the thief was coming)
q: (he would have stayed awake and would not have let his house be broken into)
notes: The sentence is referring to a past time situation, but it should be understood as being applied metaphorically to the return of Christ, which can occur at any time (see v.44).

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ᾔδει ὁ οἰκοδεσπότης ποίᾳ φυλακῇ ὁ κλέπτης ἔρχεται

greek_apodoses.q1: ἐγρηγόρησεν ἂν καὶ οὐκ ἂν εἴασεν διορυχθῆναι τὴν οἰκίαν αὐτοῦ

english:
p: (if that wicked servant says to himself 'My master is delayed', and begins to beat his fellow servants, and eats and drinks with drunkards)
q: (the master of the servant will come on a day when he does not expect him and at an hour he does not know and will cut him in pieces with the hypocrites.)
notes: P is v.48-49 and q is v.50-51.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν δὲ εἴπῃ ὁ κακὸς δοῦλος ἐκεῖνος ἐν τῇ καρδίᾳ αὐτοῦ Χρονίζει μου ὁ κύριος καὶ ἄρξηται τύπτειν τοὺς συνδούλους αὐτοῦ ἐσθίῃ δὲ καὶ πίνῃ μετὰ τῶν μεθυόντων

greek_apodoses.q1: ἥξει ὁ κύριος τοῦ δούλου ἐκείνου ἐν ἡμέρᾳ ᾗ οὐ προσδοκᾷ καὶ ἐν ὥρᾳ ᾗ οὐ γινώσκει

english:
q: (What will you give me)
p: (if I deliver him over to you)?
english_translations:
ESV, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NASB, NLT: "to" infinitive
notes: This is an implied conditional. The Greek says, "What are you willing to give me, and I will hand him over to you?" This is either translated in English as a conditional, or with an infinitive of purpose: "What are you willing to give me to betray him to you?" (NASB)

greek_protases.p1: κἀγὼ ὑμῖν παραδώσω αὐτόν

english:
q: (it would have been better for him)
p: (if he had not been born)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NIV, NLT: "if"
NRSV: "to" infinitive

greek_protases.p1: εἰ οὐκ ἐγεννήθη ὁ ἄνθρωπος ἐκεῖνος

english:
p: (though/even if they all fall away because of you)
q: (I will never fall away)
english_translations:
ESV, NRSV: "though"
NASB: "even though"
NIV, NLT: "even if"
notes:
While Mark represents this phrase grammatically as a concessive conditional (ει και), Matthew simply has ει. However, this verse seems to carry the same force of a concessive conditional.
The reality of this proposition is a bit complicated. In the preceding verses, Jesus has just stated that all will indeed fall away, including Peter. This conditional has Peter asserting that he will not fall away even if/though the others will.

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ πάντες σκανδαλισθήσονται ἐν σοί

english:
p: (even if I must die with you)
q: (I will not deny you)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NIV, NLT: "even if"
NRSV: "even though"
notes:
Greek: καν
The use of this concessive conditional indicates that Peter considered dying with Jesus to be an extreme situation, and so we have indicated the probability (from Peter's perspective) as very unlikely.
parallel_passages: Mark 14:31 (just εαν, but still a concessive conditional based on context)

greek_protases.p1: Κἂν δέῃ με σὺν σοὶ ἀποθανεῖν

english:
p: (if this cannot pass unless I drink it)
q: (your will be done)
notes: There is a general consensus among the commentaries (Hagner, Osbourne, and Morris) that the shift in the conditional to a negative exemplifies Jesus’ recognition that it is indeed the Father’s will for him to go to the cross. Furthermore, q is something that Jesus has acknowledged he wants, whatever the case in p; q is not directly dependent on p, but is simply relevant to it. See note on 26:42b.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ οὐ δύναται τοῦτο παρελθεῖν ἐὰν μὴ αὐτὸ πίω

english:
q: (this cannot pass)
p: (unless I drink it)
notes:
εαν μη 'if not', 'unless' 
Embedded within p in v.42a is another conditional. The entire conditional of 42b makes up p for 42a.
Paraphrase (to avoid multiple negatives in languages without 'unless' or 'except'): "(My father, if) this cup can be taken away only if I drink it, (your will be done)."

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν μὴ αὐτὸ πίω

english:
p: (if you are the Son of God)
q: (come down from the cross)
notes: Though Jesus was indeed the Christ, in the minds of the speakers, they consider Jesus' supposed inability to save himself as proof he is certainly not the Christ. The speakers are presenting p as "true for the sake of argument" in order to mock Jesus. Parallel accounts (in Mark particularly) make it clear that this was the attitude.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ υἱὸς εἶ τοῦ θεοῦ

english:
q: (let God deliver him now)
p: (if he desires him)
english_translations:
ESV, NIV, NLT: "if he desires/wants him"
NASB: "if he delights in him"
NRSV: "if he wants to"
notes: See note at 27:40. In the speakers' minds, God would not allow this injustice to occur if Jesus were really sent by him. Osbourne notes the irony that the mockings of Jesus come true in ways the speakers did not expect, as God does indeed "desire" Jesus and so raises him from the dead.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ θέλει αὐτόν

english:
p: (if this comes to the governor's ears)
q: (we will satisfy him and keep you out of trouble)

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν ἀκουσθῇ τοῦτο ἐπὶ τοῦ ἡγεμόνος

greek_apodoses.q1: ἡμεῖς πείσομεν αὐτὸν καὶ ὑμᾶς ἀμερίμνους ποιήσομεν

english:
p: (If you will) 
q: (you can make me clean)
notes: It seems that p could be merely a politeness strategy to make a request. However, the consensus of the commentaries is that while the leper is expressing faith in Jesus's ability, he is expressing doubt as to his willingness.

greek_protases.p1: Ἐὰν θέλῃς

english:
p: (If he does) 
q: (the patch tears away from it, the new from the old, and a worse tear is made)
english_translations:
ESV: "if he does"
NASB, NRSV, NIV: "otherwise"
NLT: "for"
notes: Greek: εἰ δὲ μή with an elided (understood) verb. Translator's Notes states that this phrase introduces a hypothetical situation in which someone does what is described in the last clause, making this is genuine conditional (as in ESV), although teh verb is elided in Greek.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ μή

greek_apodoses.q1: αἴρει τὸ πλήρωμα ἀπ αὐτοῦ τὸ καινὸν τοῦ παλαιοῦ καὶ χεῖρον σχίσμα γίνεται

english:
p: (If he does) 
q: (the wine will burst the skins—and the wine is destroyed, and so are the skins)
english_translations:
ESV: "if he does"
NASB, NRSV, NIV: "otherwise"
NLT: "for"
notes: Greek: εἰ δὲ μή with an elided (understood) verb. See note on 2:21.
parallel_passages: Matthew 9:17; Luke 5:37: both εἰ δὲ μή γε 'otherwise'

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ μή

greek_apodoses.q1: ῥήξει ὁ οἶνος τοὺς ἀσκούς καὶ ὁ οἶνος ἀπόλλυται καὶ οἱ ἀσκοί

english:
p: (if a kingdom is divided against itself)
q: (that kingdom cannot stand)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: untranslated

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν βασιλεία ἐφ ἑαυτὴν μερισθῇ

greek_apodoses.q1: οὐ δύναται σταθῆναι ἡ βασιλεία ἐκείνη

english:
p: (if a house is divided against itself)
q: (that house will not be able to stand)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: untranslated

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν οἰκία ἐφ ἑαυτὴν μερισθῇ

greek_apodoses.q1: οὐ δυνήσεται ἡ οἰκία ἐκείνη σταθῆναι

english:
p: (if Satan has risen up against himself and is divided)
q: (he cannot stand, but is coming to an end)
notes: Boyer (1981: 85) and Elliott (1981:206) cite this verse as class 1 whereas Guelich (1989) argues it is class 2 based on the fact that, given the previous two hypothetical examples, this situation must not be the case (and class 2 conditionals are non-factual).

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ὁ Σατανᾶς ἀνέστη ἐφ ἑαυτὸν καὶ ἐμερίσθη

greek_apodoses.q1: οὐ δύναται στῆναι ἀλλὰ τέλος ἔχει

english:
q: (no one can enter a strong man’s house and plunder his goods)
p: (unless he first binds the strong man)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB: "unless"
NRSV, NIV: "without"
NLT: untranslated ("only")
notes:
Greek: ἐὰν μὴ 'unless'.
Here Jesus is claiming that He has already bound Satan, but he does so using figurative language as is vs.24-25.
Paraphrase (to avoid multiple negatives in languages without 'unless' or 'except'): "A person can only enter the strong man's house and plunder/steal his property if he first binds the strong man."

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν μὴ πρῶτον τὸν ἰσχυρὸν δήσῃ

greek_apodoses.q1: καὶ τότε τὴν οἰκίαν αὐτοῦ διαρπάσει

english:
p: (If anyone has ears to hear,)
q: (let him hear.)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NIV: "if"
NRSV, NLT: untranslated
notes: This seems to have the same meaning as the more common "He who has ears to hear, let him hear." (See for example 4:9.)

greek_protases.p1: εἴ τις ἔχει ὦτα ἀκούειν

english:
p: (If I touch even his garments) 
q: (I will be made well)
notes: The illocutionary force category is not applicable here as the woman is speaking only to herself (which is Matthew's way of describing her thoughts).

greek_protases.p1: Ἐὰν ἅψωμαι κἂν τῶν ἱματίων αὐτοῦ

english:
q: (the Pharisees and all the Jews do not eat) 
p: (unless they wash their hands properly, holding to the tradition of the elders)
notes:
Greek: ἐὰν μὴ 'unless'
Paraphrase (to avoid multiple negatives in languages without 'unless' or 'except'): "For the Pharisees and all the Jews eat only if they carefully wash their hands, thus observing the traditions of the elders." Or: "Before they eat, they always wash their hands carefully."

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν μὴ πυγμῇ νίψωνται τὰς χεῖρας

english:
p: (unless they wash)
q: (they do not eat)
(p and q match the order of the Greek)
english_translations:
All English translations reverse the Greek order of p and q, thus matching 7:3.
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "unless"
NLT: "until"
notes:
Greek: ἐὰν μὴ.
Paraphrase (to avoid multiple negatives in languages without 'unless' or 'except'): "they eat only if they wash themselves." Or: "they always wash themselves before they eat."

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν μὴ βαπτίσωνται

english:
p: (If a man tells his father or his mother, “Whatever you would have gained from me is Corban” (that is, given to God) )
q: (then you no longer permit him to do anything for his father or mother)
english_translations:
ESV, NRSV, NIV: "if... then" (vv 11-12)
NASB: "if"
NLT: untranslated
notes: Within p there is an additional ἐὰν meaning "whatever"; see 7:11b in the non-conditionals section.

greek_protases.p1: Ἐὰν εἴπῃ ἄνθρωπος τῷ πατρὶ ἢ τῇ μητρί Κορβᾶν ὅ ἐστιν Δῶρον ὃ ἐὰν ἐξ ἐμοῦ ὠφεληθῇς

greek_apodoses.q1: οὐκέτι ἀφίετε αὐτὸν οὐδὲν ποιῆσαι τῷ πατρὶ ἢ τῇ μητρί

english:
p: (if I send them away hungry to their homes) 
q: (they will faint on the way)

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν ἀπολύσω αὐτοὺς νήστεις εἰς οἶκον αὐτῶν

english:
p: (If anyone would come after me) 
q: (let him deny himself and take up his cross and follow me)
english_translations:
"ESV, NASB: ""if anyone""
NRSV, NLT: "if any (of you)"
NIV: "whoever"
notes:
Greek ἐἴ τις 'if anyone' 
This probability is analyzed as likely because the crowd actually is there following Jesus.

greek_protases.p1: Εἴ τις θέλει ὀπίσω μου

greek_apodoses.q1: ἀπαρνησάσθω ἑαυτὸν καὶ ἀράτω τὸν σταυρὸν αὐτοῦ καὶ ἀκολουθείτω μοι

english:
p: (if you can do anything)
q: (have compassion on us and help us)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV, NLT: "if"
NLT: p and q are reversed
notes: Greek: εἴ τι. Even though in Mark 8:23 this construction was obviously non-conditional, here it most certainly is. Additionally, its function is certainly not that ascribed to class 1 conditionals by exegetes; here it expresses great doubt: "The problem is so severe that the father is not at all confident that Jesus, despite his remarkable reputation, can do anything to help" (Evans 2001: 52. See also Lane 1974: 333; France 2002: 367; Cole 1989: 220).

greek_protases.p1: εἴ τι δύνῃ

english:
p: (if you can)
q: missing
notes: Jesus is echoing the father's words in v.22 (NLT makes this clear: "What do you mean, 'If I can'?") He does this to draw attention to the father's doubt. This can be translated in the same way as the previous verse but marked in some way to show that it is a quotation.

greek_protases.p1: Τὸ Εἰ δύνῃ

english:
p: (if anyone would be first)
q: (he must be last of all and servant of all)
english_translations:
NASB, NRSV, ESV: "if anyone"
NIV: "anyone"
NLT: "whoever"
notes:
Greek: εἴ τις 'if anyone'
Here, even though we know that the disciples were just arguing about which of them was the greatest, Jesus presents this as a hypothetical situation, possibly to make the rebuke less direct.

greek_protases.p1: Εἴ τις θέλει πρῶτος εἶναι

greek_apodoses.q1: ἔσται πάντων ἔσχατος καὶ πάντων διάκονος

english:
q: (it would be better for him)
p: (if a great millstone were hung around his neck and he were thrown into the sea)
english_translations:
ESV, NSAB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: no conditional, "to" infinitive
notes: The unlikely situation of someone having a heavy milstone hung around their neck and being thrown into a sea or lake communicates just how terrible is the fate of someone who casues a "little one" to stumble.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ περίκειται μύλος ὀνικὸς περὶ τὸν τράχηλον αὐτοῦ καὶ βέβληται εἰς τὴν θάλασσαν

english:
p: (if your hand causes you to sin)
q: (cut it off)
notes: Jesus is warning and exhorting His listeners to take their sin seriously and deal with it earnestly; he is likely not implying that sin is something rare or unusual. Therefore, the probability of p being true is rated Very Likely.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν σκανδαλίζῃ σε ἡ χείρ σου

english:
p: (if your foot causes you to sin) 
q; (cut it off)
notes: See note on 9:43.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν ὁ πούς σου σκανδαλίζῃ σε

english:
p: (if your eye causes you to sin)
q: (tear it out)
notes: See note on 9:43.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν ὁ ὀφθαλμός σου σκανδαλίζῃ σε

english:
p: (if the salt has lost its saltiness)
q: (how will you make it salty again)
notes: This conditional must be read in its context of describing discipleship. The connection between salt and discipleship is that, as Marshall (1978) puts it, "a false form of discipleship may look like salt, but the gradual process of leeching leaves only a zestless pile of waste.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν δὲ τὸ ἅλας ἄναλον γένηται

english:
Modified from ESV to show Greek syntactic structure:
p: (if she {having divorced her husband} marries another)
q: (she commits adultery)
notes: The grammatically main verbs are "marry" and "commit adultery" with the part about divorce in a participial clause.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν αὐτὴ ἀπολύσασα τὸν ἄνδρα αὐτῆς γαμήσῃ ἄλλον

english:
p: (if anyone says to you, ‘Why are you doing this?’)
q: (say, ‘The Lord has need of it and will send it back here immediately.’)
notes: Greek: εαν τις 'if anyone'

greek_protases.p1: ἐάν τις ὑμῖν εἴπῃ Τί ποιεῖτε τοῦτο

greek_apodoses.q1: εἴπατε Ὁ κύριος αὐτοῦ χρείαν ἔχει καὶ εὐθὺς αὐτὸν ἀποστέλλει πάλιν ὧδε

english:
q: (forgive)
p: (if you have anything against anyone)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: no conditional

greek_protases.p1: εἴ τι ἔχετε κατά τινος

english:
p: (if we say, ‘From heaven’) 
q: (he will say, ‘Why then did you not believe him?')
notes: The alternative response "From men" in v.32 has no conditional (unlike the parallel passages in Mat 21:26 and Luke 20:6). NIV interprets this as an understood conditional with p but no q.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν εἴπωμεν Ἐξ οὐρανοῦ ἐρεῖ

greek_apodoses.q1: ἐρεῖ Διὰ τί οὖν οὐκ ἐπιστεύσατε αὐτῷ

english:
p: (if a man’s brother dies and leaves a wife, but leaves no child)
q: (the man must take the widow and raise up offspring for his brother)
notes: This conditional is a sumary of Deutoronomy 25:5-6. The Saducees use this to begin a conversation about the topic of remarriage after a death, in order to challenge Jesus.

greek_protases.p1: ἐάν τινος ἀδελφὸς ἀποθάνῃ καὶ καταλίπῃ γυναῖκα καὶ μὴ ἀφῇ τέκνον

greek_apodoses.q1: ἵνα λάβῃ ὁ ἀδελφὸς αὐτοῦ τὴν γυναῖκα καὶ ἐξαναστήσῃ σπέρμα τῷ ἀδελφῷ

english:
p: (if the Lord had not [decided to] cut short the days)
q: (no flesh [i.e. human being] would be saved)
notes:
εἰ μὴ 'if not', 'unless'
Although the events of this verse are in future time, the Greek switches from future tense to aorist in this verse (see France 2002: 527 for comments on the use of the aorist here). Many English translations reflect this tense change and use "had not cut short". Because "those days" are still in the future, this should be understood as "had not decided to cut short." This gives a non-factual interpretation: "If the Lord had not decided to cut short those days (but he did), no one would survive." This is confirmed because the parallel passage in Mat 24:22 states directly afterward that "those days will be cut short." Although the double negative makes it confusing this is a non-factual conditional. 
If this is paraphrased to avoid multiple negatives in languages without 'unless' or 'except', this should be expressed as a future event: "Only if the Lord shortens [i.e. will shorten] those days will any person (lit: flesh) be saved."

greek_protases.p1: εἰ μὴ ἐκολόβωσεν κύριος τὰς ἡμέρας

english:
p: (if anyone says to you, ‘Look, here is the Christ!’ or ‘Look, there he is!’) 
q: (do not believe it)
english_translations: ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV, NLT: "if anyone"
notes:
Greek: εαν τις 'if anyone'
This probability is very likely because Jesus states in the next verse that false messiahs will come (see also 13:6). This conditional describes what the disciples should do if or when they hear these false claims.

greek_protases.p1: ἐάν τις ὑμῖν εἴπῃ Ἴδε ὧδε ὁ χριστός Ἴδε ἐκεῖ

english:
q: (It would have been better for that man)
p: (if he had not been born)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NIV, NLT: "if"
NRSV: no conditional, "to" infinitive
notes:
This example is complex because it is comparison between a present reality and a hypothetical situation that has obviously not taken place. See Translator's Notes. 
The verb in q (translated "would have been") is missing here but is present in the parallel in Mat 26:24 and in some textual variants. Bratcher & Nida (1961: 438) state it is not original but should be supplied.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ οὐκ ἐγεννήθη ὁ ἄνθρωπος ἐκεῖνος

english:
NIV:
p: (even if all fall away)
q: (I will not)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV: "even though"
NIV, NLT: "even if"
notes:
Greek Εἰ καὶ 'even if'; this is a "concessive conditional."
It is hard to determine how likely Peter thought the other disciples were to fall away, but Edwards suggests that he saw it as somewhat likely: "Peter is not surprised at the thought of the defection of the other disciples. Perhaps he even expects it of them" (2002: 429). Cole (1989: 301) agrees.

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ καὶ πάντες σκανδαλισθήσονται

english:
p: (If I must die with you) 
q: (I will not deny you)
english_translations:
ESV: "if"
NASB, NIV, NLT: "even if"
NRSV: "even though"
notes:
Greek Ἐὰν 'if' but understood as a "concessive conditional" in most translations.
It is difficult to determine how likely Peter thought it was that he would have to die with Jesus. When the time came, he broke his promise and denied Jesus, but that does not negate what was in Peter's mind at the time he made this promise.

greek_protases.p1: Ἐὰν δέῃ με συναποθανεῖν σοι

english:
p: (if they drink any deadly poison)
q: (it will not hurt them)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NLT: "and if"
NIV: "and when"
notes:
Greek κἂν often expresses a concessive meaning ('even if') but here it seems to simply mean "and if".
Given the context that this is part of a list of of signs that Jesus says "will accompony those who believe", this situation has been classified as very likely. rather than neutral probability

greek_protases.p1: κἂν θανάσιμόν τι πίωσιν

english:
p: (if you are the Son of God)
q: (command this stone to become bread)
notes: Nolland notes that the devil (and Jesus) had no doubt about his identity as Son of God (see also note at Matthew 4:3). The Translator's Notes acknowledge that some scholars believe p is an expression of doubt, but we have interpretated this as a factual condition.

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ υἱὸς εἶ τοῦ θεοῦ

greek_apodoses.q1: εἰπὲ τῷ λίθῳ τούτῳ ἵνα γένηται ἄρτος

english:
p: (if you then will worship me)
q: (it will all be yours)
notes: In 4:3 and 4:9 the exhortations (or temptations) are direct and occur in q; in this verse the exhortation (or temptation) is made indirectly in p. This must have been a true temptation, as the devlil believed that there was a possibility, however small, that Jesus would give in to the temptation.

greek_protases.p1: σὺ οὖν ἐὰν προσκυνήσῃς ἐνώπιον ἐμοῦ

english:
p: (if you are the Son of God)
q: (throw yourself down from here)
notes: Again, we may assume the devil is fully aware that Jesus is the Son of God, but merely wishes to manipulate and tempt him by suggesting he prove it.

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ υἱὸς εἶ τοῦ θεοῦ

english:
p: (if you will)
q: (you can make me clean)
notes: Marshall considers the conditional here a mark of politeness, but it could also be expressing genuine doubt about Jesus' willingness to heal.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν θέλῃς

english:
p: (if he does)
q: (he willl tear the new and the piece from the new will not match the old)
english_translations:
NASB, NRSV, NIV: "otherwise"
ESV: "if he does"
NLT: "for then"
notes: Greek: εἰ δὲ μή γε with an elided (understood) verb. English translations express the constrcution εἰ δὲ μή γε in a variety of ways; the ESV translation shows how it is related to a conditional meaning. This phrase presents the alternative to what was described in the previous clause: "No one tears a piece from a new garment and sews it on an old garment."

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ

greek_apodoses.q1: καὶ τὸ καινὸν σχίσει καὶ τῷ παλαιῷ οὐ συμφωνήσει τὸ ἐπίβλημα τὸ ἀπὸ τοῦ καινοῦ

english:
p: (if he does)
q: (the new wine will burst the skins and it will be spilled, and the skins will be destroyed)
english_translations:
NASB, NRSV, NIV: "otherwise"
ESV: "if he does"
NLT: "for"
notes: Greek: εἰ δὲ μή γε with an elided (understood) verb; see note at 5:36.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ

greek_apodoses.q1: ῥήξει ὁ οἶνος ὁ νέος τοὺς ἀσκούς καὶ αὐτὸς ἐκχυθήσεται καὶ οἱ ἀσκοὶ ἀπολοῦνται

english:
p: (if you love those who love you)
q: (what benefit is that to you?)
notes: This verse and the next two (vs.33-34) are a series of conditional statements posed as rhetorical questions. Jesus' point is that loving one's enemies and doing good when no return is expected amounts to something truly worth rewarding in the eyes of the Father. Here, Luke uses ει in v.32 and εαν in the next two verses, but there does not seem to be any difference in the level of probabilitiy. Note also that Matthew 5:46 uses εαν.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ἀγαπᾶτε τοὺς ἀγαπῶντας ὑμᾶς

english:
p: (if you do good to those who do good to you)
q: (what benefit is that to you?)
notes: See note at 6:32.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν ἀγαθοποιῆτε τοὺς ἀγαθοποιοῦντας ὑμᾶς

english:
p: (if you lend to those from whom you expect to receive)
q: (what credit is that to you?)
notes: See note at 6:32.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν δανίσητε παρ ὧν ἐλπίζετε λαβεῖν

english:
p: (if this man were a prophet)
q: (he would have known who and what sort of woman this is, for she is a sinner)
notes: While in truth, Jesus is a prophet and does know who the woman is, in the mind of the Pharisee he does not, and so the condition is non-factual for the speaker.

greek_protases.p1: Οὗτος εἰ ἦν προφήτης

greek_apodoses.q1: ἐγίνωσκεν ἂν τίς καὶ ποταπὴ ἡ γυνὴ ἥτις ἅπτεται αὐτοῦ ὅτι ἁμαρτωλός ἐστιν

english:
q: (we have no more than five loaves and two fish)
p: (unless we are to go and buy food for all these people)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "unless"
NLT: "Or are you expecting...?"
notes:
Greek: ει μητι; Boyer notes that the μητι here is typically an interrogative particle in questions that expect a negative answer. This is likely why a subjunctive verb is used with ει here; it describes an event that is unlikely to occur.
The disciples make the observation in  q "We have no more than five loaves and two fish" in order to object to Jesus' instruction to feed the crowd. The disciples do not really believe that Jesus expects them to go and buy food (in fact, the parallel passage in Mark notes how beyond their means even a low estimate of the cost would be). 
The NLT offers an alternative to using 'unless': “But we have only five loaves of bread and two fish,” they answered. “Or are you expecting us to go and buy enough food for this whole crowd?” (This also easily fits with Nolland's assessment that this statement from the disciples "could easily be read as sarcasm".) Rephrasing this as, "We will have more than five loaves and two fish only if we go and buy food for all these people" would completely miss the point and is not an acceptable translation.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ μήτι πορευθέντες ἡμεῖς ἀγοράσωμεν εἰς πάντα τὸν λαὸν τοῦτον βρώματα

greek_apodoses.q1: Οὐκ εἰσὶν ἡμῖν πλεῖον ἢ ἄρτοι πέντε καὶ ἰχθύες δύο

english:
p: (if anyone would come after me)
q: (let him deny himself and take up his cross daily and follow me)
notes: Jesus is speaking to disciples, so the likelihood that they wish to follow him is high.

greek_protases.p1: Εἴ τις θέλει ὀπίσω μου ἔρχεσθαι

greek_apodoses.q1: ἀρνησάσθω ἑαυτὸν καὶ ἀράτω τὸν σταυρὸν αὐτοῦ καθ ἡμέραν καὶ ἀκολουθείτω μοι

english:
p: (if a son of peace is there)
q: (your peace will rest on him)
notes: Jesus compares two different types of people, but unlike 9:48 and other similar verses, he uses a regular 3rd class conditional paired with construction εἰ δὲ μή γε in v.6b.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν ᾖ ἐκεῖ υἱὸς εἰρήνης

greek_apodoses.q1: ἐπαναπαήσεται ἐπ αὐτὸν ἡ εἰρήνη ὑμῶν

english:
p: (if not) [i.e. if there is not a son of peace there]
q: (your peace will return to you)
english_translations: ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV, NLT: "if not"
notes: Greek: εἰ δὲ μή γε with an elided (understood) verb; see note at 5:36 for discussion of this construction. Mathew 10:13b has a 3rd class conditional here instead of the compressed negative construction.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ

english:
p: (if the mighty works done in you had been done in Tyre and Sidon)
q: (they would have repented long ago, sitting in sackcloth and ashes)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if...they would have..."
NLT: "if...their people would have..."
notes: Jesus' miracles were not done in Tyre and Sidon, but he predicts how the people of those towns would have acted in that case. Garland notes that the suggestion that notorious sinful cities would have repented seems quite improbable. This, however, communicates just how serious the situaiton is.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ἐν Τύρῳ καὶ Σιδῶνι ἐγενήθησαν αἱ δυνάμεις αἱ γενόμεναι ἐν ὑμῖν

greek_apodoses.q1: πάλαι ἂν ἐν σάκκῳ καὶ σποδῷ καθήμενοι μετενόησαν

english:
p: (though he will not get up and give him anything because he is his friend)
q: (yet because of his impudence he will rise and give him whatever he needs)
english_translations:
ESV, NLT: "though"
NASB, NRSV, NIV: "even though"
notes: Greek: ει και; this is a "concessive conditional." Because p is factual, most English translations use 'though' or 'even though' rather than 'even if'.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ καὶ οὐ δώσει αὐτῷ ἀναστὰς διὰ τὸ εἶναι φίλον αὐτοῦ

greek_apodoses.q1: διά γε τὴν ἀναίδειαν αὐτοῦ ἐγερθεὶς δώσει αὐτῷ ὅσων χρῄζει

english:
What father
p: (if his son ask for a fish)
q: (will give him a snake)?
notes: Although there is no conditional marker in the Greek, the sense here is clearly conditional. Jesus is asking his hearers to consider a hypothetical but commonplace scenario (a child asking for food) and an almost unthinkable response (a father giving the child something poisonous). Almost all English translations translate these verses as conditional sentences. The probability "likely" refers to the probability of p, not the probability of q (which is very unlikely to happen).

greek_protases.p1: αἰτήσει ὁ υἱὸς ἰχθύν

greek_apodoses.q1: καὶ ἀντὶ ἰχθύος ὄφιν αὐτῷ ἐπιδώσει

english:
p: or (if his son ask for an egg)
q: (will give him a scorpion)?
notes: See note at 11:11.

greek_protases.p1: αἰτήσει ᾠόν

english:
Note: in UBS Greek text, q is not a rhetorical question but rather a statement
p: (if you then, being evil, know how to give good gifts to your children)
q: (how much more will the heavenly Father give the Holy Spirit to those who ask Him)
notes: In verses 11 and 12 Jesus has just shown how human fathers give good things to their children, so this is a factual condition. The phrase "being evil" occurs within p; in some languages it may be best to rephrase p as a statement: "Although you are evil, you know how to give good gifts to your children. How much more, therefore will the heavenly Father give the Holy Spirit to those who ask Him?"

greek_protases.p1: εἰ οὖν ὑμεῖς πονηροὶ ὑπάρχοντες οἴδατε δόματα ἀγαθὰ διδόναι τοῖς τέκνοις ὑμῶν

greek_apodoses.q1: πόσῳ μᾶλλον ὁ πατὴρ ὁ ἐξ οὐρανοῦ δώσει πνεῦμα ἅγιον τοῖς αἰτοῦσιν αὐτόν

english:
p: (if Satan also is divided against himself)
q: (how will his kingdom stand?)
notes: P describes a false situation which Jesus presents as possible for the sake of argument in order to show that q is ridiculous (also in the following verse).

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ καὶ ὁ Σατανᾶς ἐφ ἑαυτὸν διεμερίσθη

english:
p: (and if I cast out demons by Beelzebul)
q: (by whom do your sons cast them out?)
notes: See v.18.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ ἐγὼ ἐν Βεελζεβοὺλ ἐκβάλλω τὰ δαιμόνια

greek_apodoses.q1: οἱ υἱοὶ ὑμῶν ἐν τίνι ἐκβάλλουσιν

english:
p: (but if I cast out demons by the finger of God)
q: (then the kingdom of God has come upon you)
notes: P is factual, though Jesus' audience may not yet be convinced of it.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ ἐν δακτύλῳ θεοῦ ἐκβάλλω τὰ δαιμόνια

greek_apodoses.q1: ἄρα ἔφθασεν ἐφ ὑμᾶς ἡ βασιλεία τοῦ θεοῦ

english:
p: (if then your whole body is full of light, having no dark part)
q: (it will be wholly bright)

greek_protases.p1: εἰ οὖν τὸ σῶμά σου ὅλον φωτεινόν μὴ ἔχον μέρος τι σκοτεινόν

english:
p: (if then you are not able to do as small a thing as that)
q: (why are you anxious about the rest?)

greek_protases.p1: εἰ οὖν οὐδὲ ἐλάχιστον δύνασθε

english:
p: (if God so clothes the grass, which is alive in the field today and tomorrow is thrown into the oven)
q: (how much more will he clothe you, oh you of little faith!)
notes: Jesus is using a widely known fact in p to argue for the point he makes in q, that God will indeed take care to clothe his people.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ ἐν ἀγρῷ τὸν χόρτον ὄντα σήμερον καὶ αὔριον εἰς κλίβανον βαλλόμενον ὁ θεὸς οὕτως ἀμφιέζει

english:
ESV with modifications in brackets to reflect the Greek structure:
p: ([even] if he comes in the second watch, [even if] he comes in the third watch and finds them awake)
q: (blessed are those servants)
english_translations:
ESV, NRSV: "if"
NASB: "whether... or even"
NIV: "even if"
NLT: untranslated ("may")
notes: Greek: καν...καν...; q is not dependent on when the master returns (the second watch is the mniddle of the night, the third watch is just before dawn). Rather, q is dependent on the master finding the servants awake and alert at whatever time he arrives.

greek_protases.p1: κἂν ἐν τῇ δευτέρᾳ κἂν ἐν τῇ τρίτῃ φυλακῇ ἔλθῃ καὶ εὕρῃ οὕτως

english:
p: (if the master of the house had known at what hour the thief was coming)
q: (he would not have left his house to be broken into)
notes: The sentence is referring to a past time situation, but it should be understood as being applied metaphorically to the return of Christ, which can occur at any time (see v.40).

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ᾔδει ὁ οἰκοδεσπότης ποίᾳ ὥρᾳ ὁ κλέπτης ἔρχεται

greek_apodoses.q1: οὐκ ἂν ἀφῆκεν διορυχθῆναι τὸν οἶκον αὐτοῦ

english:
p: (but if that servant says, "my master is delayed in coming", and begins to beat the male and female servants, and to eat and drink and get drunk)
q: (the master of that servant will come on a day he does not expect and an hour he does not know, and will cut him in pieces and put him with the unfaithful)
notes: P makes up v.45, while q makes up v.46.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν δὲ εἴπῃ ὁ δοῦλος ἐκεῖνος ἐν τῇ καρδίᾳ αὐτοῦ Χρονίζει ὁ κύριός μου ἔρχεσθαι καὶ ἄρξηται τύπτειν τοὺς παῖδας καὶ τὰς παιδίσκας ἐσθίειν τε καὶ πίνειν καὶ μεθύσκεσθαι

greek_apodoses.q1: ἥξει ὁ κύριος τοῦ δούλου ἐκείνου ἐν ἡμέρᾳ ᾗ οὐ προσδοκᾷ καὶ ἐν ὥρᾳ ᾗ οὐ γινώσκει καὶ διχοτομήσει αὐτὸν καὶ τὸ μέρος αὐτοῦ μετὰ τῶν ἀπίστων θήσει

english:
p: (if you do not repent)
q: (you will all likewise perish)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV, NLT: "unless"
(NLT inverts p and q)
notes:
Jesus is speaking to a general crowd here, so the probability of p is uncertain. 
These two (almost) identical sentences (13:3 and 13:5) have the regular order p>q and q is affirmative. If your language has no equivalent of 'unless', just follow the Greek: "If you(pl) do not repent, you will all perish too."

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν μὴ μετανοῆτε

english:
p: (if you do not repent)
q: (you will all likewise perish)
notes: See note at 13:3.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν μὴ μετανοῆτε

english:
Note: q is elided in the Greek
p: (if it should bear fruit next year)
q: [elided]
notes:
Greek: καν 'even if'. 
The five English translations treat this as a conditional and supply q ("fine" or "well and good"). Alternatively the Translator's Referene Transaltion suggests: "Maybe it will produce fruit next year."

greek_protases.p1: κἂν μὲν ποιήσῃ καρπὸν εἰς τὸ μέλλον

english:
Clarification in brackets
p: (if not) [if it does not bear fruit]
q: (you can cut it down)
notes: Greek: εἰ δὲ μή γε with an elided (understood) verb. See note at 5:36 for discussion of this construction and note at 13:9b for context.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ

english:
ESV:
p: (Which of you, having a son or an ox that has fallen into a well on a Sabbath day
q: (will not immediately pull him out?)
NIV:
p: (If one of you has a child or an ox that falls into a well on the Sabbath day
q: (will you not immediately pull it out?)
english_translations:
ESV: gerund "having"
NASB: future "will have"
NRSV, NIV, NLT: "if"
notes: This is an implied conditional in Greek; the main verb in the protasis is missing. The phrase "on the Sabbath" is part of the apodosis in the Greek text.

greek_protases.p1: Τίνος ὑμῶν υἱὸς ἢ βοῦς εἰς φρέαρ πεσεῖται

greek_apodoses.q1: καὶ οὐκ εὐθέως ἀνασπάσει αὐτὸν ἐν ἡμέρᾳ τοῦ σαββάτου

english:
p: (if anyone comes to me and does not hate his own father and mother and wife and children and brothers and sisters, yes even his own life)
q: (he cannot be my disciple)
notes: Jesus uses hyperbolic language in a conditional to introduce his discussion of the need to understand the cost of being a disciple.

greek_protases.p1: Εἴ τις ἔρχεται πρός με καὶ οὐ μισεῖ τὸν πατέρα ἑαυτοῦ καὶ τὴν μητέρα καὶ τὴν γυναῖκα καὶ τὰ τέκνα καὶ τοὺς ἀδελφοὺς καὶ τὰς ἀδελφάς ἔτι τε καὶ τὴν ψυχὴν ἑαυτοῦ

english:
Clarification in brackets
p: (if not) [if the king is not able to afford going to battle]
q: (while the other is still a great way off, he sends a delegation and asks for terms of peace)
english_translations:
ESV, NRSV, NIV, NLT: "if...not"
NASB: "or else"
notes: Greek: εἰ δὲ μή γε with an elided (understood) verb. See note at 5:36 for discussion of this construction.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ

greek_apodoses.q1: ἔτι αὐτοῦ πόρρω ὄντος πρεσβείαν ἀποστείλας ἐρωτᾷ τὰ πρὸς εἰρήνην

english:
p: (if salt has lost its taste)
q: (how shall its saltiness be restored?)
notes: This conditional must be read in its context of describing discipleship. The connection between salt and discipleship is that, as Marshall (1978) puts it, "a false form of discipleship may look like salt, but the gradual process of leeching leaves only a zestless pile of waste."

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν δὲ καὶ τὸ ἅλας μωρανθῇ

english:
p: (if she loses a coin)
q: ([what woman] does not light a lamp and sweep the house and seek diligently until she finds it)
notes: This conditional introduces the parable of the woman with the lost coin. While Jesus is asserting a fact about a relatable situation, he is using the parable to teach about sinners repenting.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν ἀπολέσῃ δραχμὴν μίαν

greek_apodoses.q1: οὐχὶ ἅπτει λύχνον καὶ σαροῖ τὴν οἰκίαν καὶ ζητεῖ ἐπιμελῶς ἕως οὗ εὕρῃ

english:
p: (if then you have not been faithful with unrighteous wealth)
q: (who will entrust to you the true riches?)

greek_protases.p1: εἰ οὖν ἐν τῷ ἀδίκῳ μαμωνᾷ πιστοὶ οὐκ ἐγένεσθε

english:
p: (if you have not been faithful with that which is another's)
q: (who will give you that which is your own?)

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ἐν τῷ ἀλλοτρίῳ πιστοὶ οὐκ ἐγένεσθε

english:
p: (if someone goes to them from the dead)
q: (they will repent)
notes: The rich man seemed convinced that a visit from the dead would convince his family members of God's truth. He would likely not have made the suggestion if he did not believe it possible or even likely.

greek_protases.p1: ἐάν τις ἀπὸ νεκρῶν πορευθῇ πρὸς αὐτοὺς

english:
p: (if they do not hear Moses and the prophets)
q: (neither will they be convinced if someone should rise from the dead)
notes: P is factual because the rich man's relatives are not listening to the Law and Prophets. Q itself consists of a conditional sentence.

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ Μωϋσέως καὶ τῶν προφητῶν οὐκ ἀκούουσιν

greek_apodoses.q1: οὐδ ἐάν τις ἐκ νεκρῶν ἀναστῇ πεισθήσονται

english:
Order modified to reflect the Greek
p: ([neither] if someone should rise from the dead)
q: (will they be convinced)
english_translations:
ESV: "if"
NASB, NRSV, NIV, NLT: "even if"
notes: This conditional makes up the q of v.31a. Although Greek just has ἐάν 'if', p is so unlikely (from the perspective of the characters in teh story) that most English translations treat this as a concessive conditional and use "even if". Most English translations also reverse the order and put q before p.

greek_protases.p1: ἐάν τις ἐκ νεκρῶν ἀναστῇ

english:
q: (it would be better for him)
p: (if a milstone were hung around his neck and he were cast into the sea)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV: "if"
NIV, NLT: untranslated
notes: The unlikely situation of someone having a heavy milstone hung around their neck and being thrown into a sea or lake communicates just how terrible is the fate of someone who casues a "little one" to stumble.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ λίθος μυλικὸς περίκειται περὶ τὸν τράχηλον αὐτοῦ καὶ ἔρριπται εἰς τὴν θάλασσαν

english:
p: (if your brother sins)
q: (rebuke him)
notes: The second person pronouns ('your', 'you') and the verbs 'rebuke' and 'forgive' in vs.3-4 are all singular; Jesus is addressing each of his discples individually.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν ἁμάρτῃ ὁ ἀδελφός σου

english:
p: (if he repents)
q: (forgive him)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NIV, NLT: "even if"

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν μετανοήσῃ

english:
p: (if he sins against you seven times in the day and turns to you seven times, saying, "I repent")
q: (you must forgive him)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV: "if"
NIV, NLT: "even if"
notes: Although the form of the conditional here is the same as in v.3 (ἐὰν 'if), v.4 describes a more unlikely event, and so the NIV and NLT translate it here as a concessive conditional 'even if'. The command to forgive has the same verb as in v.3b but the form of the verb is different; ESV, NRSV, NIV, and NLT all translate this as "you must forgive".

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν ἑπτάκις τῆς ἡμέρας ἁμαρτήσῃ εἰς σὲ καὶ ἑπτάκις ἐπιστρέψῃ πρὸς σὲ λέγων Μετανοῶ

english:
Modified to better reflect the verb tense/aspect of the Greek
p: (if you have faith like a grain of mustard seed)
q: (you could have been saying to the mulberry tree, "..." and it would have obeyed you.)
notes:
This ia mixed conditional: p has εἰ μὴ plus an indicative present verb, typical of class 1; q has ἂν which is typical of class 2. Boyer suggests that αν is being used with an alternative meaning, something like "could".
The probability is debatable here. In the parallel passage in Matthew 17:20, Jesus describes the disciples as having "so little faith. However, the time reference appears to be gnomic rather than restricted to the moment of speech, suggesting that this statement is applicable to all who have faith rather than just to the original disciples. However, the context here is different, and Jesus seems to be teaching them that the dsiciples do not require an increase of faith, but rather that whatever faith they have is enough to produce great results.

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ ἔχετε πίστιν ὡς κόκκον σινάπεως

greek_apodoses.q1: ἐλέγετε ἂν τῇ συκαμίνῳ ταύτῃ Ἐκριζώθητι καὶ φυτεύθητι ἐν τῇ θαλάσσῃ καὶ ὑπήκουσεν ἂν ὑμῖν

english:
p: (though I neither fear God nor respect man)
q: (yet because this widow keeps bothering me, I will give her justice)
english_translations:
ESV, NRSV: "though"
NIV, NASB: "even though"
NLT: untranslated
notes: This is a "concessive conditional." Because p is factual, most English translations use 'though' or 'even though' rather than 'even if'/

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ καὶ τὸν θεὸν οὐ φοβοῦμαι οὐδὲ ἄνθρωπον ἐντρέπομαι

greek_apodoses.q1: διά γε τὸ παρέχειν μοι κόπον τὴν χήραν ταύτην ἐκδικήσω αὐτήν

english:
NASB:
p: (if I have defrauded anyone of anything)
q: (I will give back four times as much)
notes: From what is known about tax collectors at the time, it is highly likely that Zaccaeus did extort money. He would likely not be in doubt and know for sure as well, so while he presents this as a condtional, he is most likely stating a known fact. Effectively he is saying, "I will pay back four times as much to everyone I have defrauded."

greek_protases.p1: εἴ τινός τι ἐσυκοφάντησα

english:
p: (If anyone asks you, 'why are you untying it?')
q: (you shall say this: 'The Lord has need of it.')
notes: Greek: εαν τις 'if anyone'

greek_protases.p1: ἐάν τις ὑμᾶς ἐρωτᾷ Διὰ τί λύετε

greek_apodoses.q1: οὕτως ἐρεῖτε ὅτι Ὁ κύριος αὐτοῦ χρείαν ἔχει

english:
NASB:
p: (if these become silent)
q: (the stones will cry out)
notes: The question of how to read the verbs has a great influence over the interpretation of this conditional. In Greek, both the verb of p and q are future indicative (which is an unusual pairing with εαν). Some English translations interpret this conditional as a counterfactual, referring to the present or pas: the people are not silent, but if they were currently silent, the stones would have/would be crying out. Other English translations (NASB', NIV, NLT) express p as a possible future event: "if they become silent, the stones will cry out."

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν οὗτοι σιωπήσουσιν

english:
p: (if we say 'from heaven')
q: (he will say 'why did you not believe him')
notes: The conditionals in this verse and the next should be understood as a pair; together they give the two possible answers to Jesus' question and the consequences of each.

greek_protases.p1: Ἐὰν εἴπωμεν Ἐξ οὐρανοῦ

greek_apodoses.q1: ἐρεῖ Διὰ τί οὐκ ἐπιστεύσατε αὐτῷ

english:
p: (but if we say 'from man')
q: (all the people will stone us to death)
notes: See note on v.5.
parallel_passages: Matthew 21:26 (Mark 11:32 is truncated; no overt conditional

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν δὲ εἴπωμεν Ἐξ ἀνθρώπων

english:
p: (if a man's brother dies, having a wife but no children)
q: (the man must take the widow and raise up offspring for his brother)
notes: This conditional is a sumary of Deutoronomy 25:5-6. The Saducees use this to begin a conversation about the topic of remarriage after a death in order to challenge Jesus.

greek_protases.p1: ἐάν τινος ἀδελφὸς ἀποθάνῃ ἔχων γυναῖκα καὶ οὗτος ἄτεκνος ᾖ

greek_apodoses.q1: ἵνα λάβῃ ὁ ἀδελφὸς αὐτοῦ τὴν γυναῖκα καὶ ἐξαναστήσῃ σπέρμα τῷ ἀδελφῷ

english:
p: (if you are willing)
q: (remove this cup from me)
notes: There is a textual variant here that has an infinitive instead of an imperative, which produces, "If you wish to take this cup from me," and elides q.
parallel_passages: Matthew 26:39 (if possible); Mark 14:35/36 (if it were possible)

greek_protases.p1: εἰ βούλει

greek_apodoses.q1: παρένεγκε τοῦτο τὸ ποτήριον ἀπ ἐμοῦ

english:
p: (if you are the Christ)
q: (tell us)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: treated as direct question marker ("Tell us, are you the Messiah?")
notes: The Jewish leaders are once again not really interested in genuinely discovering the truth. Nolland views this as another trap in order to have something to accuse Jesus with. In the minds of the speakers, there is very low probability that Jesus is the Christ. However, they want him to state who he is, whether or not he will claim to be Christ. The NLT has a reasonable interpretation, taking this as asking "if/whether."

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ σὺ εἶ ὁ χριστός

english:
p: (if I tell you)
q: (you will not believe)
notes: The authorities have already shown in 20:1-8 that their desire is not to discover the truth. They have already made their decision to condemn Jesus and seek only an opportunity for accusation. Jesus' response here and in v.68 shows that he does not intend to answer them, and the "very unlikely" probablity represents Jesus' evaluation.

greek_protases.p1: Ἐὰν ὑμῖν εἴπω

english:
p: (if I ask you)
q: (you will not answer)
notes: As in v.67b, the Sanhedrin is not interested in truth, so if Jesus was to ask them a question, they would likely side-step it and refuse to answer, as they did in Luke 20:5-6.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν δὲ ἐρωτήσω

english:
p: (if they do these things when the wood is green)
q: (what will happen when it is dry?)
notes: In this verse, Jesus uses metephorical language to describe what is happening to him (a factual condtion), and asks a rhetorical question (also using the same metaphor) to warn of judgement that will come.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ἐν τῷ ὑγρῷ ξύλῳ ταῦτα ποιοῦσιν

english:
q: (let him save himself)
p: (if he is the Christ of God, his Chosen One)
notes: The challenges in this verse and in v.37 are not genuine, and the the speakers do not believe p is true. They only use p to mock Jesus and scoff at his claims.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ οὗτός ἐστιν ὁ χριστὸς τοῦ θεοῦ ὁ ἐκλεκτός

english:
p: (if you are the King of the Jews)
q: (save yourself)
notes: See note at 23:35.

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ σὺ εἶ ὁ βασιλεὺς τῶν Ἰουδαίων

english:
q: (then why are you baptizing?)
p: (if you are neither the Christ, nor Elijah, nor the the Prophet)
notes: John confirms in the previous verses the truth of p. The question they ask is relevant to John's identity, as his identity would be a signal to them of his authority to baptize.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ σὺ οὐκ εἶ ὁ χριστὸς

english:
q: (no one can do these signs you do)
p: (unless God is with him)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB: "unless"
NRSV, NLT: untranslated
NIV: "if...not"
notes: This conditional presents Nicodemus's belief in Jesus' miracles being a sign that he is from God. P describes a hypothetical circumstance, even though this conditional as a whole presents a firm belief about miracles in general. While most English translations use "unless" in a similar syntactic form to the Greek, Translator's Notes suggests that it may be better understood by reframing the double negative as a positive (to avoid multiple negatives in languages without 'unless' or 'except'): "for a person can do the signs/miracles that you do only if God is with him." Or "The only way one could...is if God was with him."

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν μὴ ᾖ ὁ θεὸς μετ αὐτοῦ

greek_apodoses.q1: οὐδεὶς γὰρ δύναται ταῦτα τὰ σημεῖα ποιεῖν ἃ σὺ ποιεῖς

english:
p: (unless one is born again)
q: (he cannot see the kingdom of God)
notes:
Paraphrase (to avoid multiple negatives in languages without 'unless' or 'except'): "Only if a person is born again can s/he see the Kingdom of God." Or: “The only way for people to enter the Kingdom of God is if they are born again." 
This conditional (and the conditional in 3:5) is used by Jesus to specifically correct misconceptions about how one enters the Kingdom of Heaven (Fong 86).

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν μή τις γεννηθῇ ἄνωθεν

greek_apodoses.q1: οὐ δύναται ἰδεῖν τὴν βασιλείαν τοῦ θεοῦ

english:
p: (unless one is born of water and the Spirit)
q: (he cannot enter the kingdom of God)
notes:
Paraphrase (to avoid multiple negatives in languages without 'unless' or 'except'): "only if a person is born of water and the Spirit can s/he enter into the Kingdom of God." Or: “the only way for people to enter the kingdom of God is if they are born of water and the Spirit."
See note at 3:3.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν μή τις γεννηθῇ ἐξ ὕδατος καὶ πνεύματος

greek_apodoses.q1: οὐ δύναται εἰσελθεῖν εἰς τὴν βασιλείαν τοῦ θεοῦ

english:
p: (if I have told you of earthly things and you do not believe)
q: (how can you believe if I tell you heavenly things?)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NLT: "if"
NIV: untranslated
notes: Trail discusses various options for what Jesus is implying by his rhetorical question in q; see note at 3:12b for further discussion regarding the embedded conditional.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ τὰ ἐπίγεια εἶπον ὑμῖν

greek_apodoses.q1: πῶς ἐὰν εἴπω ὑμῖν τὰ ἐπουράνια πιστεύσετε

english:
q: (how can you believe?)
p: (if I tell you about heavenly things)
notes: Jesus could be saying that it is useless to teach about heavenly things or that Nicodemus certainly won't believe in heavenly things (these options would make the probability of p unlikely). On the other hand, Jesus could be intending to discuss heavenly things with Nicodemus (which would make the probability of p likely). We are inclined to interpret towards the latter option.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν εἴπω ὑμῖν τὰ ἐπουράνια

english:
ESV:
q: (a person cannot receive one thing)
p: (unless it is given to him from heaven)

NRSV:
q: (no one can receive anything)
p: (except what has been given from heaven)
notes:
Some scholars believe that John is specifically talking about Jesus because of the disciples' question in v.26. If this is the case, John would be saying that Jesus would not gain followers if God did not give them to him. However, it is also appropriate to interpret this verse as giving a general truth, which applies to Jesus and also to John.
Paraphrase (to avoid multiple negatives in languages without 'unless' or 'except'): "A person can only recieve something if it is given to him by God." Or: "A person can receive only what is given them from heaven." (NIV)

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν μὴ ᾖ δεδομένον αὐτῷ ἐκ τοῦ οὐρανοῦ

greek_apodoses.q1: Οὐ δύναται ἄνθρωπος λαμβάνειν οὐδὲ ἓν

english:
p: (if you knew the gift of God and who it is that is saying to you "Give me a drink")
q: (you would have asked him and he would have given you living water.)
notes: Jesus uses the conditional to point out what the Samaritan women did not know and the appropriate response to this revelation. Though the woman is surprised Jesus is speaking with her, as Klink points out, "the surprise is greater than [she] can imagine."

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ ᾔδεις τὴν δωρεὰν τοῦ θεοῦ καὶ τίς ἐστιν ὁ λέγων σοι

greek_apodoses.q1: Δός μοι πεῖν σὺ ἂν ᾔτησας αὐτὸν καὶ ἔδωκεν ἄν σοι ὕδωρ ζῶν

english:
p: (unless you see signs and wonders)
q: (you will not believe)
notes:
The use of plural 'you' pronouns shows that Jesus is addressing the people in general and not just the offical who has requested a miracle from him.
Paraphrase (to avoid multiple negatives in languages without 'unless' or 'except'): "Only if you(pl) see signs and wonders will you believe."

greek_protases.p1: Ἐὰν μὴ σημεῖα καὶ τέρατα ἴδητε

english:
NASB:
q: (the Son can do nothing of Himself)
p: (unless it is something he sees the father doing)

NRSV:
q: (the son can do nothing on his own)
p: (but only what he sees the Father doing)
english_translations:
ESV, NRSV: "but only"
NASB: "unless"
NIV, NLT: separate independent clauses, p has "only"
notes: Four of the five sample English translations do not translate this as a conditional, but rather as a conveying a sense of the "only" way p positively takes place (e.g. NIV: "the son can do nothing by himself; he can only do what he sees his Father doing..."). Trail suggests that εαν μη has a meaning of "except" here, but Boyer does not consider this a true "exceptive" use of the condtional as there is no elipsis. Fong claims that this is a conditional and in fact serves as a point of departure for this chunk of discourse (vs.19-30).

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν μή τι βλέπῃ τὸν πατέρα ποιοῦντα

greek_apodoses.q1: οὐ δύναται ὁ υἱὸς ποιεῖν ἀφ ἑαυτοῦ οὐδὲν

english:
