p: (if I alone bear witness to myself)
q: (my testimony is not true)
notes: Though this is syntactically a class 3 conditional (which usually have neutral probability), Jesus states in the next verse that p is non-factual.

greek_protases.p1: Ἐὰν ἐγὼ μαρτυρῶ περὶ ἐμαυτοῦ

greek_apodoses.q1: ἡ μαρτυρία μου οὐκ ἔστιν ἀληθής

english:
p: (if another comes in his own name)
q: (you will receive him)
notes: Klink here notes that Jesus' point here is not to prophesy about another person coming, but rather to talk about in whose authority a person may come. Jesus comes "in my Father's name" (i.e. with God's authority), while others would come simply with their own authority.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν ἄλλος ἔλθῃ ἐν τῷ ὀνόματι τῷ ἰδίῳ

english:
p: (if you believed Moses)
q: (you would believe me)
notes: Because Jesus has already stated that the audience does not believe him (see v.43) this conditional means that they also do not believe Moses, because Moses wrote about Jesus. Jesus continues this line of thought in v.47.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ γὰρ ἐπιστεύετε Μωϋσεῖ

english:
p: (if you do not believe his writings)
q: (how will you believe my words?)
notes: Based on the conclusion in the previous conditional, that belief in Moses equates to belief in Jesus, because Moses wrote about him, Jesus asks a rhetorical question in q. As well as being used to rebuke the audience, Trail notes that this rhetorical question also has a function of expressing sadness (lament).

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ τοῖς ἐκείνου γράμμασιν οὐ πιστεύετε

english:
q: (no one can come to me)
p: (unless the Father, who sent me, draws him)
notes: Paraphrase (to avoid multiple negatives for languages without 'unless' or 'except'): “A person can come to me only if the Father who sent me draws him" or "The only way a person can come to me is if my Father draws him" (Translator's Notes; see also Jhn 6:65).

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν μὴ ὁ πατὴρ ὁ πέμψας με ἑλκύσῃ αὐτόν

english:
p: (if anyone eats of this bread)
q: (he will live forever)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB: "if anyone"
NRSV, NIV: "whoever"
NLT: "anyone who"
notes: Greek: ἐάν τις "if anyone"

greek_protases.p1: ἐάν τις φάγῃ ἐκ τούτου τοῦ ἄρτου

english:
p: (unless you eat the flesh of the Son of Man and drink his blood)
q: (you have no life in you)
notes: Paraphrase (to avoid multiple negatives in languages without 'unless' or 'except'): "only if you eat the flesh and drink the blood of the Son of Man can you have life in yourselves."

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν μὴ φάγητε τὴν σάρκα τοῦ υἱοῦ τοῦ ἀνθρώπου καὶ πίητε αὐτοῦ τὸ αἷμα

english:
ESV (q is in brackets to show that it is not in the Greek)
q [what]
p: (if you were to see the Son of Man ascending to where he was before?)
notes: Jesus' emphasis here is clearly not on a prediction of what they will or won't see, but on their response if they were to see him ascending to heaven. Some commentators (like Carson) believe Jesus is referring not only to his post-resurrection ascension, but also to the cross.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν οὖν θεωρῆτε τὸν υἱὸν τοῦ ἀνθρώπου ἀναβαίνοντα

english:
q: (no one can come to me)
p: (unless it is granted by the Father)
notes: Paraphrase (to avoid multiple negatives in languages without 'unless' or 'except'): "a person can only come to me if it has been granted him from the Father." (NIV "... if the Father has enabled them")

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν μὴ ᾖ δεδομένον αὐτῷ ἐκ τοῦ πατρός

english:
p: (if you do these things)
q: (show yourself to the world)
notes: Translator's Notes and Trail both acknowledge that there are two possible readings of this conditional. 1) The brothers could be mocking Jesus; they do not believe that he can do "these things" and are just presenting this as "true for the sake of argument". This reading is supported by v.5, and Klink advocates it. 2) Jesus' brothers were well aware of Jesus' miracles and thus encouraged him to be "public" with his ministry. In this case v.5 would mean that Jesus' brothers did not acknowledge appropriately what his miracles actually meant for them and the world. We have followed the first interpretation and given the illocutionary force as "mock".

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ταῦτα ποιεῖς

english:
p: (if anyone's will is to do God's will)
q: (he will know whether the teaching is from God or whether I am speaking on my own authority)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB: "if anyone"
NRSV, NIV, NLT: "anyone who"
notes: Translator's Notes mentions that Jesus' statement here applies to anyone but especially to his immediate listeners. Jesus makes a connection between a willingness to do God's will and understanding that Jesus' teaching is truly from God.

greek_protases.p1: ἐάν τις θέλῃ τὸ θέλημα αὐτοῦ ποιεῖν

greek_apodoses.q1: γνώσεται περὶ τῆς διδαχῆς πότερον ἐκ τοῦ θεοῦ ἐστιν ἢ ἐγὼ ἀπ ἐμαυτοῦ λαλῶ

english:
p: (if on the Sabbath a man receives circumcision, so that the law of Moses may not be broken)
q: (are you angry with me because on the Sabbath I made a man's whole body well?)
notes: It was true that baby boys were circumcised on the Sabbath if necessary, but Jesus is not referring to a specific occurrence. His point is to show the Pharisees where they are holding a double standard and failing to follow the spirit of the law.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ περιτομὴν λαμβάνει ἄνθρωπος ἐν σαββάτῳ ἵνα μὴ λυθῇ ὁ νόμος Μωϋσέως

greek_apodoses.q1: ἐμοὶ χολᾶτε ὅτι ὅλον ἄνθρωπον ὑγιῆ ἐποίησα ἐν σαββάτῳ

english:
p: (if anyone thirsts)
q: (let him come to me and drink)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB: "if"
NRSV, NIV, NLT: no conditional used
notes: Greek: ἐάν τις "if anyone"

greek_protases.p1: Ἐάν τις διψᾷ

english:
q: (our law does not judge a man / does our law judge a man)
p: (unless it first hears from him and knows what he is doing)
english_translations:
NASB: "unless"
ESV, NRSV, NIV: "without" (no conditional)
NLT: "before" (no conditional)
notes:
As Klink and Beasley-Murray both note, it was indeed in the Jewish law that judgement should not be passed until someone had spoken for themselves. Nicodemus' view here is more than merely a reminder of legal technicality, but rather a subtle indication that he did not support Jesus' condemnation.
This whole verse is a question that expects the answer "No!" NASB and NRSV do this with a tag question, "does it?" 
Both clauses are negated in Greek (our law does not judge a man if it does not first hear from him...). To avoid multiple negatives, q can be expressed as affirmative (as in the ESV, NRSN, NIV, and NLT). If necessary, the answer to the question can be supplied: "Of course not."
Note also that the Greek literally says that the law judges and hears. If this is unnatural or confusing, here is an alternative: "According to our law, can we judge a man before we have listened to him and learned what he has done? No (we can't)."

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν μὴ ἀκούσῃ πρῶτον παρ αὐτοῦ καὶ γνῷ τί ποιεῖ

greek_apodoses.q1: Μὴ ὁ νόμος ἡμῶν κρίνει τὸν ἄνθρωπον

english:
p: (Even if I do bear witness about myself)
q: (my testimony is true)
english_translations:
NASB, ESV, RSV, NIV: "even if"
NLT: "even though" (inverted)
notes:
Greek: καν; this is a "concessive conditional". It is treated by four of the five English versions as a true conditional including "if".
Though this verse seems to contradict 5:31, Klink explains that "the Son is so dependent on the Father that he is unable to provide a witness for himself; the witness of Jesus must be rooted in the Father (and empowered by the Spirit). But that does not mean that Jesus’s self-witness, when rooted in the Trinitarian identity of God, is not therefore valid and “true.” It is further affirmed in v.18.

greek_protases.p1: Κἂν ἐγὼ μαρτυρῶ περὶ ἐμαυτοῦ

english:
p: (even if I do judge)
q: (my judgement is true)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "even if"
NLT: "if"
notes:
Greek: και εαν; this is a "concessive conditional."
Like v.14, this concessive conditional seems to contradict a previous assertion (v.15). Again Klink as well as the Translator's Notes clarify that Jesus does indeed judge, a factual condition. Translator's Notes offer multiple possible interpretations of v.15 which explain how both verses can be simultaneously true.

greek_protases.p1: καὶ ἐὰν κρίνω δὲ ἐγώ

greek_apodoses.q1: ἡ κρίσις ἡ ἐμὴ ἀληθινή ἐστιν

english:
p: (if you knew me)
q: (you would know the Father also)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: "since" + negation
notes: Jesus argues from the fact that the Pharisees do not "know" him, that is, have a relationship with him and know he is God's son (Translator's Notes), they therefore do not know (have a relationship with) the Father.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ἐμὲ ᾔδειτε

greek_apodoses.q1: καὶ τὸν πατέρα μου ἂν ᾔδειτε

english:
ESV:
p: (unless you believe that I am he)
q: (you will die in your sins)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NLT: "unless" (NRSV inverts)
NIV: "if...not"
notes: Klink classifies the Jews' lack of belief as "uncertain, though likely" and notes that it "offers a hint of hope to the Jews." The probability rating "Very Likely" refers to "you do not believe". See NIV: "if you do not believe that I am he, you will indeed die in your sins."

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν γὰρ μὴ πιστεύσητε ὅτι ἐγώ εἰμι

english:
p: (if you abide by my word)
q v.31: (you are truly my disciples)
q v.32: (and you will know the truth, and the truth will set you free)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV, NLT: "if"
(NLT inverts)
notes: Though the verse states that Jesus was speaking to those who believed in him, the passage shows that the faith was not a lasting one. Here Jesus' conditional seems to offer no indication of whether or not he expected the audience to actually "remain" in him. Q seems to contain three clauses, though it is possible to read v. 32 as a separate elaboration of the result of being a disciple (see NIV). If v.32 is included in the q, interestingly, that puts q in v.31 in a different semantic relation than q in v.32. The first is an evidence-inference relationship (abiding in my word shows that you are my disciples), while the second and third clauses in v. 32 would be in a cause-effect relation to p (abiding in my word will cause you to know the truth).

greek_protases.p1: Ἐὰν ὑμεῖς μείνητε ἐν τῷ λόγῳ τῷ ἐμῷ

greek_apodoses.q1: ἀληθῶς μαθηταί μού ἐστε καὶ γνώσεσθε τὴν ἀλήθειαν καὶ ἡ ἀλήθεια ἐλευθερώσει ὑμᾶς

english:
p: (if the son sets you free)
q: (you will be free indeed)

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν οὖν ὁ υἱὸς ὑμᾶς ἐλευθερώσῃ

english:
modification in brackets to reflect the Greek
p: (if you [are/were] Abraham's children)
q: (you would be doing the works Abraham did)
notes: It is heavily debated whether this is a factual condition (Jesus is echoing "Abraham is our father") or a non-factual condition (Jesus is expressing his own belief). This is because of a textual variant; the NET translation has the following note: "Although most manuscripts have the imperfect ἦτε (ēte, “you were”) here, making this sentence a proper second class condition, the harder reading, ἐστε (este, “you are”), is found in the better witnesses." English translations that interpret it as factual use the present "If you are..." (NASB, NET); those that interpret it as non-factual use the past subjunctive "if you were" (ESV, NRSV, NIV, NLT). Most translations treat q as a statement "you would be doing" (ESV, NRSV, NET) or "you would do" (NIV) but NASB treats q as a command "do the deeds of Abraham." Jesus' point is that though his audience may indeed be Abraham's biological descendents, they were not in fact his spiritual descendents, based on their actions.

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ τέκνα τοῦ Ἀβραάμ ἐστε

english:
p: (if God were your Father)
q: (you would love me)
notes: This conditional is more clearly non-actual than v.39.

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ ὁ θεὸς πατὴρ ὑμῶν ἦν

english:
p: (if I tell the truth)
q: (why do you not believe me?)
notes: This is clearly factual, as Jesus stated in v.45 "I tell the truth".

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ἀλήθειαν λέγω

greek_apodoses.q1: διὰ τί ὑμεῖς οὐ πιστεύετέ μοι

english:
p: (if anyone obeys my word)
q: (he will never see death)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB: "if anyone..."
NIV, NRSV: "whoever"
NLT: "anyone who..."
notes: Greek: ἐάν τις 'if anyone'

greek_protases.p1: ἐάν τις τὸν ἐμὸν λόγον τηρήσῃ

greek_apodoses.q1: θάνατον οὐ μὴ θεωρήσῃ εἰς τὸν αἰῶνα

english:
p: (if anyone obeys my word)
q: (he will never see death)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB: "if anyone..."
NIV, NRSV: "whoever"
NLT: "anyone who..."
notes: This verse is a word-for-word quote of v.51; see note there.

greek_protases.p1: Ἐάν τις τὸν λόγον μου τηρήσῃ

greek_apodoses.q1: οὐ μὴ γεύσηται θανάτου εἰς τὸν αἰῶνα

english:
p: (if [as you imply] I glorify myself)
q: (my glory is nothing)
notes: In v.50 Jesus had said, "I do not seek my own glory," so this conditional represents the presumed belief of the Jews whom Jesus is speaking with; Jesus himself "echoes" this belief in order to refute it.

greek_protases.p1: Ἐὰν ἐγὼ δοξάσω ἐμαυτόν

english:
p: (if I were to say that I do not know him)
q: (I would be a liar like you)
notes:
Greek: καν 'even if'
Jesus continues his arguement and declaration of who he is by asserting his own truthfulness. Here we have a class 3 conditional that is very unlikely. ESV expresses this unlikeliness by using a past subjunctive "iI I were to say...",, NRSV by using "if I would say...", and NIV and NLT by using a simple past "If I said...".

greek_protases.p1: κἂν εἴπω ὅτι οὐκ οἶδα αὐτόν

english:
p: (if anyone should confess Jesus to be Christ)
q: (he was to be put out of the synagogue)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB: "if anyone..."
NRSV, NIV, NLT: "anyone who..."
notes: Greek: ἐάν τις 'if anyone'

greek_protases.p1: ἐάν τις αὐτὸν ὁμολογήσῃ χριστόν

english:
p: (if anyone is a worshiper of God and does his will)
q: (God listens to him)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB: "if anyone..."
NRSV: "the one who..."
NIV, NLT: untranslated/paraphrased as a non-conditional
notes: Greek: ἐάν τις 'if anyone'

greek_protases.p1: ἐάν τις θεοσεβὴς ᾖ καὶ τὸ θέλημα αὐτοῦ ποιῇ

english:
p: (if this man were not from God)
q: (he could do nothing)
notes:
The man continues his arguement by stating what is not true (therefore the opposite must be true), but it was nevertheless the view held by his audience, which he was refuting. 
If possible, the negative conditional should be kept. If an affirmative wording is more natural, it could be expressed using a 'because' clause: "This man was/is able to do this thing only because he is from God."

greek_protases.p1: εἰ μὴ ἦν οὗτος παρὰ θεοῦ

english:
p: (if you were blind)
q: (you would have no guilt)
notes: Jesus uses figurative language here to rebuke the Pharisees for not believing in him. They are not blind physically, and Jesus, using a non-factual, acknowledges that they are not even totally blind spiritually. They would be less guilty if they were entirely spiritually blind to who Jesus is.

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ τυφλοὶ ἦτε

english:
p: (if anyone enters by me)
q: (he will be saved and will go in and out and find pasture)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB: "if anyone..."
NRSV, NIV: "whoever"
NLT: "those who..."
notes: Greek: ἐάν τις 'if anyone'

greek_protases.p1: δι ἐμοῦ ἐάν τις εἰσέλθῃ

greek_apodoses.q1: σωθήσεται καὶ εἰσελεύσεται καὶ ἐξελεύσεται καὶ νομὴν εὑρήσει

english:
p: (if you are the Christ)
q: (tell us plainly)
notes: Beasley-Murray and Trail agree that the intent of the speakers is likely hostile, not a genuine request for information. Therefore, they seem to not be implying a particular probability. They are probably echoining what they have heard people claim about Jesus, or what they assumed Jesus was intending to claim. It is evidently not something that they believe, since they try to stone him (v.31).

greek_protases.p1: εἰ σὺ εἶ ὁ χριστός

english:
p: (if he called them 'gods' to whom the word of God came...)
q: (do you say of him whom the Father consecrated and sent into the world, 'You are blaspheming' because I said 'I am the Son of God'?)
notes: Jesus has just quoted Psa 82:6 that forms the basis for his claim in the protasis. This verse, along with the next few forms a rebuke from Jesus to the Jewish leaders who have failed as leaders of Israel. Psalm 82 was originally a rebuke of judges of Israel, according to Klink.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ἐκείνους εἶπεν θεοὺς πρὸς οὓς ὁ λόγος τοῦ θεοῦ ἐγένετο καὶ οὐ δύναται λυθῆναι ἡ γραφή

greek_apodoses.q1: ὃν ὁ πατὴρ ἡγίασεν καὶ ἀπέστειλεν εἰς τὸν κόσμον ὑμεῖς λέγετε ὅτι Βλασφημεῖς ὅτι εἶπον Υἱὸς τοῦ θεοῦ εἰμι

english:
p: (if I am not doing the works of my Father)
q: (then do not believe me)
notes:
Jesus presents a conditional that he does not believe to be true, but which he attributes to his hearers. Only in the (false) case where Jesus does not do his Father's work should his audience not believe him. In actual fact, Jesus is doing "good works from the Father' (v.31), but the the Jewish leaders still do not believe him.
The negative conditional should be kept, as the following verse provides the affirmative counterpart of p.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ οὐ ποιῶ τὰ ἔργα τοῦ πατρός μου

english:
p: (if I do them)
q: (even though you do not believe me, believe the works)
notes: This conditional is embedded within the conditional in 38b. See note there for further discussion, as the conditional there forms q of this one.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ ποιῶ

greek_apodoses.q1: κἂν ἐμοὶ μὴ πιστεύητε τοῖς ἔργοις πιστεύετε

english:
p: (even though you do not believe me)
q: (believe the works)
english_translations:
ESV, NRSV, NIV: "even though"
NASB: "though"
NLT: "even if"
notes:
Greek: καν; this is a "concessive conditional".
This conditional should be interpreted as factual (or at least highly likely), as Jesus is aware of his listeners hostility and disbelief which becomes even more evident to readers in the following verse. Because of this, most of the English translations translate as a factual concessive with 'though' rather than 'if'.

greek_protases.p1: κἂν ἐμοὶ μὴ πιστεύητε

english:
p: (if anyone walks in the day)
q: (he does not stumble because he sees the light of this world)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB: "if anyone"
NRSV: "those who"
NIV: "anyone who"
NLT: non-conditional statement
notes:
Greek: ἐάν τις 'if anyone'
This condtion and the one in v.10 together have a literal meaning and a figurative one. Because it is gnomic (a timeless truth) some English translations have made this non-conditional.

greek_protases.p1: ἐάν τις περιπατῇ ἐν τῇ ἡμέρᾳ

greek_apodoses.q1: οὐ προσκόπτει ὅτι τὸ φῶς τοῦ κόσμου τούτου βλέπει

english:
p: (if anyone walks in the night)
q: (he stumbles because the light is not in him)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB: "if anyone"
NRSV, NIV, NLT: untranslated/paraphrased as a non-conditional
notes: Greek: ἐάν τις; see note at v.9.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν δέ τις περιπατῇ ἐν τῇ νυκτί

greek_apodoses.q1: προσκόπτει ὅτι τὸ φῶς οὐκ ἔστιν ἐν αὐτῷ

english:
p: (if he has fallen asleep)
q: (he will recover)
notes: The disciples misunderstood Jesus by taking his statement as literally true when he was actually speaking figuratively.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ κεκοίμηται

english:
p: (if you had been here)
q: (my brother would not have died)
notes: Young says this is a rebuke softened with a conditonal. On the other hand, Beasley-Murray sees this statement as a lament. Trail simply says that this expresses her disapointment and regret that Jesus had not arrived sooner.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ἦς ὧδε οὐκ

greek_apodoses.q1: οὐκ ἂν ἀπέθανεν ὁ ἀδελφός μου

english:
q: (he who believes in me shall live)
p: (even if he dies)
english_translations:
ESV, NRSV, NIV: "(even) though"
NASB: "even if"
NLT: "even after"
notes: Greek: κἂν; this is a "concessive conditional". The probability of death does not really seem to be in focus, though logic would say that it is likely (and that Jesus understands it to be).

greek_protases.p1: κἂν ἀποθάνῃ

greek_apodoses.q1: ὁ πιστεύων εἰς ἐμὲ κἂν ἀποθάνῃ ζήσεται

english:
p: (if you had been here)
q: (my brother would not have died)
notes: This conditional is identical to that in v.21, however Jesus' reaction to Martha (v.21) and Mary (v.32) is quite different.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ἦς ὧδε

greek_apodoses.q1: οὐκ ἄν μου ἀπέθανεν ὁ ἀδελφός

english:
NASB
p: (if you believe)
q: (you will see the glory of God)
notes: Trail notes that this verse is a "gentle reprimand" and a "challenge to her faith." Jesus is reporting what he had said earlier (so ESV and NRSV have "if you believed") and does not seem to be stating whether Martha did or not believe.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν πιστεύσῃς

english:
p: (if we let him go on like this)
q: (everyone will believe in him and the Romans will come and take away both our place and our nation)
notes: The Sanhedrin are implying that they should not allow Jesus to continue performing miracles.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν ἀφῶμεν αὐτὸν οὕτως

greek_apodoses.q1: πάντες πιστεύσουσιν εἰς αὐτόν καὶ ἐλεύσονται οἱ Ῥωμαῖοι καὶ ἀροῦσιν ἡμῶν καὶ τὸν τόπον καὶ τὸ ἔθνος

english:
p: (if anyone knew where he was)
q: (he should let them know)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB: "if anyone"
NRSV, NIV, NLT: "anyone (who)"
notes:
Greek: ἐάν τις 'if anyone'
This is one of the few conditionals in reported speech.

greek_protases.p1: ἐάν τις γνῷ ποῦ ἐστιν

english:
p: (unless a grain of wheat falls into the earth and dies)
q: (it remains alone)
notes:
In the context of the parable, Jesus is not implying a likelihood or unlikelihood of a seed dying. However, Jesus knew that he (as the one the parable is pointing to figuratively) would in fact die and bring others to life.
The negative conditional shouldbe kept; the following sentence provides the affirmative counterpart of p.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν μὴ ὁ κόκκος τοῦ σίτου πεσὼν εἰς τὴν γῆν ἀποθάνῃ

english:
p: (if it dies)
q: (it bears much fruit)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: untranslated/paraphrased as a non-conditional
notes: See note at v.24a.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν δὲ ἀποθάνῃ

english:
p: (if anyone serves me)
q: (he must follow me)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB: "if anyone"
NRSV, NIV: "whoever"
NLT: "anyone who"
notes:
Greek: ἐάν τις 'if anyone'
The first conditional in v.26 expresses a command, and the second conditional expresses the corresponding promise.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν ἐμοί τις διακονῇ

english:
p: (if anyone serves me)
q: (the Father will honor him)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB: "if anyone'"
NRSV: "whoever"
NIV: "the one who"
NLT: "anyone who"
notes:
Greek: ἐάν τις 'if anyone'
See note at v.26a

greek_protases.p1: ἐάν τις ἐμοὶ διακονῇ

english:
p: (and I, when I am lifted up from the earth)
q: (will draw all people to myself)
notes: Languages with an "if/when" category could use this here. Trail notes that the meaning of εαν approaches "when/whenever" here and is used to declare "what is expected to occur." Jesus is sure this event will occur, even though it is still in the future; it is his prediction of his death on the cross (Carlton). (See Klink for the alternative view.)

greek_protases.p1: κἀγὼ ἐὰν ὑψωθῶ ἐκ τῆς γῆς

english:
p: (if anyone hears my words and does not keep them)
q: (I do not judge him)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NIV: "if anyone"
NRSV: "anyone who"
NLT: untranslated/paraphrased as a non-conditional
notes:
Greek: ἐάν τις 'if anyone'
Jesus knows that many of those who heard him would not obey him, but the likelihood of this is not in focus.

greek_protases.p1: ἐάν τίς μου ἀκούσῃ τῶν ῥημάτων καὶ μὴ φυλάξῃ

english:
p: (if I do not wash you)
q: (you have no share with me)
notes: Tthe negative conditional should be kept if possible because Jesus' words "If I do not wash you" echo Peter's words "You will never wash my feet!"

greek_protases.p1: Ἐὰν μὴ νίψω σε

english:
p: (if I then, your Lord and Teacher have washed your feet)
q: (you also ought to wash one another's feet)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV: "if"
NIV: "now that"
NLT: "since"
notes: Klink refers to this conditional as an "argument", but according to Young it is primarily an exhortation. We follow Young here.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ οὖν ἐγὼ ἔνιψα ὑμῶν τοὺς πόδας ὁ κύριος καὶ ὁ διδάσκαλος

greek_apodoses.q1: καὶ ὑμεῖς ὀφείλετε ἀλλήλων νίπτειν τοὺς πόδας

english:
p: (if you know these things)
q: (blessed are you if you do them)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV: "if"
NIV, NLT: "now that"
notes: Boyer analyzes this conditional as sharing a single apodosis with 17b, however we consider it as containing the 17b conditional embedded within this one. As Boyer himself notes, the first conditional (17a) describes something that is already true (knowing), while the second (17b) is not yet known (doing). While v.17 does pronounce a blessing, it is a condtional blessing. See note at 17b for further discussion.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ταῦτα οἴδατε

english:
q: (blessed are you)
p: (if you do them)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: untranslated/paraphrased as a non-conditional
notes: This conditonal is embedded in 17a; see note there. The conditonal here ("if you do them") makes the blessing in 17a conditional on doing as well as on knowing. This is not a factual condition as in v.17a, but Jesus does expect his disciples to follow his example.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν ποιῆτε αὐτά

english:
p: (if God is glorified in him)
q: (God will also glorify him in himself, and glorify him at once)
notes: The time reference changes from aorist (past, completed) in p (and preceding context) to future in q. Trail suggests that the use of the aorist indicates that Jesus was so sure of his death and resurrection that he speaks about them as if they were already completed.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ὁ θεὸς ἐδοξάσθη ἐν αὐτῷ

greek_apodoses.q1: καὶ ὁ θεὸς δοξάσει αὐτὸν ἐν αὑτῷ

english:
q: (by this all people will know you are my disciples)
p: (if you have love for one another)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: non-conditional staement
notes: The "this" (Greek τούτῳ ) in q refers forward to the whole of p. This may be unnatural in some languages, and it may be better to put p before q. NLT does this, and also removes the conditional: "Your love for one another will prove to the world that you are my disciples.”

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν ἀγάπην ἔχητε ἐν ἀλλήλοις

greek_apodoses.q1: γνώσονται πάντες ὅτι ἐμοὶ μαθηταί ἐστε

english:
ESV:
p: (If it were not so)
q: (would I have told you that I go and prepare a place for you?)

NASB:
p: (if it were not so)
q: (I would have told you) for/because I go to prepare a place for you
notes:
Greek: εἰ δὲ μή with an elided (understood) verb is often translated simply as "if not" or "otherwise". This phrase presents the alternative to "In my Father's house are many rooms" in the previous clause. The effect of this conditional is to assure the disciples that Jesus will, indeed, "prepare a place" for them. 
The majority of translations (ESV, NRSV, NIV, NLT) treat q as a rhetorical question referring to indirect speech; others (NASB, NET) have only "I would have told you" in q, and treat "I go to prepare a place for you" as a separate statement.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ μή

greek_apodoses.q1: εἶπον ἂν ὑμῖν ὅτι πορεύομαι ἑτοιμάσαι τόπον ὑμῖν

english:
p: (if I go and prepare a place for you)
q: (I will come again and take you to myself, that where I am you may be also)
notes: Although the Greek has a class 3 conditional, this is clearly factual; the force of this conditional sentence is a promise rather than an argument.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν πορευθῶ καὶ ἑτοιμάσω τόπον ὑμῖν

greek_apodoses.q1: πάλιν ἔρχομαι καὶ παραλήμψομαι ὑμᾶς πρὸς ἐμαυτόν

english:
Our own translation:
p: (if you have known me)
q: (you know my Father also)
notes: We have chosen to analyze this as a factual conditional, based on the UBS Greek text with a class 1 conditional. Some manuscripts have a pluperfect verb in both p and q (and an αν in q), which is evidently the interpreatation most of the English translations take. However, the UBS Greek has a perfect verb in p and a future verb in q (with the variants listed in the footnotes); the interpretation in the NIV is based on this. The alternative class 2 interpreation seems to imply that the disciples haven't really known Jesus, but now do. There is merit in both interpretations, and Jesus' point either way is that he and the Father are one; knowledge of him is the same thing as knowledge of the Father, so the disciples do indeed know the Father.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ἐγνώκειτέ με

english:
NET:
p: (if you do not believe me)
q: (believe because of the miraculous deeds themselves)
english_translations:
ESV: "or else"
NASB: "otherwise"
NRSV: "but if...not"
NIV, NLT: "or at least"
notes: εἰ δὲ μή with an elided (understood) verb "if not" or "otherwise".

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ μή

english:
p: (if you ask me anything in my name)
q: (I will do it)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV: "if"
NIV, NLT: implied conditional
notes: This conditional is used to restate and reinforce the promise made in v.13, hence NLT: "Yes, ask me for anything in my name, and I will do it!"

greek_protases.p1: ἐάν τι αἰτήσητέ με ἐν τῷ ὀνόματί μου

english:
p: (if you love me)
q: (you will keep my commandments)
notes: The 'you' here is plural.

greek_protases.p1: Ἐὰν ἀγαπᾶτέ με

english:
p: (if anyone loves me)
q: (he will keep my word, and my Father will love him, and we will come to him and make our home with him)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB: "if anyone"
NRSV: "those who"
NIV: "anyone who"
NLT: "all who"
notes:
Greek: ἐάν τις 'if anyone'
In v.15 Jesus was addressing his disciples, but here he is talking about "the world" (v.22).

greek_protases.p1: Ἐάν τις ἀγαπᾷ με

greek_apodoses.q1: τὸν λόγον μου τηρήσει καὶ ὁ πατήρ μου ἀγαπήσει αὐτόν καὶ πρὸς αὐτὸν ἐλευσόμεθα καὶ μονὴν παρ αὐτῷ ποιησόμεθα

english:
p: (if you loved me)
q: (you would have rejoiced [that] I am going to the Father, for the Father is greater than I)
notes: Jesus indicates here that the disciples ought to view his departure positively (Klink). Trail notes that due to this being a contrary-to-fact condition, Jesus shows that "their love is not genuine love." However, Boyer reads the durative imperfect verbal aspect in the verse as indicating Jesus was referring to the instance of time when he had told them, "I am going away, but I will come back again to you." The disciples did not have genuine love at that time, but this does not mean they never exhibited genuine love. Jesus' ulitmate purpose in telling them this is so that they can indeed have true love and rejoice at his ascension.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ἠγαπᾶτέ με

greek_apodoses.q1: ἐχάρητε ἄν ὅτι πορεύομαι πρὸς τὸν πατέρα ὅτι ὁ πατὴρ μείζων μού ἐστιν

english:
q: (as the branch cannot bear fruit by itself)
p: (unless it abides in the vine)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV: "unless"
NIV: non-conditional statement
NLT: "if it is severed..." (antonymical verb)
notes:
15:4a and b are one sentence, used together to argue the necessity that the disciples "remain" in Christ: v.4a describes the relation between a vine and its fruit, and v.4b applies this to Jesus and his disciples.
Paraphrase (to avoid multiple negatives in languages without 'unless'): "A branch can only bear fruit if it remains in the vine. In the same way, you can only bear fruit if you remain in me." (Translators should also consider the words to use for 'branch' and 'vine', and whether "remain in me" is a metaphor that communicates clearly and naturally.)
NLT uses an affirmative conditional with a verb that means the opposite of 'remain': "a branch cannot produce fruit if it is severed [cut off] from the vine."
Digo translation: "Hold tightly* to me, and I will hold tightly to you. For a branch cannot bear fruit alone, until it holds tightly to the vine itself. So it is with you also, you cannot bear fruits until you hold tightly to me." (* 'Hold tightly' is a translation of "gbwirana", the reciprocal form of the verb 'hold'; it can also mean 'be attached to'.)

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν μὴ μένῃ ἐν τῇ ἀμπέλῳ

greek_apodoses.q1: καθὼς τὸ κλῆμα οὐ δύναται καρπὸν φέρειν ἀφ ἑαυτοῦ

english:
q: (neither can you)
p: (unless you abide in me)
notes: See note at 15:4a. (See note at 15:6 for discussion of the implied conditional in 15:5.)

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν μὴ ἐν ἐμοὶ μένητε

english:
p: (if anyone does not abide in me)
q: (he is thrown away like a branch and withers)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB: "if anyone does not"
NIV: "if you do not"
NRSV: "whoever does not"
NLT: "anyone who does not"
notes:
Greek: ἐὰν μή τις 'unless someone'
This verse provides the negative counterpart to v.5, which in Greek is "the one remaining in me and I in him, this one bears much fruit." This is an implied conditional. Because Jesus is addressing his disciples directly, NIV has expressed v.5 as a conditional with "you": “If you remain in me and I in you, you will bear much fruit." NIV continues to use "you" in v.6 "If you do not remain in me, you are like a branch that is thrown away and withers..."

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν μή τις μένῃ ἐν ἐμοί

greek_apodoses.q1: ἐβλήθη ἔξω ὡς τὸ κλῆμα καὶ ἐξηράνθη

english:
p: (if you abide in me and my words abide in you)
q: (ask whatever you wish and it will be done for you)
notes: Jesus repeats the promise given in 14:14 in q (so q has an implied condition); p presents an additional condition.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν μείνητε ἐν ἐμοὶ καὶ τὰ ῥήματά μου ἐν ὑμῖν μείνῃ

greek_apodoses.q1: ὃ ἐὰν θέλητε αἰτήσασθε καὶ γενήσεται ὑμῖν

english:
p: (if you keep my commandments)
q: (you will abide in my love)
notes: Klink notes that "obedience springs from love and is the response to love, not the reverse." He emphasizes that in the context of the passage, it is clear that it is humans who respond to God, not God responding to the actions of humans. This makes Jesus' statment less of a promise (as it may sound) and more of an assertion that the disciples' obedience is an indicator of their love for God.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν τὰς ἐντολάς μου τηρήσητε

english:
q: (you are my friends)
p: (if you do what I command you)
notes: In light of the following vereses where Jesus elaborates on calling his disciples friends, it becomes clear that as in v.10, this condition does not indicate temporal order (as if the disciples only become Jesus' friends after they show obedience). Rather, Jesus is saying that their obedience is proof that they are truly his friends.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν ποιῆτε ἃ ἐγὼ ἐντέλλομαι ὑμῖν

english:
p: (if the world hates you)
q: (know that it has hated me before it hated you)
notes: In 15:19b, Jesus states, "I chose you out of the world, so the world hates you." From this, it is clear that p expreses a fact rather than just a possibility.

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ ὁ κόσμος ὑμᾶς μισεῖ

greek_apodoses.q1: γινώσκετε ὅτι ἐμὲ πρῶτον ὑμῶν μεμίσηκεν

english:
p: (if you were of the world)
q: (the world would love you as its own)
notes: Jesus uses a non-factual condtional to express the negative counterpart of v.19b.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ἐκ τοῦ κόσμου ἦτε

greek_apodoses.q1: ὁ κόσμος ἂν τὸ ἴδιον ἐφίλει

english:
p: (if they persecuted me)
q: (they will also persecute you)
notes: In Jhn 15:18-19, Jesus has warned his disciples that the world will hate them, just as the world has hated him. He uses a conditional in v.20b to emphasize that the way others have treated him (which is known) indicates the way that others will treat the disciples (which the disciples have not yet experienced).

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ἐμὲ ἐδίωξαν

english: p: (if they kept my word) q: (they will also keep yours)
notes:
One interpretation of this conditional is that it refers to a different group of people than in v.20b (or to a sub-group of people within the general group referred to as “the world”). Carson (1991) explains: ‘If they persecuted me (and many of them did), they will persecute you also; if they obeyed my teaching (and some of them did), they will obey yours also.’ If this interpretation is followed, one possible way to translate v.20b-c is: "Those who persecuted me will also persecute you(pl), and/but those who kept my word will also keep yours(pl)."
An alternative interpretation, noted by Carson (1991) and Beasley-Murray (1999), treats the conditional in v.20c as non-factual and therefore complementary to rather than in contrast with v.20b. This interpretation accords with the overall theme of Jhn 15:18-25, which is that the people of the world hate Jesus and will therefore also hate the disciples, and is followed in the NLT: "Since they persecuted me, naturally they will persecute you. And if they had listened to me, they would listen to you."

greek_protases.p1: εἰ τὸν λόγον μου ἐτήρησαν

english:
p: (if I had not come and spoken to them)
q: (they would not have been guilty of sin)
notes: Both p and q are negative; Jesus is in effect saying "Because I came and spoke to them, they are guilty of sin."

greek_protases.p1: εἰ μὴ ἦλθον καὶ ἐλάλησα αὐτοῖς

english:
p: (if I had not done among them the works that no one else did)
q: (they would not be guilty of sin)
notes: Both p and q are negative; Jesus is in effect saying "Because I did among them the works (miracles) that no one else did, they are guilty of sin."

greek_protases.p1: εἰ τὰ ἔργα μὴ ἐποίησα ἐν αὐτοῖς ἃ οὐδεὶς ἄλλος ἐποίησεν

english:
p: (if I do not go away)
q: (the Helper will not come to you)
notes:
There are two conditional constructions in this verse: a negative one, and then an affirmative counterpart. Because of this, the first conditional should be kept as negative if possible. If it is not possible, it can be made affirmative and the second conditional abbreviated: "only if I go away will the Helper (Advocate) come to you; yes, I will send him to you."
Although Jesus presents two alternative scenarios (the first of which he knows is false and the second he knows is true), they have the same form in Greek, and are presented as hypothetical alternatives.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν γὰρ μὴ ἀπέλθω

greek_apodoses.q1: ὁ παράκλητος οὐ μὴ ἔλθῃ πρὸς ὑμᾶς

english:
p: (if I go)
q: (I will send him to you)
notes: See note at 16:7a.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν δὲ πορευθῶ

english:
p: (if you seek me)
q: (let these men go)
notes: It has been established in the context that they are indeed seeking Jesus; the condtional here does not express doubt. See NLT: "since I am the one you want, let these others go."

greek_protases.p1: εἰ οὖν ἐμὲ ζητεῖτε

english:
p: (if what I said is wrong)
q: (bear witness about the wrong)
notes: Jesus is not admitting that he said something wrong; he is expressing what the Temple guard believed.

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ κακῶς ἐλάλησα

english:
p: (if what I said is right)
q: (why do you strike me?)
notes: Jesus knows tnat what he said was right, but this is presented as an alternative to 18:23a.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ καλῶς

english:
p: (if this man were not a criminal)
q: (we would not have handed him over to you)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV, NLT: "if"
(NLT inverts p and q)
notes:
It is important to note that this conditional is non-factual in the opinion of the speakers, though historically it is true that Jesus was not a criminal. (ESV has the verbal "doing evil" rather than the nominal "a criminal".)
Both p and q are negative; if it is difficult to keep two negatives in your translation, this can be expressed as "We have handed him over to you because he is a criminal." It should be clear that the Jewish leaders are not giving a direct answer to Pilate's question in v.29.

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ μὴ ἦν οὗτος κακὸν ποιῶν

english:
p: (if my kingdom were of this world)
q: (my servants would have been fighting, that I might not be delivered over to the Jews)
notes: Jesus has just stated, "My kingdom is not of this world," so NIV and NLT reduce p to "If it were".

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ἐκ τοῦ κόσμου τούτου ἦν ἡ βασιλεία ἡ ἐμή

greek_apodoses.q1: οἱ ὑπηρέται οἱ ἐμοὶ ἠγωνίζοντο ἄν ἵνα μὴ παραδοθῶ τοῖς Ἰουδαίοις

english:
q: (you would have no authority over me at all)
p: (unless it had been given you from above)
notes:
Paraphrase (to avoid multiple negatives in languages without 'unless' or 'except'): "You only have authority over me because* it has been given to you from above."
*Jesus is responding to Pilate's question in v.10 "Do you not know that I have authority to release you, and I have authority to crucify you?" It is a fact that Pilate has authority over Jesus, and for this reason it may be better to use "because" rather than a conditional.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ μὴ ἦν δεδομένον σοι ἄνωθεν

greek_apodoses.q1: Οὐκ εἶχες ἐξουσίαν κατ ἐμοῦ οὐδεμίαν

english:
p: (if you release this man)
q: (you are not Caesar's friend)

greek_protases.p1: Ἐὰν τοῦτον ἀπολύσῃς

english:
p: (if you have carried him away)
q: (tell me where you have laid him, and I will take him away)

greek_protases.p1: εἰ σὺ ἐβάστασας αὐτόν

greek_apodoses.q1: εἰπέ μοι ποῦ ἔθηκας αὐτόν κἀγὼ αὐτὸν ἀρῶ

english:
p: (If you forgive the sins of any)
q: (they are forgiven them)
notes: There are two conditional sentences here, presenting alternative scenarios. The form of the conditional is unusual; ἄν τινων is a construction meaing 'if someone' or 'whoever'.

greek_protases.p1: ἄν τινων ἀφῆτε τὰς ἁμαρτίας

english: p: (if you withold forgiveness from any) q: (it is withheld)
notes: There are two conditional sentences here, presenting alternative scenarios. The form of the conditional is unusual; ἄν τινων is a construction meaing 'if someone' or 'whoever'.

greek_protases.p1: ἄν τινων κρατῆτε

english:
p: (unless I see in his hands the mark of the nails, and place my finger into the mark of the nails, and place my hand into his side)
q: (I will never believe)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV, NLT: "unless"
(NLT inverted)
notes:
Very Likely is the probability of the negative condition; Thomas expected that it was " Very Likely" he would not see the nail marks or place his hand in Jesus' side.
Paraphrase (to avoid multiple negatives in languages without 'unless'): “Only if I see in his hands the wound of the nails, and put my finger into the wound of the nails, and put my hand into his side, will I believe.” Or: "I will believe only if I see in his hands the wound of the nails, and put my finger into the wound of the nails, and put my hand into his side."

greek_protases.p1: Ἐὰν μὴ ἴδω ἐν ταῖς χερσὶν αὐτοῦ τὸν τύπον τῶν ἥλων καὶ βάλω τὸν δάκτυλόν μου εἰς τὸν τύπον τῶν ἥλων καὶ βάλω μου τὴν χεῖρα εἰς τὴν πλευρὰν αὐτοῦ

english:
p: (if it is my will that he remain until I come)
q: (what is that to you?)
notes: Jesus is not intending to imply any likelihood in this conditonal, which is made clear by John's explanation in v.23.

greek_protases.p1: Ἐὰν αὐτὸν θέλω μένειν ἕως ἔρχομαι

english:
p: (if it is my will that he remain until I come)
q: (what is that to you?)
notes: Identical to v.22.

greek_protases.p1: Ἐὰν αὐτὸν θέλω μένειν ἕως ἔρχομαι

english:
NASB
p: (if they were written in detail)
q: (I suppose that even the world itself would not contain the books that would be written)
english_translations:
ESV: "were [they] to be written"
NASB, NRSV, NIV, NLT: "if"
notes: It is clear from the conclusion drawn in q that John does not expect this conditional could possibly be fullfilled. His point is to emphasize how many great things Jesus did.

greek_protases.p1: ἅτινα ἐὰν γράφηται καθ ἕν

greek_apodoses.q1: οὐδ αὐτὸν οἶμαι τὸν κόσμον χωρήσειν τὰ γραφόμενα βιβλία

english:
p: (if we are being examined today concerning a good deed done to a crippled man, by what means this man has been healed)
q: (let it be known to all of you and to all the people of Israel that by the name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth... this man is standing before you well.)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: untranslated/paraphrased as a non-conditional in the form of a direct question marker
notes: This is an example of a speech act conditional; q is true regardless of whether p is true - p simply states why it is relevant to know q. The NLT uses a rhetorical question to accomplish the same function.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ἡμεῖς σήμερον ἀνακρινόμεθα ἐπὶ εὐεργεσίᾳ ἀνθρώπου ἀσθενοῦς

greek_apodoses.q1: γνωστὸν ἔστω πᾶσιν ὑμῖν καὶ παντὶ τῷ λαῷ Ἰσραὴλ ὅτι ἐν τῷ ὀνόματι Ἰησοῦ Χριστοῦ τοῦ Ναζωραίου ὃν ὑμεῖς ἐσταυρώσατε ὃν ὁ θεὸς ἤγειρεν ἐκ νεκρῶν ἐν τούτῳ οὗτος παρέστηκεν ἐνώπιον ὑμῶν ὑγιής

english:
p: (Whether it is right in the sight of God to listen to you rather than to God)
q: (you must judge)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV: "whether"
NIV, NLT: translated as a direct question
notes: When there is a choice within p, English often expresses this using 'whether' rather than 'if'.

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ δίκαιόν ἐστιν ἐνώπιον τοῦ θεοῦ ὑμῶν ἀκούειν μᾶλλον ἢ τοῦ θεοῦ

english:
p: (if this plan or this undertaking is of man)
q: (it will fail)
notes: Gamaliel uses the conditionals in v.38b and v.39a to present the two possible situations: either the apostles are acting on their own authority, or they are acting with God's authority. These possible situations have two corresponding outcomes: either their activities will come to nothing, or they will succeed, and the Sanhedrin will not be able to stop them.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν ᾖ ἐξ ἀνθρώπων ἡ βουλὴ αὕτη ἢ τὸ ἔργον τοῦτο

english:
p: (but if it is of God)
q: (you will not be able to overthrow them)
notes: See note at v38. Even though this conditional is class 1 (which typically expresses factual conditions) this seems to be simply presenting the alternative to teh conditional in v.38b.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ ἐκ θεοῦ ἐστιν

english:
q: (how can I [understand what I am reading])
p: (unless someone guides me)
notes:
Greek: ἐάν μή...αν + a verb in the optative
Elliot suggests that the optative could be used to "expres a request in deferential style," which fits this context well.  
Translation considerations:
If q remains as a question, p should remain as a negative conditional: "How can I (understand) if someone does not guide/teach me?" Or: "How can I (understand) unless someone guides/teaches me?" Or: "How can I understand if no one guides/teaches me?"
Paraphrase (to avoid multiple negatives in languages without 'unless':
1) express p as a statement: "There is no one to guide/teach me, so how can I understand?" or "How can I understand without someone to teach me?"
2) express q as a statement: "I can only understand if someone guides/me (but there is no one)."
3) express p and q as statements: "There is no one to guide/teach me, so I can not understand." or "I can not understand because there is no one to guide/teach me."

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν μή τις ὁδηγήσει με

english:
p: (if he found any belonging to the Way, men or women)
q: (he might bring them bound to Jerusalem)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: untranslated/paraphrased as a non-conditional in the form of indirect speech
notes: The conditinoal occurs in indirect speech. If this is not natural or clear, it could be rephrased without a conditional as the NLT does.

greek_protases.p1: ὅπως ἐάν τινας εὕρῃ τῆς ὁδοῦ ὄντας ἄνδρας τε καὶ γυναῖκας

english:
p: (if God then gave the same gift to them as he gave to us when we believed in the Lord Jesus Christ)
q: (who was I that I could stand in God's way?)

greek_protases.p1: εἰ οὖν τὴν ἴσην δωρεὰν ἔδωκεν αὐτοῖς ὁ θεὸς ὡς καὶ ἡμῖν πιστεύσασιν ἐπὶ τὸν κύριον Ἰησοῦν Χριστόν

greek_apodoses.q1: ἐγὼ τίς ἤμην δυνατὸς κωλῦσαι τὸν θεόν

english:
p: (if you have any word of encouragement for the people)
q: (say it)
notes: This conditional is a polite invitation to Paul and his companions to speak. If conditionals are not used in this way in your language, use an appropriate form for a polite invitation or request.

greek_protases.p1: εἴ τίς ἐστιν ἐν ὑμῖν λόγος παρακλήσεως πρὸς τὸν λαόν

english:
q: (I am doing a work in your days, a work that you will not believe)
p: (even if one tells it to you)
english_translations:
ESV, NRSV, NIV, NLT: "even if"
NASB: "though"
notes: This is a "concessive conditional," occuring in a quotation of Old Testament prophecy. The concessive tone does not necessarily imply that p is unlikely. In fact, in the OT quotation, p was real as the re told about this "work" in the following verses.

greek_protases.p1: ἐάν τις ἐκδιηγῆται ὑμῖν

english:
p: (unless you are circumcised according to the custom of Moses)
q: (you cannot be saved)
notes:
Greek: ἐάν μή 'unless'
Paraphrase (to avoid multiple negatives in languages without 'unless'): "You can be saved only if you are circumcised according to the custom of Moses."
(This conditional is factual because the speakers thought that p was true, even though Paul and Barnabas disagreed.)

greek_protases.p1: Ἐὰν μὴ περιτμηθῆτε τῷ ἔθει τῷ Μωϋσέως

english:
p: (if you have judged me to be faithful to the Lord)
q: (come to my house and stay)
notes: Lydia is not doubting whether she is a true believer; rather, she is using a conditional to express a polite invitation (as in 13:15).

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ κεκρίκατέ με πιστὴν τῷ κυρίῳ εἶναι

greek_apodoses.q1: εἰσελθόντες εἰς τὸν οἶκόν μου μένετε

english:
p: (if this were a matter of wrongdoing or vicious crime)
q: (I would have reason to accept your complaint)
notes: This verse and the next (v.15) form a pair in which the speaker compares two situations, one false and the other true.

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ μὲν ἦν ἀδίκημά τι ἢ ῥᾳδιούργημα πονηρόν

english:
p: (since it is a matter of questions and words and names and your own law)
q: (see to it yourselves)
notes: See note at v.14.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ ζητήματά ἐστιν περὶ λόγου καὶ ὀνομάτων καὶ νόμου τοῦ καθ ὑμᾶς

english:
p: (if therefore Demetrius and the craftsmen with him have a complaint against anyone)
q: (the courts are open and there are proconsuls)
notes: This is a speech act conditional; q is true regardless of whether p is true - p states why it is relevant to know q.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ μὲν οὖν Δημήτριος καὶ οἱ σὺν αὐτῷ τεχνῖται ἔχουσιν πρός τινα λόγον

english:
p: (but if you seek anything further)
q: (it shall be settled in a regular assembly)
notes: Although the form of this conditional is the same as in v.38, it does not seem to be factual.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δέ τι περαιτέρω ἐπιζητεῖτε

english:
Greek:
p: (if a man [is] a Roman citizen and uncondemned)
q: (Ιs it lawful for you to flog [him]?)
english_translations: ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV, NLT: translated as a relative clause "who is..."
notes: Although none of the English translations listed translate this as a conditional, it has the form of a conditional in Greek and can be understood as having a conditional meaning. Paul knows that it is not legal for the centurion to whip a Roman citizen who has not been found guilty of a crime, so this is a rhetorical question.

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ ἄνθρωπον Ῥωμαῖον καὶ ἀκατάκριτον

english:
p: (what if a spirit or an angel spoke to him?)
q: missing
english_translations:
ESV, NRSV, NIV: "what if"
NASB: "suppose"
NLT: "perhaps"
notes: Boyer and Elliot consider this a true condition with an elipsed q. They do not comment on what the q would be. We think that if stated, it would likely be an assertion that Paul would be innocent under the condtion of p.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ πνεῦμα ἐλάλησεν αὐτῷ ἢ ἄγγελος

english:
NRSV:
q: (they ought to be here before you to make accusation)
p: (if they have anything against me)
english_translations:
ESV: "should they have" (conditional sense)
NASB, NRSV, NIV, NLT: "if"

greek_protases.p1: εἴ τι ἔχοιεν πρὸς ἐμέ

greek_apodoses.q1: τινὲς δὲ ἀπὸ τῆς Ἀσίας Ἰουδαῖοι οὓς ἔδει ἐπὶ σοῦ παρεῖναι καὶ κατηγορεῖν

english:
p: (if there is anything wrong about the man)
q: (let them bring charges against him)
notes: Although this is a class 1 conditional, which are often factual, there is evidence that Festus believes that Paul has done anything wrong.

greek_protases.p1: εἴ τί ἐστιν ἐν τῷ ἀνδρὶ ἄτοπον

english:
p: (if then I am a wrongdoer and have committed anything for which I deserve to die)
q: (I do not seek to escape death)
notes: Paul uses two conditionals in 11a and 11b to show the powo possible situations (he is either guilty or not guilty) and the consequences of these situations (either he should die or he should be released).

greek_protases.p1: εἰ μὲν οὖν ἀδικῶ καὶ ἄξιον θανάτου πέπραχά τι

english:
p: (but if there is nothing to their charges against me)
q: (no one can give me up to them)
notes: See note at v.11a.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ οὐδέν ἐστιν ὧν οὗτοι κατηγοροῦσίν μου

english:
NLT:
p: (if they would admit it)
q: (they know that I have been a member of the Pharisees, the strictest sect of our religion)
notes: Q is true regardless of p. If this is not clear using a conditional construction in your language, it can be rephrased as a statement: "They know that I have been a member of the Pharisees, the strictest sect of our religion, but they are not willing to admit it."

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν θέλωσι μαρτυρεῖν ὅτι κατὰ τὴν ἀκριβεστάτην αἵρεσιν τῆς ἡμετέρας θρησκείας ἔζησα Φαρισαῖος

english:
NASB: 
q: (why is it considered incredible among you)
p: (if God does raise the dead?)
notes: Many English translations do not treat this as a conditional, but instead translate ει 'if' as a complementizer 'that'. Hoowever, it can also be interpreted as introducing a factual condition: "if God raises the dead (which he does), why should any of you think that this is unbeleivable?"

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ὁ θεὸς νεκροὺς ἐγείρει

english:
q: (this man might have been set free)
p: (if he had not appealed to Caesar)

greek_protases.p1: εἰ μὴ ἐπεκέκλητο Καίσαρα

english:
p: (unless these men stay in the ship = if these men do not stay in the ship)
q: (you cannot be saved)
notes:
Greek: ἐάν μή 'unless'
Paraphrase (to avoid multiple negatives in languages without 'unless' or 'except'): "Only if these men remain in the ship can you be saved." Or: "You can be saved only if these men remain in the ship."

greek_protases.p1: Ἐὰν μὴ οὗτοι μείνωσιν ἐν τῷ πλοίῳ

english:
p: (if you call yourself a Jew and rely on the law and boast in God and know his will and approve what is excellent, because you are intructed from the law; and if you are sure that you yourself are a guide to the blind, a light to those who are in darkness, an instructor of the foolish, a teacher of children, having in the law the embodiment of truth)
q: (you then who teach others, do not teach yourself)
notes:
Paul lists the priviledges of being a Jew and then admonishes them for the way they act (Kruse). Essentially, Paul is saying, "if you know so much, why do you act in this way?"
In the greek ει is only used once at the beginning, in most English translations "if" is used more than once (e.g. ESV and NRSV in vs.17 & 19, NIV four times in vs.17-19) so the reader knows that the conditional is continuing. NLT makes vs.17-20 statements and uses "if" in the first rhetorical question in v.21.
Since p is vs.17-20, q could be considered to encompass all four rhetorical questions in the rest of vs.21 and 22.

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ δὲ σὺ Ἰουδαῖος ἐπονομάζῃ καὶ ἐπαναπαύῃ νόμῳ καὶ καυχᾶσαι ἐν θεῷ καὶ γινώσκεις τὸ θέλημα καὶ δοκιμάζεις τὰ διαφέροντα κατηχούμενος ἐκ τοῦ νόμου πέποιθάς τε σεαυτὸν ὁδηγὸν εἶναι τυφλῶν φῶς τῶν ἐν σκότει παιδευτὴν ἀφρόνων διδάσκαλον νηπίων ἔχοντα τὴν μόρφωσιν τῆς γνώσεως καὶ τῆς ἀληθείας ἐν τῷ νόμῳ

greek_apodoses.q1: ὁ οὖν διδάσκων ἕτερον σεαυτὸν οὐ διδάσκεις

english:
q: (For circumcision indeed is of value)
p: (if you obey the law)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: "only if"
notes: Circumcision was a sign that set the Jews apart from the other nations, but Paul says that it is only important if it is accompanied by obedience to the Jewish law. Paul is presenting obeying the law as possible, even though it is clear from the context that no one was completely obedient to the law.

greek_protases.p1: Περιτομὴ μὲν γὰρ ὠφελεῖ

english:
p: (but if you break the law)
q: (your circumcision becomes uncircumcision)
notes: Paul is presenting breaking the law as hypothetical, even though it is clear from the context that everyone will break the law at some point

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν δὲ παραβάτης νόμου ᾖς

english:
p: (so, if a man who is uncircumcised keeps the precepts of the law)
q: (will not his uncircumcision be regarded as circumcision?)
notes: A rhetorical question intended to be answered positively (which Paul does in verses 27-29).

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν οὖν ἡ ἀκροβυστία τὰ δικαιώματα τοῦ νόμου φυλάσσῃ

greek_apodoses.q1: οὐχ ἡ ἀκροβυστία αὐτοῦ εἰς περιτομὴν λογισθήσεται

english:
What then?
p: (If some did not believe,)
q: (their unbelief will not nullify the faithfulness of God, will it?) (NASB)
english_translations:
NASB: "if"
ESV, NRSV, NIV: "what if"
NLT: "just because"
notes:
P expresses something that is known to be true (some did not believe), and q is a rhetorical question that expects a negative answer.
The ESV, NRSV and NIV express this as two rhetorical questions:
p: (what if some were unfaithful?)
q: (does their faithfulness nullify the faithfulness of God?)

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ἠπίστησάν τινες

greek_apodoses.q1: μὴ ἡ ἀπιστία αὐτῶν τὴν πίστιν τοῦ θεοῦ καταργήσει

english:
p: (but if our unrighteousness serves to show the righteousness of God,)
q: (what shall we say? That God is unrighteous to inflict wrath on us?)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: not translated
notes: In 3:5 and 3:7 Paul is presenting the kind of argument that his opponents might use (NLT "some might say"), namely that if our sins demonstrate God's righteousness, we do not deserve to be punished for our sin. As in 3:3, q is a rhetorical question that expects a negative answer.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ ἡ ἀδικία ἡμῶν θεοῦ δικαιοσύνην συνίστησιν

greek_apodoses.q1: τί ἐροῦμεν μὴ ἄδικος ὁ θεὸς ὁ ἐπιφέρων τὴν ὀργήν

english:
p: (But if through my lie God's truth abounds to his glory)
q: (why am I still being condemned as a sinner?)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT : "some might say"
notes:
Paul is presenting the kind of argument that his opponents might use, and some translations make this explicit, e.g. NIV, NLT: "Someone might argue..."
Q expects an answer, "There is no reason why I should be condemned as a sinner."

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ ἡ ἀλήθεια τοῦ θεοῦ ἐν τῷ ἐμῷ ψεύσματι ἐπερίσσευσεν εἰς τὴν δόξαν αὐτοῦ

greek_apodoses.q1: τί ἔτι κἀγὼ ὡς ἁμαρτωλὸς κρίνομαι

english:
q: ([He is God] of the Gentiles also)
p: (since God is one)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "since"
NLT: not translated
notes:
Greek: εἴπερ 'since'
Because God created the whole of humankind the Jews cannot claim God for themselves alone (even though they hold special importance as Paul points out throughout the letter).

greek_protases.p1: ναὶ καὶ ἐθνῶν

english:
p: (for if Abraham was justified by works)
q: (he has something to boast about)
notes: Paul explains that this conditional is non-factual at the end of v3 "Abraham believed God and it was counted to him as righteousness" It was not Abraham's works which saved him or brought him righteousness, but his faith. The NIV makes this clear by adding "in fact" after "if".

greek_protases.p1: εἰ γὰρ Ἀβραὰμ ἐξ ἔργων ἐδικαιώθη

english:
p: (for if it is the adherents of the law who are to be the heirs)
q: (faith is null and the promise is void)
notes: In v.13 Paul stated, the promise to Abraham ... that he would be heir of the world did not come through the law..." From this, it is clear that p is non-factual, and so q is false: faith is not null, and the promise is not void.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ γὰρ οἱ ἐκ νόμου κληρονόμοι

greek_apodoses.q1: κεκένωται ἡ πίστις καὶ κατήργηται ἡ ἐπαγγελία

english:
p: (for if while we were enemies we were reconciled to God by the death of his Son)
q: (much more, now that we are reconciled, shall we be saved by his life)
notes: Paul uses several of these "how much more" statements (5:10, 15, 17, 11:12, 24) to try to explain how amazing God's grace is. Instead of q being dependant on p (as is usually the case in conditional sentences), p and q are compared: we were reconciled by Christ's death; we will certainly be saved by his life.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ γὰρ ἐχθροὶ ὄντες κατηλλάγημεν τῷ θεῷ διὰ τοῦ θανάτου τοῦ υἱοῦ αὐτοῦ

greek_apodoses.q1: πολλῷ μᾶλλον καταλλαγέντες σωθησόμεθα ἐν τῇ ζωῇ αὐτοῦ

english:
p: (for if many died through one man's trespass)
q: (much more have the grace of God and the free gift by the grace of that one man Jesus Christ abounded for many)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: q is introduced by "but"
notes: See 5:10

greek_protases.p1: εἰ γὰρ τῷ τοῦ ἑνὸς παραπτώματι οἱ πολλοὶ ἀπέθανον

greek_apodoses.q1: πολλῷ μᾶλλον ἡ χάρις τοῦ θεοῦ καὶ ἡ δωρεὰ ἐν χάριτι τῇ τοῦ ἑνὸς ἀνθρώπου Ἰησοῦ Χριστοῦ εἰς τοὺς πολλοὺς ἐπερίσσευσεν

english:
p: (for if, because of one man's trespass, death reigned through that one man)
q: (how much more will those who receive the abundance of grace and the free gift of righteousness reign in life through the one man Jesus Christ)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: q is introduced by "but"
notes: See 5:10

greek_protases.p1: εἰ γὰρ τῷ τοῦ ἑνὸς παραπτώματι ὁ θάνατος ἐβασίλευσεν διὰ τοῦ ἑνός

greek_apodoses.q1: πολλῷ μᾶλλον οἱ τὴν περισσείαν τῆς χάριτος καὶ τῆς δωρεᾶς τῆς δικαιοσύνης λαμβάνοντες ἐν ζωῇ βασιλεύσουσιν διὰ τοῦ ἑνὸς Ἰησοῦ Χριστοῦ

english:
p: (for if we have been united with him in a death like his)
q: (we shall certainly be united with him in a resurrection like his)
notes: See 5:10

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ γὰρ σύμφυτοι γεγόναμεν τῷ ὁμοιώματι τοῦ θανάτου αὐτοῦ

english:
p: (now if we have died with Christ)
q: (we believe that we will also live with him)
notes: This is another example of p and q being placed together for comparison (see notes on 5:10). 2Ti 2:11 is very similar.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ ἀπεθάνομεν σὺν Χριστῷ

english:
p: (but if her husband dies)
q: (she is released from the law of marriage)
notes: This conditional (and the next two in 7:3) are examples to illustrate the point Paul makes in 7:4-6 about dying to the law. Since we have died we are released from the law

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν δὲ ἀποθάνῃ ὁ ἀνήρ

greek_apodoses.q1: κατήργηται ἀπὸ τοῦ νόμου τοῦ ἀνδρός

english:
q: (she will be called an adulteress)
p: (if she lives with another man while her husband is alive)
notes: Some translations (e.g. NASB, NIV) put p before q: "So then, if she has sexual relations with another man while her husband is still alive, she is called an adulteress." (NIV)

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν γένηται ἀνδρὶ ἑτέρῳ ἐὰν δὲ ἀποθάνῃ ὁ ἀνήρ

greek_apodoses.q1: ἄρα οὖν ζῶντος τοῦ ἀνδρὸς μοιχαλὶς χρηματίσει

english:
p: (but if her husband dies)
q: (she is free from that law)
notes: In Greek, the last part of v.3 contains a participle verb form γενομένην ἀνδρὶ ἑτέρῳ 'having been joined to a different husband.' ESV, NRSV, and NIV express this as another conditional: "and if she marries another man she is not an adulteress"; NASB expresses this as "though she is joined to another man" and NLT as "when she remarries."

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν δὲ ἀποθάνῃ ὁ ἀνήρ

english:
q: (I would not have known sin)
p: (if it had not been for the law)
(Greek q p order is changed to p q in ESV)
english_translations:
ESV, NRSV: "if... not"
NASB: "except"
NIV: subject-verb inversion "had it not been"
notes: The phrase εἰ μὴ 'except' is usually treated as a "non-conditional" (see 13:1, 13:8, 14:14) but because mmany English translations have "if not" and the structure is parallel to 7:7b we have included this here.  In some languages, the combination of a negative conditional and inverted order (q before p) may be unnatural. In this case, you could rephrase as "Apart from/Without the law, I would not have known what sin was." Or: "I only knew what sin was because of the law."

greek_protases.p1: εἰ μὴ διὰ νόμου

english:
q: (for I would not have known what it is to covet)
p: (if the law had not said, "You shall not covet")
english_translations: ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV, NLT: "if... not"
notes: The phrase εἰ μὴ is translated as "if... not" rather than as "except" by most English translations. In some languages, the combination of a negative conditional and inverted order (q before p) may be unnatural. In this case, you could rephrase as "It is only because the law had said, "You must not covet" that I knew what it means to covet." Or: "I only knew what it means to covet because the law had said, 'You must not covet.'"

greek_protases.p1: εἰ μὴ ὁ νόμος ἔλεγεν Οὐκ ἐπιθυμήσεις

greek_apodoses.q1: τήν τε γὰρ ἐπιθυμίαν οὐκ ᾔδειν

english:
p: (now if I do what I do not want)
q: (I agree with the law, that it is good)
notes: The truth of p is stated in v.15: "I do not do what I want, but I do the very thing I hate." V.17 could be rephrased, "So since/because I do what I do not want, I agree that the law is good."

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ ὃ οὐ θέλω τοῦτο ποιῶ

english:
p: (now if I do what I do not want)
q: (it is no longer I who do it, but sin that dwells within me)
notes: This is a repetition - in abbreviated form - of vs.16-17.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ ὃ οὐ θέλω τοῦτο ποιῶ

greek_apodoses.q1: οὐκέτι ἐγὼ κατεργάζομαι αὐτὸ ἀλλὰ ἡ οἰκοῦσα ἐν ἐμοὶ ἁμαρτία

english:
q: (you, however, are not in the flesh but in the Spirit)
p: (if in fact/since the Spirit of God dwells in you)
english_translations:
ESV, RSV: "If in fact"
NASB, NIV: "If indeed"
NRSV: "since"
NLT: "if"
notes: The Greek connctive εἴπερ indicates a known fact, and is often translated 'since'. If the order q p is not natural in your language, this can be rephrased as "Since/Because the Spirit of God lives in you(pl), you(pl) are controlled by the Spirit, not by your sinful nature."

greek_protases.p1: εἴπερ πνεῦμα θεοῦ οἰκεῖ ἐν ὑμῖν

greek_apodoses.q1: Ὑμεῖς δὲ οὐκ ἐστὲ ἐν σαρκὶ ἀλλὰ ἐν πνεύματι

english:
p: (if anyone does not have the Spirit of Christ)
q: (he does not belong to him) (NASB)
english_translations:
ESV, NRSV: "anyone who"
NASB, NIV: "if anyone"
NLT: "those who"
notes: This describes the opposite scenario to the previous (8:9a) conditional. Whereas 8:9a was addressed to all of Paul's readers (the 'you' in Greek is plural) in 8:9b τις 'anyone' and οὗτος 'this one' are singular. This indicates that Paul is simply describing the opposite condition, rather than warning or rebuking his readers.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δέ τις πνεῦμα Χριστοῦ οὐκ ἔχει

english:
p: (but if Christ is in you)
q: (although the body is dead because of sin, the Spirit is life because of righteousness)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: statement "Christ lives within you, so..."
notes: The conditionals in 8:9a, 8:10, and 8:11 all describe the same reality and are all true.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ Χριστὸς ἐν ὑμῖν

greek_apodoses.q1: τὸ μὲν σῶμα νεκρὸν διὰ ἁμαρτίαν τὸ δὲ πνεῦμα ζωὴ διὰ δικαιοσύνην

english:
p: (if the Spirit of him who raised Jesus from the dead dwells in you)
q: (he who raised Christ Jesus from the dead will also give life to your mortal bodies through his Spirit who dwells in you)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: statement "The Spirit of God... lives in you."
notes: The conditionals in 8:9a, 8:10, and 8:11 all describe the same reality and are all true.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ τὸ πνεῦμα τοῦ ἐγείραντος τὸν Ἰησοῦν ἐκ νεκρῶν οἰκεῖ ἐν ὑμῖν

greek_apodoses.q1: ὁ ἐγείρας ἐκ νεκρῶν Χριστὸν Ἰησοῦν ζῳοποιήσει καὶ τὰ θνητὰ σώματα ὑμῶν διὰ τὸ ἐνοικοῦν αὐτοῦ πνεῦμα ἐν ὑμῖν

english:
p: (for if you live according to the flesh)
q: (you will die)
notes: Paul's purpose here is to set out the consequences of living "according to the flesh" rather than to criticize his readers ('you' is plural).

greek_protases.p1: εἰ γὰρ κατὰ σάρκα ζῆτε

english:
p: (but if by the Spirit you put to death the deeds of the body)
q: (you will live)
notes: "In Rom 8:11–12, Paul states that we are not obligated to live according to the flesh now that the Spirit has made us alive. Verse 13 contrasts the two alternatives, establishing explicit states of affairs for the main clauses that follow using conditional frames." [Runge, Steven E. 2010. Discourse Grammar of the Greek New Testament: A Practical Introduction for Teaching and Exegesis. Bellingham, WA: Lexham Press.]

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ πνεύματι τὰς πράξεις τοῦ σώματος θανατοῦτε

english:
p: (and if children)
q: (then heirs)
notes: The previous verse states the truth of p: "The Spirit himself bears witness with our spirit that we are children of God" (8:16)

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ τέκνα

english:
q: (heirs of God and fellow heirs with Christ)
p: (if indeed/provided we suffer with him in order that we may also be glorified with him)
english_translations:
ESV, RSV: "provided"
NASB, NIV: "if indeed"
NRSV: "if, in fact"
notes: The Greek connctive εἴπερ indicates a known fact, and is often translated 'since'; this seems to indicate that Paul assumes that his readers are suffering or have suffered because of their faith in Christ. If a conditional in your language does not allow this interpretation, you could rephrase as "We are not only heirs of God but co-heirs/joint heirs with Christ, because we are suffering with him so that we may also be glorified with him."

greek_protases.p1: εἴπερ συμπάσχομεν ἵνα καὶ συνδοξασθῶμεν

greek_apodoses.q1: καὶ κληρονόμοι κληρονόμοι μὲν θεοῦ συγκληρονόμοι δὲ Χριστοῦ

english:
p: (but if we hope for what we do not see)
q: (we wait for it with patience)
notes: This expresses an exhortation: If we hope for what we do not see (and we should as Christians) we wait for it with patience (and this is how we should be acting).

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ ὃ οὐ βλέπομεν ἐλπίζομεν

english:
p: (if God is for us)
q: (who can be against us?)
notes: Q is a rhetorical question that is meant to be answered 'No one!'

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ὁ θεὸς ὑπὲρ ἡμῶν

english: p: (what if God, desiring to show his wrath and to make known his power, has endured with much patience vessels of wrath prepared for destruction...)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "what if"
NLT: "even though"
notes: There is some debate as to whether this is an actual conditional or not, as it has a protasis but no apodosis. This protasis is in the form of a rhetorical question, hence most English translations express εἰ 'if' as "What if". In Greek, the question extends from v.22 through v.24, although NRSV and NIV end it at v.22, and start a new "what if" question at v.23. NASB ends the rhetorical question at v.22 and makes vs.23-24 into a statement. NLT interprets  as concessional 'even if/though': "... even though God has the right to show his anger and his power, he is very patient with those on whom his anger falls, who are destined for destruction."

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ θέλων ὁ θεὸς ἐνδείξασθαι τὴν ὀργὴν καὶ γνωρίσαι τὸ δυνατὸν αὐτοῦ

greek_apodoses.q1: ἤνεγκεν ἐν πολλῇ μακροθυμίᾳ σκεύη ὀργῆς κατηρτισμένα εἰς ἀπώλειαν

english:
p: (Though the number of the sons of Israel be as the sand of the sea)
q: (only a remanant of them will be saved)
notes: This conditional is part of a quote from Isaiah 10:22-23. Here, Ἐὰν has the force of a concessive conditional 'even if/though'.

greek_protases.p1: Ἐὰν ᾖ ὁ ἀριθμὸς τῶν υἱῶν Ἰσραὴλ ὡς ἡ ἄμμος τῆς θαλάσσης

english:
p: (if the Lord of hosts had not left us offspring)
q: (we would have been like Sodom and become like Gomorrah)
english_translations:
ESV, NRSV, NLT: "if... not"
NASB, NIV: "unless"
notes: εἰ μὴ 'unless'. This conditional is part of a quote from Isaiah 1:9; p states something that did not happen and q states the consequences of this. This conditional should not be rephrased using an affirmative form.

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ μὴ κύριος Σαβαὼθ ἐγκατέλιπεν ἡμῖν σπέρμα

greek_apodoses.q1: ὡς Σόδομα ἂν ἐγενήθημεν καὶ ὡς Γόμορρα ἂν ὡμοιώθημεν

english:
p: (if you confess with your mouth that Jesus is Lord and believe in your heart that God raised him from the dead)
q: (you will be saved)
notes: This conditional applies to any person at any time (so the time orientation is gnomic). In your translation, make sure that it does not sound as if Paul is addressing a single individual only (the verb forms in Greek are 2nd person singular). Paul expands in v.10 using 3rd person singular, which ESV translates as "one": "For with the heart one believes and is justified, and with the mouth one confesses and is saved."

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν ὁμολογήσῃς ἐν τῷ στόματί σου κύριον Ἰησοῦν καὶ πιστεύσῃς ἐν τῇ καρδίᾳ σου ὅτι ὁ θεὸς αὐτὸν ἤγειρεν ἐκ νεκρῶν

english:
q: (how are they to preach? ~ implies: they can not preach)
p: (unless they are sent = if they are not sent)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "unless"
NLT: "without being sent"
notes:
ἐάν μή 'unless'. The whole conditional is phrased as a rhetorical question that is meant to be answered negatively.
Paraphrase (to avoid multiple negatives in languages without 'unless' or 'except'): And they can preach only if they are sent.
It is best to keep the order Q>P, if possible, because this sentence forms part of a chain starting in v.14: But how are they to call on one in whom they have not BELIEVED? And how are they to BELIEVE in one of whom they have never HEARD? And how are they to HEAR without someone to PROCLAIM him? And how are they to PROCLAIM him unless they are sent? (Note that the subject changes between verses 14 and 15.)

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν μὴ ἀποσταλῶσιν

english:
p: (but if it is by grace)
q: (it is no longer on the basis of works)
notes: 11:5 makes clear that this is a present time, factual conditional: "So too at the present time there is a remnant, chosen by grace." Verse 6 continues with a clarification that includes the non-conditional conjunction ἐπεὶ 'otherwise'.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ χάριτι

english:
p: (now if their trespass means riches for the world, and if their faliure means riches for the Gentiles)
q: (how much more will their full inclusion mean)
notes: The truth of p is asserted in v.11: "through their [the Jews'] trespass salvation has come to the Gentiles.".

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ τὸ παράπτωμα αὐτῶν πλοῦτος κόσμου καὶ τὸ ἥττημα αὐτῶν πλοῦτος ἐθνῶν

english:
p v.13: (I magnify my ministry)
q v.14: (if somehow I might move to jealousy my fellow countrymen and save some of them) (NASB)
english_translations:
ESV: "in order somehow"
NASB: "if somehow"
NRSV: "in order"
NIV: "in the hope that"
NLT: "for I want somehow"
notes:
This unusual Greek construction has the conjunction ει (found in class 1 and 3 conditionals) plus the particle πως 'somehow', followed by a subjunctive verb (found in class 2 conditionals).
Q contains a "how much more" statement (see also 5:10, 15, 17, 11:24).

greek_protases.p1: εἴ πως παραζηλώσω μου τὴν σάρκα καὶ σώσω τινὰς ἐξ αὐτῶν

english:
p: (For if their rejection means reconciliation of the world)
q: (what will their acceptance mean but life from the dead)
notes:
Some commentators argue that 'their rejection' refers to God's rejection of Israel, however, in light of vs.11-12 it is more likely to mean Israel's rejection of God.
The word 'but' in "but life from the dead" is a translation of εἰ μὴ 'except'.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ γὰρ ἡ ἀποβολὴ αὐτῶν καταλλαγὴ κόσμου

greek_apodoses.q1: τίς ἡ πρόσλημψις εἰ μὴ ζωὴ ἐκ νεκρῶν

english:
p: (if the dough offered as firstfruits is holy)
q: (so is the whole lump)
notes: There are several interpretations as to what the dough is referring to. The firstfruits of the dough could refer to Abraham and the patriarchs, the remnant of Israel, or Christ. The whole lump could refer to all Israel  or all believers (Kruse). It is best to translate this using a conditional construction that can be used for universal truths, without making any particular interpretation explicit (as NLT does when it adds "since Abraham and the other patriarchs were holy, their descendants will also be holy."

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ ἡ ἀπαρχὴ ἁγία

english:
p: (and if the root is holy)
q: (so are the branches)
notes: There are several interpretations as to what the root is referring to. Suggestions include; the Patriarchs (Abraham in particular), the remnant of Israel, or Christ. The branches could refer to Israel as a whole, the Jewish elect, or all believers (Kruse). It is best to translate this using a conditional construction that can be used for universal truths, without making any particular interpretation explicit.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ἡ ῥίζα ἁγία

english:
p v.17: (but if some of the branches were broken off, and you, although a wild olive shoot were grafted in among the others and now share in the nourishing root of the olive tree)
q v.18a: (do not be arrogant toward the branches)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: statements
notes: The branches that have been broken off represent the Jews who did not believe in Jesus. The command in q (v.18a) is not to be arrogant toward those unbelieving Jews. The verb form translated "do not be arrogant" or "do not boast" is second person singular.

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ δέ τινες τῶν κλάδων ἐξεκλάσθησαν σὺ δὲ ἀγριέλαιος ὢν ἐνεκεντρίσθης ἐν αὐτοῖς καὶ συγκοινωνὸς τῆς ῥίζης τῆς πιότητος τῆς ἐλαίας ἐγένου

english:
p: (if you are arrogant)
q: ([remember that] it is not you who support the root, but the root that supports you)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: negative command "you must not brag"
notes: The Greek simply states, "but if you boast/exult, you do not carry/support the root, but the root you." The verb forms and pronouns translated 'you' here and in vs.21 & 22 are second person singular.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ κατακαυχᾶσαι

greek_apodoses.q1: οὐ σὺ τὴν ῥίζαν βαστάζεις ἀλλὰ ἡ ῥίζα σέ

english:
p: (for if God did not spare the natural branches)
q: (neither will he spare you)
notes: This verse continues the comparison between the Jews (natural branches) and the Gentiles (grafted branches). Verse 21 states. "They [the natural branches] were broken off because of their unbelief..." so we know that p is a knkown fact.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ γὰρ ὁ θεὸς τῶν κατὰ φύσιν κλάδων οὐκ ἐφείσατο

english:
q: (Behold then the kindness and severity of God; to those who fell, severity, but to you, God’s kindness)
p: (if you contine in his kindness) (NASB)
notes:
Paul is saying that God will be kind to you (singular), but only if you continue to trust in his kindness.
Verse 22 concludes with a warning that includes the non-conditional conjunction ἐπεὶ 'otherwise': "Otherwise you too will be cut off."

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν ἐπιμένῃς τῇ χρηστότητι

greek_apodoses.q1: ἴδε οὖν χρηστότητα καὶ ἀποτομίαν θεοῦ ἐπὶ μὲν τοὺς πεσόντας ἀποτομία ἐπὶ δὲ σὲ χρηστότης θεοῦ

english:
p: (and even they, if they do not continue in their unbelief)
q: (will be grafted in)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: "if they turn from" (see Notes)
notes:
ἐάν μή 'unless'. The fact that the unbelieving Jews have been cut off does not mean that they cannot be grafted back in; being cut off is not a final judgement.
P contains two negative elements: if they do NOT continue in their UNbelief. This could be rephrased as e.g. 'if they turn from their unbelief' (NLT), or 'if they start to believe' (cf. New Century: 'And if the Jews will believe in God again...'; Parole de Vie: 'Mais si un jour, les Juifs acceptent de croire...').

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν μὴ ἐπιμένωσι τῇ ἀπιστίᾳ

english:
p: (for if you were cut from what is by nature a wild olive tree, and grafted, contrary to nature, into a cultivated olive tree)
q: (how much more will these, the natural branches, be grafted back into their own olive tree)
notes: P describes a known fact; q contains another  "how much more" statement (see also 5:10, 15, 17, 11:12).

greek_protases.p1: εἰ γὰρ σὺ ἐκ τῆς κατὰ φύσιν ἐξεκόπης ἀγριελαίου καὶ παρὰ φύσιν ἐνεκεντρίσθης εἰς καλλιέλαιον
