greek_apodoses.q1: πόσῳ μᾶλλον οὗτοι οἱ κατὰ φύσιν ἐγκεντρισθήσονται τῇ ἰδίᾳ ἐλαίᾳ

english:
p: (if prophecy)
q: (in proportion to our faith);
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NIV, NLT: "if"
NRSV, not translated
notes:
The conditionals in vs.6-8 should be understood as a group. The conjunction εἴτε 'if, whether' introduces either a spiritual gift or a person having a certain spiritual gift. It occurs 4 times in vs.6-8; the final 3 types of person are introduced without εἴτε. None of these are complete clauses.
εἴτε introduces prophecy, service, he who teaches, and he who exhorts. Listed afterwards are he who gives, he who leads, and he who shows mercy. 
Each apodosis describes how to use the gift mentioned in p. The first apodosis begins with κατα but after that εν is used. None of these are complete clauses, but some translations (e.g. NIV, NLT) express these as complete clauses.

greek_protases.p1: εἴτε προφητείαν

english:
p: (if service) 
q: (in our serving)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NIV, NLT: "if"
NRSV, not translated
notes: See 12:6

greek_protases.p1: εἴτε διακονίαν

english:
p: (if it is teaching)
q: (then teach) (NIV)
english_translations:
NIV, NLT: "if"
ESV, NASB, NRSV, not translated
notes: See 12:6

greek_protases.p1: εἴτε ὁ διδάσκων

english:
p: (if it is to encourage)
q: (then give encouragement) (NIV)
english_translations:
NIV, NLT: "if"
ESV, NASB, NRSV, not translated
notes: See 12:6. The three final gifts in the list (giving, leading, showing mercy) are not introduced by εἴτε but can be translated the same way as the previous gifts if this is more natural in your language.

greek_protases.p1: εἴτε ὁ παρακαλῶν

english:
p: (if your enemy is hungry)
q: (feed him)
notes: Quotes Proverbs 25:22 but omits "and the Lord will reward you". Should be read in light of v21 "do not be overcome by evil, but overcome evil with good" and v19 "beloved, never avenge youselves, but leave it to the wrath of God". Paul is challenging his readers to act in kindness with no thought for vengeance.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν πεινᾷ ὁ ἐχθρός σου

english:
p: (if he is thirsty)
q: (give him something to drink)
notes: See notes on 12:20a

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν διψᾷ

english:
p: (but if you do wrong)
q: (be afraid)

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν δὲ τὸ κακὸν ποιῇς

english:
p: (and if there is any other commandment)
q: (it is summed up in this saying "you shall love your neighbor as yourself) (NASB)
english_translations:
NASB: "if there is any other"
ESV, NRSV: "any other"
NIV: "whatever other"
NLT: "other such"
notes: εἴ τις 'if any' seems to fuinction as an abbreviation of 'if there is any'

greek_protases.p1: εἴ τις ἑτέρα ἐντολή

greek_apodoses.q1: ἐν τῷ λόγῳ τούτῳ ἀνακεφαλαιοῦται ἐν τῷ Ἀγαπήσεις τὸν πλησίον σου ὡς σεαυτόν

english:
p: (for if we live)
q: (we live to the Lord)

greek_protases.p1: ἐάν τε γὰρ ζῶμεν

english:
p: (and if we die)
q: (we die to the Lord)

greek_protases.p1: ἐάν τε ἀποθνῄσκωμεν

english:
p: (for if your brother is grieved by what you eat)
q: (you are no longer walking in love)
notes: This conditional is used to explain the previous verse (discussed in the non-conditional section below). Although Paul has just claimed that nothing is inherently unclean, we need to be aware of how other people view things so as not to 'grieve' them.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ γὰρ διὰ βρῶμα ὁ ἀδελφός σου λυπεῖται

english:
p: (the one doubting, if he eats)
q: (he has been condemned) (literal translation)
notes: ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV, and NLT all express this as an inverted conditional, e.g. ESV: q: (whoever has doubts is condemned) p: (if he eats). In Greek, p "if he eats" comes between the subject "whoever has doubts" and the rest of q "is condemned".

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν φάγῃ

english:
p: (for if the Gentiles have come to share in their spiritual blessings)
q: (they ought also to be of service to them in material blessings)
notes: The "saints at Jerusalem" (v.26) are Jews who have believed in Christ. In chapter 11 Paul explained that the Gentiles have received spiritual blessings that were first given to the Jew, and so p expresses a known fact.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ γὰρ τοῖς πνευματικοῖς αὐτῶν ἐκοινώνησαν τὰ ἔθνη

greek_apodoses.q1: ὀφείλουσιν καὶ ἐν τοῖς σαρκικοῖς λειτουργῆσαι αὐτοῖς

english:
p: (for if they had,)
q: (they would not have crucified the Lord of glory)
notes: Paul uses a false p and q to prove the truthfulness of the previous statement, "None of the rulers of this age understood this, for..."

greek_protases.p1: εἰ γὰρ ἔγνωσαν

greek_apodoses.q1: οὐκ ἂν τὸν κύριον τῆς δόξης ἐσταύρωσαν

english:
p: (Now if anyone builds on the foundation with gold, silver, precious stones, wood, hay, straw)
q: (each one's work will become manifest)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: no conditional
notes:
Greek: εἰ τις "If anyone"
The conditional elaborates on v.10-11 where Paul describes himself as laying the foundation of Jesus Christ, and another is building on this foundation. Grammatically, the time reference of p is present, but we have listed it as gnomic (timeless) because it appears to refer to anyone who has built, is building, or will build; the work of any of these people will eventually "be shown for what it is." (NIV)

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δέ τις ἐποικοδομεῖ ἐπὶ τὸν θεμέλιον χρυσόν ἄργυρον λίθους τιμίους ξύλα χόρτον καλάμην

english:
p: (if the work that anyone has built on the foundation survives)
q: (he will receive a reward)
notes:
In Greek, this is "If anyone’s work will remain which he built on it, a reward he will receive."
Those who build on the foundation will be tried and tested; the conditionals in v.14 and 15 show the two possible outcomes.

greek_protases.p1: εἴ τινος τὸ ἔργον μενεῖ ὃ ἐποικοδόμησεν

english:
p: (if anyone's work is burned up)
q: (he will suffer loss, though he himself will be saved, but only as through fire)
notes: This shows the alternative to v.14.

greek_protases.p1: εἴ τινος τὸ ἔργον κατακαήσεται

greek_apodoses.q1: ζημιωθήσεται αὐτὸς δὲ σωθήσεται οὕτως δὲ ὡς διὰ πυρός

english:
p: (if anyone destroys God's temple)
q: (God will destroy him)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: no conditional

greek_protases.p1: εἴ τις τὸν ναὸν τοῦ θεοῦ φθείρει

english:
p: (if anyone among you thinks that he is wise in this age)
q: (let him become a fool that he may become wise)
notes:
The expression εἴ τις δοκεῖ  "If anyone thinks/imagines..." is also used in 8:2 and 14:37.
ESV and NASB follow the Greek and use a 3rd person 'he' throughout; NRSV, NIV, and NLT use 2nd person 'you': "If any of you think you are wise by the standards of this age, you should become “fools” so that you may become wise." (NIV)

greek_protases.p1: εἴ τις δοκεῖ σοφὸς εἶναι ἐν ὑμῖν ἐν τῷ αἰῶνι τούτῳ

english:
p: (if then you received it)
q: (why do you boast as if you did not receive it?)
notes: P presents a known fact (you received everything from God), and q is a rhetorical question that functions as a rebuke (so you should not boast).

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ καὶ ἔλαβες

english:
p: (even if you had ten thousand guardians in Christ)
q: (you do not have many fathers) (NIV)
english_translations:
ESV: "though you have"
NASB: "if you were to have"
NRSV: "though you might have"
NIV, NLT: "even if you had"
notes:
This is a case of hyperbole; p expresses an extremely high number (μυρίους "countless" is literally 10,000) that is unlikely to be true, but q expresses a statement that is true regardless of p. For this reason, ESV "though you have" is not a good model to follow; a better model is NIV, NLT "even if you had ten thousand..." (Note that the past tense 'had' in English here indicates a non-factual statement, not a past time statement; the time reference is actually present.)
Boyer notes that this has a concessive ('even if') sense even though ἐὰν is not accompanied by the usual και. See also "concessive conditionals" article.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν γὰρ μυρίους παιδαγωγοὺς ἔχητε ἐν Χριστῷ

english:
q: (But I will come to you soon)
p: (if the Lord wills)
notes: Paul plans and desires to go to the Corinthians, but he remains submissive to God's leading.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν ὁ κύριος θελήσῃ

english:
q: (But now I am writing to you not to associate with anyone who bears the name of brother)
p: (if he is guilty of sexual immorality or greed, or is an idolater, reviler, drunkard, or swindler)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, RSV: "if"
NRSV, NIV, NLT: no conditional
notes: In Greek, ἐὰν 'if' comes before 'one who is called a brother'. A possible alternative translation is: "But now I am writing to you not to associate with anyone if he is called a brother and/but is guilty of immorality or greed, or is an idolater, reviler, drunkard, or swindler."

greek_protases.p1: ἐάν τις ἀδελφὸς ὀνομαζόμενος ᾖ πόρνος ἢ πλεονέκτης ἢ εἰδωλολάτρης ἢ λοίδορος ἢ μέθυσος ἢ ἅρπαξ

greek_apodoses.q1: νῦν δὲ ἔγραψα ὑμῖν μὴ συναναμίγνυσθαι

english:
p: (if the world is to be judged by you)
q: (are you incompetent to try trivial cases?)
notes: Third in a line of rhetorical questions rebuking the Corinthians for how they, presumably, have been dealing with conflicts within the church.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ἐν ὑμῖν κρίνεται ὁ κόσμος

english:
p: (if you have such cases)
q: (why so you lay them before those who have no standing in the church?)

greek_protases.p1: βιωτικὰ μὲν οὖν κριτήρια ἐὰν ἔχητε

greek_apodoses.q1: τοὺς ἐξουθενημένους ἐν τῇ ἐκκλησίᾳ τούτους καθίζετε

english:
q: (it is good for them [the unmarried and widows)
p: (if they remain even as I [am]) (NASB)
english_translations:
NASB: "if"
ESV, NRSV, NIV, NLT: no conditional
notes:
This could be rephrased without a conditional, as ESV does: ...it is good for them to remain single, as I am.
In Greek, this is the first of a series of conditional sentences (vs.8, 9, 11, 12, 13, 15) concerning singleness and marriage.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν μείνωσιν ὡς κἀγώ

english:
p: (But if they cannot exercise self-control)
q: (they should marry)
notes: This and the previous conditional work together. The first conditional represents Paul's first choice and the second represents another, not as good option, for those who are unable to do the first. The force of the 3rd person imperative γαμησάτωσαν "let them marry" is expressed as an exhortation "they should marry" in most English translations. Note that 3rd person imperative forms are also used in q in vs.11, 12 and 13.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ οὐκ ἐγκρατεύονται

english:
p: (but if she does leave)
q: (she must remain unmarried, or else be reconciled to her husband) (NASB)
notes:
The context pf p is 7:10 "the wife should not separate from her husband". If p happens, q allows two choices. It is not determined which of these must happen, only that no other things should happen.
The force of the 3rd person imperative μενέτω ἄγαμος is understood differently in different translations: NASB and NIV express it as a command "she must remain unmarried", ESV as an exhortation "she should remain unmarried", and NRSV and NLT as an exhortation/concession "let her remain unmarried".

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν δὲ καὶ χωρισθῇ

greek_apodoses.q1: μενέτω ἄγαμος ἢ τῷ ἀνδρὶ καταλλαγήτω

english:
p: (if any brother has a wife who is an unbeliever, and she consents to live with him)
q: (he should not divorce her)
notes: The "if" here is situational and means "in the case that" (Ellingworth). A non-conditional way to render this is: "Any man whose wife is not a believer but is willing to live with him should not divorce her." In some languages, it may be best to use a more direct, 2nd person form: "If your wife is not a believer, but she is willing  to live with you, you should not divorce her." The negative 3rd person imperative μὴ ἀφιέτω is translated in NASB, NIV and NLT as a command "he must not divorce", and in ESV and NRSV as an exhortation "he should not divorce".

greek_protases.p1: εἴ τις ἀδελφὸς γυναῖκα ἔχει ἄπιστον καὶ αὕτη συνευδοκεῖ οἰκεῖν μετ αὐτοῦ

english:
p: (if any woman has a husband who is an unbeliever, and he consents to live with her)
q: (she should not divorce him)
english_translations:
ESV, NRSV, NIV, NLT: "if"
NASB: no conditional
notes: This verse is parallel to v.12 but addresses a believing woman whose husband is not a believer. In some languages and cultures, a woman cannot divorce a man (but a woman can be divorced by a man). In this case, it may be necessary to use a verb such as 'leave'. The force of the command/exhortation should be the same in v.12 and v.13.

greek_protases.p1: καὶ γυνὴ εἴ τις ἔχει ἄνδρα ἄπιστον καὶ οὗτος συνευδοκεῖ οἰκεῖν μετ αὐτῆς

english:
p: (but if the unbelieving partner seperates)
q: (let it be so)
notes: Paired with the conditionals in 7:12,13 gives the unbeliever the choice - they can stay or they can separate. ESV, NASB and NIV all translate q as "let it be so"; NASB "let him leave" follows the form of the Greek more closely but "him" should be understood as applying to both male and female, which NLT translates using a gender-neutral "them". The force of this 3rd person passive imperative is not a command but rather permission.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ ὁ ἄπιστος χωρίζεται

english:
p: (but if you can gain your freedom)
q: (avail yourself of that opportunity)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NIV, NLT: "if"
NRSV: "even if"
notes:
The Greek here has εἰ καὶ, but only NRSV translates this as "even if". It is recommended to follow other translations, such as NIV: "although if you can gain your freedom, do so."  Paul is not addressing a particular individual here, so we have listed the probability of p as Neutral.
Boyer suggests that 7:21a could be an implied conditional: "If you were a bondservant when called, do not be concerned about it."

greek_protases.p1: εἰ καὶ δύνασαι ἐλεύθερος γενέσθαι

english:
p: (but if you do marry)
q: (you have not sinned)
notes:
Most take the pair of conditionals in v.28 to be talking about unmarried men and unmarried women respectively.
The Greek ἐὰν καὶ  could be interpreted as "even if" (a 'concessive conditional'), in which q is not dependent on the validity of p. This interpretation is appropriate if Paul assumes that most of his readers will obey his command in v.27 to "not sek a wife". The ESV, NIV and NLT express a similar idea in English by using the emphatic "if you do marry" rather than the normal "if you marry".

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν δὲ καὶ γαμήσῃς

english:
p: (and if a virgin marries)
q: (she has not sinned) (NASB, NIV)
notes: See 7:28a. NASB, NRSV abd NIV translate παρθένος as "virgin"; ESV translates it as "betrothed woman" and NLT translates it as "young woman".

greek_protases.p1: καὶ ἐὰν γήμῃ ἡ παρθένος

english:
p1: (if anyone thinks that he is not behaving properly toward his betrothed)
p2: (if his passions are strong, and it has to be)
q: (let him do as he wishes: let them marry)
notes:
This is a complicated sentence because there are two distinct protases (p1 and p2) and q contains two clauses that express basically the same idea.
For p2, "if his passions are strong" is the majority interpretation (ESV, NRSV, NIV, NLT); NASB has "if she is past her youth" (see also NET), and in fact interprets τὴν παρθένον αὐτοῦ "the virgin of him" as "his virgin daughter" rather than as "his fiancée".

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ δέ τις ἀσχημονεῖν ἐπὶ τὴν παρθένον αὐτοῦ νομίζει ἐὰν ᾖ ὑπέρακμος καὶ οὕτως ὀφείλει γίνεσθαι

greek_apodoses.q1: ὃ θέλει ποιείτω οὐχ ἁμαρτάνει γαμείτωσαν

english:
p: (but if her husband dies)
q: (she is free to be married to whom she wishes, only in the Lord)
notes: This condition describes teh situation when 7:39a no longer applies: "A wife is bound to her husband as long as he lives."

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν δὲ κοιμηθῇ ὁ ἀνήρ

greek_apodoses.q1: ἐλευθέρα ἐστὶν ᾧ θέλει γαμηθῆναι μόνον ἐν κυρίῳ

english:
q: (she is happier)
p: (if she remains as she is)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: no conditional
notes: Paul emphasizes that this is his opinion.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν οὕτως μείνῃ

english:
p: (if anyone imagines that he knows something)
q: (he does not yet know as he ought to know)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB: "if anyone"
NRSV, NLT: "anyone who"
NIV: "those who"
notes:
εἴ τις 'if anyone'
Similar to 3:18, 14:37 "If anyone thinks/imagines" and Gal 6:3 "if anyone thinks he is something, he deceives himself."
This knowing likely refers to the previous verse which talks about the knowledge which "puffs up". Although they may "know things" it is of little use since it is not use to benefit the body of Christ. There were people in the Corinthian church claiming to have secret knowledge (Ellingworth) so this is at least very likely to be true.

greek_protases.p1: εἴ τις δοκεῖ ἐγνωκέναι τι

english:
p: (but if anyone loves God)
q: (he is known by God)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB: "if anyone"
NRSV: "anyone"
NIV: "whoever"
NLT: "the person who"
notes: εἴ τις 'if anyone'

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δέ τις ἀγαπᾷ τὸν θεόν

english:
p: (even though there may be so-called gods...)
q: (yet for us there is one God...) (NRSV)
english_translations:
ESV: "although"
NASB, NIV: "even if"
NRSV: "even though"
NLT: "there may be"
notes: και εἴπερ 'even though' is a concessive conditional, in which q is not dependent on the validity of p. Rather, p describes a situation which emphasizes q by virtue of its exceptional and/or unexpected nature. P states that it is true that there are so-called gods, but indicates that this is of no importance, because for us there is only one God.

greek_protases.p1: καὶ γὰρ εἴπερ εἰσὶν λεγόμενοι θεοὶ εἴτε ἐν οὐρανῷ εἴτε ἐπὶ γῆς ὥσπερ εἰσὶν θεοὶ πολλοὶ καὶ κύριοι πολλοί

greek_apodoses.q1: ἀλλ ἡμῖν εἷς θεὸς ὁ πατήρ

english:
q: (we are no worse off)
p: (if we do not eat)
notes:
ἐάν μή 'if ... not'; in Greek p comes before q, and is introduced by οὔτε 'neither/nor' but most English translations invert p and q.
The negative "if... not" should be kept in translation, if possible, because it forms part of a contrastive pair. If this is not natural, here are two alternatives:
1) use an expression like 'fast' or 'abstain' if your language has this: "If we fast/abstain we are not worse, and if we eat we are not better."
2) combine the two conditionals: "Whether we eat or not makes no difference at all."

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν μὴ φάγωμεν

english:
q: (and no better of)
p: (if we do)
notes: This forms a contrastive pair with v.8a. In Greek p comes before q, and is introduced by οὔτε 'neither/nor' ("nor if we eat we are better") but most English translations invert p and q.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν φάγωμεν

english:
p: (for if anyone sees you who have knowledge eating in an idol's temple)
q: (will he not be encouraged if his conscience is weak to eat food offered to idols)
notes:
Although there is a second 'if' in ESV and NASB it is part of q and is not a conditional in Greek. 
A very literal translation might look like this  "For if anyone should see you the one having knowledge eating in an idol's temple, (might) not his conscience being weak be strengthened to eat food offered to idols." (Trail)

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν γάρ τις ἴδῃ σὲ τὸν ἔχοντα γνῶσιν ἐν εἰδωλείῳ κατακείμενον

greek_apodoses.q1: οὐχὶ ἡ συνείδησις αὐτοῦ ἀσθενοῦς ὄντος οἰκοδομηθήσεται εἰς τὸ τὰ εἰδωλόθυτα ἐσθίειν

english:
p: (if food makes my brother stumble)
q: (I will never eat meat)
notes: Whether the food we eat is likely to cause a fellow believer to stumble will vary for each individual believer. Paul was not a member of the congregation at Corinth where food did cause some believers to stumble, but he describes how he would behave if he were in that situation.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ βρῶμα σκανδαλίζει τὸν ἀδελφόν μου

greek_apodoses.q1: οὐ μὴ φάγω κρέα εἰς τὸν αἰῶνα

english:
p: (if to others I am not an apostle)
q: (at least I am to you)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV: "if"
NIV: "even though"
NLT: "even if"
notes: Boyer notes that this is one of the instances where the conditional is concessive ('even if') without the use of και. Although p and q are connected, q is true regardless of p.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ἄλλοις οὐκ εἰμὶ ἀπόστολος

english:
p: (if we have sown spiritual things among you)
q: 11b
notes: Q here is the whole conditional statement in 9:11b. The image here is from farming, where seeds are sown and a harvest is reaped.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ἡμεῖς ὑμῶν τὰ σαρκικὰ θερίσομεν

greek_apodoses.q1: μέγα εἰ ἡμεῖς ὑμῶν τὰ σαρκικὰ θερίσομεν

english:
q: (is it too much)
p: (if we reap material things from you?)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: no conditional
notes: Some English translations express this without a conditional, which avoids having a conditional embedded within a conditional. NET: "is it too much to reap material things from you?" NLT: "aren't we entitled to a harvest of physical food and drink?"

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ἡμεῖς ὑμῶν τὰ σαρκικὰ θερίσομεν

english:
p: (If others share this rightful claim on you)
q: (do not we even more?)
notes: Elaborating on the previous verse, Paul reminds his readers in p that they have supported other preachers, and asks in q (using a rhetorical question) whether he and his companions do not deserve to be supported as well.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ἄλλοι τῆς ὑμῶν ἐξουσίας μετέχουσιν

english:
p: (If I preach the gospel)
q: (that gives me no ground for boasting)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV: "if"
NIV: "when"
NLT: no conditional
notes: This is something Paul is doing, so NIV has: "when I preach the gospel, I cannot boast"

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν γὰρ εὐαγγελίζωμαι

english:
q: (Woe to me)
p: (if I do [did] not preach the gospel)
notes:
The negative conditional ἐάν μή 'if ... not' should be kept if possible, as this is the negative counterpart to the affirmative conditional in the first part of the verse. (Note that the affirmative conditional is factual - Paul is proclaiming the gospel, but the negative conditional is non-factual.) 
It may be more natural to put p before q: "If I didn't proclaim the gospel, it would be so terrible for me."
In some languages, 'not proclaim' can be expressed as 'fail to proclaim': "If I were to fail to proclaim the good news, it would be so terrble for me."

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν μὴ εὐαγγελίσωμαι

english:
p: (for if I do this of my own will)
q: (I have a reward)
notes: 9:17 contains two conditionals that describe two situations - the first (v.17a) false, the second (v.17b) true.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ γὰρ ἑκὼν τοῦτο πράσσω

english:
p: (but if not of my own will)
q: (I am still entrusted with a stewardship)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: no conditional
notes: 9:16a shows that this conditional is factual as Paul wrote "I am compelled to preach" (NIV).

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ ἄκων

english:
p: (if one of the unbelievers invites you to dinner and you are disposed to go)
q: (eat whatever is set before you without raising any question on the ground of conscience)

greek_protases.p1: εἴ τις καλεῖ ὑμᾶς τῶν ἀπίστων καὶ θέλετε πορεύεσθαι

greek_apodoses.q1: πᾶν τὸ παρατιθέμενον ὑμῖν ἐσθίετε μηδὲν ἀνακρίνοντες διὰ τὴν συνείδησιν

english:
p: (but if someone says to you "this has been offered in sacrifice")
q: (then do not eat it)

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν δέ τις ὑμῖν εἴπῃ Τοῦτο ἱερόθυτόν ἐστιν

english:
p: (if I partake with thankfulness)
q: (why am I denounced beacuase of that for which I give thanks?)

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ἐγὼ χάριτι μετέχω

greek_apodoses.q1: τί βλασφημοῦμαι ὑπὲρ οὗ ἐγὼ εὐχαριστῶ

english:
p: (for if a woman does not cover her head)
q: (let her also have her hair cut off) (NASB)
notes:
It would have been shameful for a woman to have her hair cut off or cut short, in both Jewish and Greek society, so Paul is issuing a strong rebuke to women who do not cover their heads while praying. NIV expresses this naturally in English as "For if a woman does not cover her head, she might as well have her hair cut off."
ESV translates γυνή as "wife" butthe other translations all have "woman".

greek_protases.p1: εἰ γὰρ οὐ κατακαλύπτεται γυνή

english:
p: (but if it is disgraceful for a woman to have her hair cut off or her head shaved)
q: (let her cover her head) (NASB)
notes: Here Paul makes the same point as in v.6a, but he starts with the (then) commonly accepted truth that it was shameful for a woman to have her hair cut off or cut short in p; q is an imperative and has the force of a command.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ αἰσχρὸν γυναικὶ τὸ κείρασθαι ἢ ξυρᾶσθαι

english:
Does not nature itself teach you that
p: (if a man wears long hair)
q: (it is a disgrace for him)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: no conditional
notes: Vs14 and 15 together describe Paul's teaching about men and women's hair.

greek_protases.p1: ἀνὴρ μὲν ἐὰν κομᾷ

english:
p: (but if a woman has long hair)
q: (it is her glory?)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: no conditional

greek_protases.p1: γυνὴ δὲ ἐὰν κομᾷ

english:
p: (if anyone is inclined to be contentious)
q: (we have no such practice, nor do the churches of God)

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δέ τις δοκεῖ φιλόνεικος εἶναι

greek_apodoses.q1: ἡμεῖς τοιαύτην συνήθειαν οὐκ ἔχομεν οὐδὲ αἱ ἐκκλησίαι τοῦ θεοῦ

english:
p: (but if we judged ourselves truly)
q: (we would not be judged)
notes: In v.29 Paul has stated that some have been judged, so p is not true.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ ἑαυτοὺς διεκρίνομεν

english:
p: (if anyone is hungry)
q: (let him eat at home)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NLT: "if"
NIV: no conditional
notes: This has ben interpreted as, "if anyone is so hungry that he cannot wait for everyone to arrive, he should eat at home" (Hatton) or "if you want to gorge yourselves... eat at home" (Fee)

greek_protases.p1: εἴ τις πεινᾷ

english:
p: (if the foot should say "because I am not a hand, I do not belong to the body")
q: (that would not make it any less a part of the body)
notes: This is the first of a series of conditionals in which Paul develops the metaphor of the church as a body.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν εἴπῃ ὁ πούς Ὅτι οὐκ εἰμὶ χείρ οὐκ εἰμὶ ἐκ τοῦ σώματος

greek_apodoses.q1: οὐ παρὰ τοῦτο οὐκ ἔστιν ἐκ τοῦ σώματος

english:
p: (and if the ear should say, "Because I am not an eye, I do not belong to the body")
q: (that would not make it any less a part of the body)

greek_protases.p1: καὶ ἐὰν εἴπῃ τὸ οὖς Ὅτι οὐκ εἰμὶ ὀφθαλμός οὐκ εἰμὶ ἐκ τοῦ σώματος

greek_apodoses.q1: οὐ παρὰ τοῦτο οὐκ ἔστιν ἐκ τοῦ σώματος

english:
p: (if the whole body were an eye)
q: (where would be the sense of hearing?)

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ὅλον τὸ σῶμα ὀφθαλμός

english:
p: (if the whole body were an ear)
q: (where would be the sense of smell?)

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ὅλον ἀκοή

english:
p: (if all were a single member)
q: (where would the body be?)

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ ἦν τὰ πάντα ἓν μέλος

english:
p: (if one member suffers)
q: (all suffer together)
notes: In Greek the form of both conditionals in v.26 is εἴτε, indicating that they are complimentary and should be understood together.

greek_protases.p1: εἴτε πάσχει ἓν μέλος

english:
p: (if one member is honoured)
q: (all rejoice together)
notes: εἴτε See 12:26a

greek_protases.p1: εἴτε δοξάζεται μέλος

english:
p: (if I speak in the tongues of men and of angels, but have not love)
q: (I am a noisy gong or a clanging cymbal)

greek_protases.p1: Ἐὰν ταῖς γλώσσαις τῶν ἀνθρώπων λαλῶ καὶ τῶν ἀγγέλων ἀγάπην δὲ μὴ ἔχω

greek_apodoses.q1: γέγονα χαλκὸς ἠχῶν ἢ κύμβαλον ἀλαλάζον

english:
p1: (and if I have prophetic powers, and understand all mysteries and all knowledge [...but have not love])
p2: (and if I have all faith, so as to remove mountains, but have not love)
q: (I am nothing)
notes: This verse has a complex protasis consisting of three positive statements (1) I have prophecy, (2) I know all mysteries and all knowledge, (3) I have all faith so as to remove mountains; in Greek, ἐὰν 'if' occurs before (1) and (3). Most English translations follow the Greek and use "if" twice, but NLT uses "if" before all three statements. In some languages, it may be more natural to only have one conditional markerfor all three statements. These positive statements are followed by one negative statement "but love I do not have", which overrides the positive statements; in Greek there is emphasis on "love" (which is fronted).

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν ἔχω προφητείαν καὶ εἰδῶ τὰ μυστήρια πάντα καὶ πᾶσαν τὴν γνῶσιν
greek_protases.p2: ἐὰν ἔχω πᾶσαν τὴν πίστιν ὥστε ὄρη μεθιστάναι

english:
p1: (if I give away all I have [...but have not love])
p2: (and if I deliver up my body to be burned, but have not love)
q: (I gain nothing)
notes: This verse has a complex protasis consisting of two positive statements (1) I give away all my possessions, (2) I surrender my body to be burned. In Greek, p1 has κἂν and p2 has καὶ ἐὰν both of which can be understood either as 'even if or 'and if', but no English translation translates these as concessives (except KJV & NKJV which use "though"). Most English translations follow the Greek and use "if" twice, but NIV and NLT only use "if" once. As with 13:2, these positive statements are followed by one negative statement "but love I do not have", which overrides the positive statements; in Greek there is emphasis on "love" (which is fronted).

greek_protases.p1: ψωμίσω πάντα τὰ ὑπάρχοντά μου
greek_protases.p2: ἐὰν ψωμίσω πάντα τὰ ὑπάρχοντά μου καὶ ἐὰν παραδῶ τὸ σῶμά μου ἵνα

english:
q: (The one who prophesies is greater than the one who speaks in tongues)
p: (unless someone [he] interprets)
notes:
εἰ μὴ 'if not' is modified by ἐκτὸς 'except'. This phrase is only used two other times:1 Cor 15:2b and 1Ti 5:19.
The subject of "interprets" is either "someone" (ESV, NRSV, NIV, NLT) or "he", i.e. the one who speaks in tongues (NASB, ASV, NET, REB).
If a translation of of "unless", "except if", or "if not" is unclear or unnatural in your language, this can be rephrased as an affirmative with 'only': "The one who speaks in tongues is only greater than the one who prophesies if he/someone interprets what he has said."

greek_protases.p1: εἰ μὴ διερμηνεύῃ

greek_apodoses.q1: μείζων δὲ ὁ προφητεύων ἢ ὁ λαλῶν γλώσσαις

english:
p: (if I come to you speaking in tongues)
q: (14:6b)
notes: Q is the whole of 14:6b, which is itself a conditional. If necessary, this could be broken up into two separate sentences: (6a) "if I come to you speaking in tongues, how will this benefit you? (6b) It will not benefit you unless I bring you some revelation or knowledge or prophecy or teaching."

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν ἔλθω πρὸς ὑμᾶς γλώσσαις λαλῶν

greek_apodoses.q1: τί ὑμᾶς ὠφελήσω ἐὰν μὴ ὑμῖν λαλήσω ἢ ἐν ἀποκαλύψει ἢ ἐν γνώσει ἢ ἐν προφητείᾳ ἢ ἐν διδαχῇ

english:
q: (how will I benefit you ~ implies: I will not benefit you)
p: (unless I bring you [= if I do not bring you] some revelation or knowledge or prophecy or teaching)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "unless"
NLT: no conditional
notes:
This conditional functions as q of the conditional 'if I come to you speaking in tongues' in 14:6a. 
Paraphrase (for languages without 'unless' or 'except'); this breaks the verse into two separate sentences, and makes the negative conditional into an affirmative: "I will benefit you only if I bring you some revelation or knowledge or prophecy or teaching."
NLT provides an alternative structure: "Dear brothers and sisters, if I should (or: were to) come to you speaking in an unknown language, how would that help you? But if I bring you a revelation or some special knowledge or prophecy or teaching, that will be helpful."

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν μὴ ὑμῖν λαλήσω ἢ ἐν ἀποκαλύψει ἢ ἐν γνώσει ἢ ἐν προφητείᾳ ἢ ἐν διδαχῇ

english:
It is the same way with lifeless instruments that produce sound, such as the flute or the harp
p: (If they do not give distinct notes,)
q: ( how will anyone know what is being played?) (NRSV)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV: "if... not"
NIV: "unless"
NLT: no conditional
notes:
ἐάν...μή 'if... not', 'unless'
Paraphrase (to avoid multiple negatives in languages without 'unless' or 'except'): 'Consider lifeless instruments like the flute or the harp; only if they produce clear notes will a person recognize the melody.'
The question "how will it be known what is played on the flute or on the harp?" expects a negative answer: "It will not be known."

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν διαστολὴν τοῖς φθόγγοις μὴ δῷ

greek_apodoses.q1: πῶς γνωσθήσεται τὸ αὐλούμενον ἢ τὸ κιθαριζόμενον

english:
p: (if the bugle gives an indistinct sound)
q: (who will get ready for battle?)
notes: Note that 14:7b, 8, 9 are making basically the same argument. 14:7b & 8 provide illustrations, and 14:9 provides the application.

greek_protases.p1: καὶ γὰρ ἐὰν ἄδηλον φωνὴν σάλπιγξ δῷ

english:
p: (if with your tongue you utter speech that is not intelligible)
q: (how will anyone know what is said?) (ESV)
Or:
p: (unless you speak intelligible words with your tongue,)
q: (how will anyone know what you are saying?) (NIV)
english_translations:
ESV, NRSV, NLT: "if... not"
NASB, NIV: "unless"
notes:
ἐάν μή 'if ... not', 'unless'
Paraphrase avoiding rhetorical question: "If the tongue does not speak words that people understand, no one will know what is said."
Paraphrase (to avoid multiple negatives in languages without 'unless' or 'except'): "Only if the tongue speaks understandable words will people know what is said."
NLT expresses thisas: "If you speak to people in words they don’t understand, how will they know what you are saying?"

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν μὴ εὔσημον λόγον δῶτε

english:
p: (If I do not know the meaning of the language)
q: (I will be a foreigner to the speaker and the speaker [will be] a foreigner to me)
english_translations: ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV, NLT: "if... not"
notes: ἐάν... μή 'if... not'

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν οὖν μὴ εἰδῶ τὴν δύναμιν τῆς φωνῆς

greek_apodoses.q1: ἔσομαι τῷ λαλοῦντι βάρβαρος καὶ ὁ λαλῶν ἐν ἐμοὶ βάρβαρος

english:
p: (if I pray in a tongue)
q: (my spirit prays but my mind is unfruitful)

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν γὰρ προσεύχωμαι γλώσσῃ

greek_apodoses.q1: τὸ πνεῦμά μου προσεύχεται ὁ δὲ νοῦς μου ἄκαρπός ἐστιν

english:
p: (if you give thanks with your spirit)
q: (how can anyone in the position of an outsider say 'amen' to your thanksgiving when he does not know what you are saying?)
notes: Q is a rhetorical question meant to be answered "they cannot".

greek_protases.p1: ἐπεὶ ἐὰν εὐλογῇς πνεύματι

greek_apodoses.q1: ὁ ἀναπληρῶν τὸν τόπον τοῦ ἰδιώτου πῶς ἐρεῖ τὸ Ἀμήν ἐπὶ τῇ σῇ εὐχαριστίᾳ

english:
p: (if the whole church comes together and all speak in tongues, and outsiders or unbelievers enter)
q: (will they not say that you are out of your minds?)
notes: Q is a rhetorical question meant to be answered "they will".

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν οὖν συνέλθῃ ἡ ἐκκλησία ὅλη ἐπὶ τὸ αὐτὸ καὶ πάντες λαλῶσιν γλώσσαις

greek_apodoses.q1: εἰσέλθωσιν δὲ ἰδιῶται ἢ ἄπιστοι οὐκ ἐροῦσιν ὅτι μαίνεσθε

english:
p: (if all prophesy, and an unbeliever or outsider enters)
q: (he is convicted by all, his is called to account by all...)

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν δὲ πάντες προφητεύωσιν

english:
p: (if any speak in a tongue)
q: (let there be only two or at most three, and each in turn, and let someone interpret)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: no conditional
notes: εἴτε "if"

greek_protases.p1: εἴτε γλώσσῃ τις λαλεῖ

greek_apodoses.q1: κατὰ δύο ἢ τὸ πλεῖστον τρεῖς καὶ ἀνὰ μέρος καὶ εἷς διερμηνευέτω

english:
p: (if there is no one to interpret)
q: (let each of them keep silent in church and speak to himself and to God)
notes: ἐάν...μή 'if...not

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν δὲ μὴ ᾖ διερμηνευτής

greek_apodoses.q1: σιγάτω ἐν ἐκκλησίᾳ ἑαυτῷ δὲ λαλείτω καὶ τῷ θεῷ

english:
p: (if a revelation is made to another sitting there)
q: (let the first be silent)

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν δὲ ἄλλῳ ἀποκαλυφθῇ καθημένῳ

english:
p: (if there is anything they desire to learn)
q: (let them ask their husbands at home)

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δέ τι μαθεῖν θέλουσιν

greek_apodoses.q1: ἐν οἴκῳ τοὺς ἰδίους ἄνδρας ἐπερωτάτωσαν

english:
p: (if anyone thinks that he is a prophet, or spiritual)
q: (he should acknowledge that the things I am writing to you are a command of the Lord)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NIV: "if anyone"
NRSV: "anyone who"
NLT: "if you"
notes: Similar to 3:18, 8:2 "If anyone thinks/imagines"

greek_protases.p1: Εἴ τις δοκεῖ προφήτης εἶναι ἢ πνευματικός

greek_apodoses.q1: ἐπιγινωσκέτω ἃ γράφω ὑμῖν ὅτι κυρίου ἐστὶν

english:
p: (if anyone does not recognize this)
q: (he is not recognized)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NIV: "if anyone"
NRSV: "anyone who"
NLT: "if you"
notes: Refers back to 14:37

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δέ τις ἀγνοεῖ

english:
q: ([the gospel] by which you are being saved)
p: (if you hold fast the word which I preached to you)
notes: P is a continuation of v.1: "the gospel I preached to you, which you received, in which you stand, (2) and by which also you are being saved"; however, only "being saved" is dependent on "holding firmly to the message I proclaimed", and so it may be best to start a new sentence here, as NIV does: "By this gospel you are saved, if you hold firmly to the word I preached to you."

greek_protases.p1: εἰ κατέχετε

greek_apodoses.q1: δι οὗ καὶ σῴζεσθε τίνι λόγῳ εὐηγγελισάμην ὑμῖν

english:
q: (implied: you are being saved by the gospel)
p: (unless you believed in vain)
notes:
εἰ μὴ 'if not' is modified by ἐκτὸς 'except'. This phrase is only used two other times:1 Cor 14:5b and 1Ti 5:19.
NIV is a good model: "By this gospel you are saved, if you hold firmly to the word I preached to you. Otherwise, you have believed in vain." This is saying "If this is not true (i.e. you are not saved by the gospel), then you have believed for no reason." 
An alternative interpretation treats 'if you hold fast...' and 'unless you believed in vain' as two parallel conditions for 'you are saved by the gospel'. An example of this interpretation is NLT: "It is this Good News that saves you if you continue to believe the message I told you—unless, of course, you believed something that was never true in the first place." (Or: "... unless you never believed it in the forstplace."

greek_protases.p1: εἰ μὴ εἰκῇ ἐπιστεύσατε

english:
p: (now if Christ is proclaimed as raised from the dead)
q: (how can some of you say that there is no resurrection of the dead?)
notes:
The conditionals in 15:12-19 belong to the same argument and build on each other. Often they take q of the previous conditional (perhaps slightly modified) and use it as p of the new conditional. From v.13 on the protases are false, and so the corresponding apodoses are also false.
The time reference in v.12 refers to "is being proclaimed" not to "raised from the dead".

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ δὲ Χριστὸς κηρύσσεται ὅτι ἐκ νεκρῶν ἐγήγερται

greek_apodoses.q1: πῶς λέγουσιν ἐν ὑμῖν τινες ὅτι ἀνάστασις νεκρῶν οὐκ ἔστιν

english:
p: (but if there is no resurrection of the dead)
q: (then not even Christ has been raised)
notes:
See note on 15:12. 
The two negatives (in p and q) plus the fact that this is non-factual may cause difficulties in some languages. Lyman (1975) noted the following rendering in a Zapotec translation: “If it is true that the dead do not come back to life, then we cannot say that Christ came back to life.”

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ ἀνάστασις νεκρῶν οὐκ ἔστιν

english:
p: (and if Christ has not been raised)
q: (then our preaching is in vain and your faith is in vain)
notes: See note on 15:12.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ Χριστὸς οὐκ ἐγήγερται

greek_apodoses.q1: τὸ κήρυγμα ἡμῶν κενὴ καὶ ἡ πίστις ὑμῶν

english:
q: (But he did not raise him [Christ])
p: (if in fact the dead are not raised.) (NIV)
notes:
εἴπερ here indicates that p "the dead are not raised" is false.
See note on 15:12.

greek_protases.p1: εἴπερ ἄρα νεκροὶ οὐκ ἐγείρονται

english:
p: for (if the dead are not raised)
q: (not even Christ has been raised)
notes:
See note on 15:12.
Lyman (1975) suggests the following: "If it is true that God does not bring dead people back to life, then we cannot say that he brought Christ back to life."

greek_protases.p1: εἰ γὰρ νεκροὶ οὐκ ἐγείρονται

english:
p: (and if Christ has not been raised)
q: (your faith is futile and you are still in your sins)
notes:
See note on 15:12. 
"If it is true that Christ did not come back to life, then we cannot say that there is any use in believing Christ, nor can we say that our sins are not following us around." (Lyman 1975)

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ Χριστὸς οὐκ ἐγήγερται

greek_apodoses.q1: ματαία ἡ πίστις ὑμῶν ἔτι ἐστὲ ἐν ταῖς ἁμαρτίαις

english:
p: (if in Christ we have hope in this life only)
q: (we are of all people most to be pitied)
notes: See note on 15:12.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ἐν τῇ ζωῇ ταύτῃ ἐν Χριστῷ ἠλπικότες ἐσμὲν μόνον

english:
p: (if the dead are not raised at all)
q: (why are people baptized on their behalf?)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: no conditional
notes: The rhetorical question of q implies that this is something the people of Corinth are doing. However, it does not mean that Paul is condoning or encouraging the practice.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ὅλως νεκροὶ οὐκ ἐγείρονται

english:
p: (If from human motives I fought with wild beasts at Ephesus
q: (what does it profit me?) (NASB)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: no conditional
notes:
Not inverted in the Greek.
Paul did battle "wild beasts" in Ephesus, but not for human reasons (NIV)

greek_protases.p1: εἰ κατὰ ἄνθρωπον ἐθηριομάχησα ἐν Ἐφέσῳ

english:
p: (if the dead are not raised)
q: (let us eat and drink, for tomorrow we die)
notes: Q is quoted from Isaiah 22:13.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ νεκροὶ οὐκ ἐγείρονται

greek_apodoses.q1: Φάγωμεν καὶ πίωμεν αὔριον γὰρ ἀποθνῄσκομεν

english:
q: (What you sow does not come to life)
p: (unless it dies = if it does not die)
notes:
ἐάν μή 'unless'
Paraphrase (to avoid multiple negatives in languages without 'unless' or 'except'): "That which you sow comes to life [is made alive] only if it dies."

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν μὴ ἀποθάνῃ

english:
p: (if there is a natural body)
q: (there is also a spiritual body)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: "just as"
notes: 15:42-43 accounts for what happens in the resurrection of the dead. This is the conclusion of that argument - beginning with something they all know to be true thus claiming that q must also be true.

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ ἔστιν σῶμα ψυχικόν

english:
p: (if it seems advisable that I should go also)
q: (they will accompany me)

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν δὲ ἄξιον ᾖ τοῦ κἀμὲ πορεύεσθαι

english:
q: (I hope to spend some time with you)
p: (if the Lord permits)

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν ὁ κύριος ἐπιτρέψῃ

greek_apodoses.q1: ἐλπίζω γὰρ χρόνον τινὰ ἐπιμεῖναι πρὸς ὑμᾶς

english:
p: (when Timothy comes)
q: (see that you put him at ease among you)
notes: Although it is not certain, Paul writes as if he fully expects Timothy to visit Corinth.

greek_protases.p1: Ἐὰν δὲ ἔλθῃ Τιμόθεος

greek_apodoses.q1: βλέπετε ἵνα ἀφόβως γένηται πρὸς ὑμᾶς

english:
p: (if anyone has no love for the Lord)
q: (let him be accursed)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NIV, NLT: "if"
NRSV: no conditional

greek_protases.p1: εἴ τις οὐ φιλεῖ τὸν κύριον

english:
p: (if we are afflicted)
q: (it is for your comfort and salvation)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: "even when"
notes:
Both εἴτε conditionals in v.6 should be understood as a group. Together they encompass the spectrum of reality. In either situation, the result is comfort for the Corinthians. See also "ειτε conditional marker" article. 
Vs.4-5 make it clear that Paul and Timothy were afflicted/troubled.

greek_protases.p1: εἴτε δὲ θλιβόμεθα

greek_apodoses.q1: ὑπὲρ τῆς ὑμῶν παρακλήσεως καὶ σωτηρίας

english:
p: (and if we are comforted)
q: (it is for your comfort)
notes:
εἴτε See notes on 1:6a.
Vs.4-5 make it clear that Paul and Timothy were comorted/encouraged.

greek_protases.p1: εἴτε παρακαλούμεθα

english:
p: (for if I cause you pain)
q: (who is there to make me glad but the one whom I have pained?)
notes: In v.1 Paul refers to his last visit to the Corinthians and the pain it caused. He had decided not to visit again so as to avoid further pain (NASB "sorrow), and so we have rated the probability of p Very Likely.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ γὰρ ἐγὼ λυπῶ ὑμᾶς

greek_apodoses.q1: καὶ τίς ὁ εὐφραίνων με εἰ μὴ ὁ λυπούμενος ἐξ ἐμοῦ

english:
p: (if anyone has caused pain)
q: (he has caused it not to me but... to all of you)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: paraphrased in a relative clause
notes:
ει τις "if anyone"
Similarly to 2:2, Paul is discussing the specific problems in Corinth and almost certainly has a specific person in mind. The NLT translates in such a way that makes this explicit

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ δέ τις λελύπηκεν

greek_apodoses.q1: οὐκ ἐμὲ λελύπηκεν ἀλλὰ ἀπὸ μέρους ἵνα μὴ ἐπιβαρῶ πάντας ὑμᾶς

english:
p: (if I have forgiven anything)
q: (what I have forgiven has been for your sake in the presence of Christ)
notes:
εἴ τι 'if anything', 'whatever' (see Mat 18:28; 2Co 7:14, 1Ti 1:10). 
P "if I have fogiven anything" constitutes a parenthetical thought, occurring between two halves of its apodosis. Most English translations separate this off from the rest of the sentence with commas, dashes or brackets.
In this speech act conditional q is true regardless of the truth of p. Translator's Notes (Miller and Martens 2016) describe two possible interpretations of this verse, and encourage a translation that allows for either interpretation. Either the sin was not against Paul personally, so his forgiveness was not really required, or the sin was a small problem and easy to forgive (i.e. it was no longer a problem because the person had repented).

greek_protases.p1: εἴ τι κεχάρισμαι

greek_apodoses.q1d: καὶ γὰρ ἐγὼ ὃ κεχάρισμαι … δι ὑμᾶς ἐν προσώπῳ Χριστοῦ

english:
p: (Now if the ministry of death, carved in letters of stone, came with such glory...)
q: (will not the ministry of the Spirit have even more glory?)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: no conditional
notes: Paul compares the glory of the old covenant with the glory of the new convenant by using a factual conditional in v.7 and a rhetorical question that expects a "yes" answer in v.8. This conditional and the following two (v.9 and v.11) have essentially the same message stated three different ways: the new convenant is far more glorious than the old covenant.

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ δὲ ἡ διακονία τοῦ θανάτου ἐν γράμμασιν ἐντετυπωμένη λίθοις ἐγενήθη ἐν δόξῃ ὥστε μὴ δύνασθαι ἀτενίσαι τοὺς υἱοὺς Ἰσραὴλ εἰς τὸ πρόσωπον Μωϋσέως διὰ τὴν δόξαν τοῦ προσώπου αὐτοῦ τὴν καταργουμένην

greek_apodoses.q1: πῶς οὐχὶ μᾶλλον ἡ διακονία τοῦ πνεύματος ἔσται ἐν δόξῃ

english:
p: (For if there was glory in the ministry of condemnation)
q:(the minsitry of righteousness must far exceed it in glory)
notes: See note on v.7-8

greek_protases.p1: εἰ γὰρ τῇ διακονίᾳ τῆς κατακρίσεως δόξα

greek_apodoses.q1: πολλῷ μᾶλλον περισσεύει ἡ διακονία τῆς δικαιοσύνης δόξῃ

english:
p: (for if what was being brought to an end came with glory)
q: (much more will what is permanent have glory)
notes: Paul once more continues his arguement for the superior glory of the new covanent this time by comparing their durations. The old covanent was "fading away" while the other was permanent. See also note at v.7-8

greek_protases.p1: εἰ γὰρ τὸ καταργούμενον διὰ δόξης

greek_apodoses.q1: πολλῷ μᾶλλον τὸ μένον ἐν δόξῃ

english:
p: (even if our gospel is veiled)
q: (it is veiled to those who are perishing)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "even if"
NLT: "if"
notes:
εἰ καὶ 'if indeed', 'even if'
The force of this conditional is expressed well by NLT: "If the Good News we preach is hidden behind a veil, it is hidden only from people who are perishing."

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ καὶ ἔστιν κεκαλυμμένον τὸ εὐαγγέλιον ἡμῶν

english:
p: (though our outer self is wasting away)
q: (our inner self is being renewed day by day)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NIV, NLT: "though"
NRSV, "even though"
notes:
εἰ καὶ 'if indeed', 'even if', 'although'
This is a concessive conditional in which q is not dependent on the validity of p. Rather, p describes a situation which emphasizes q by virtue of its exceptional and/or unexpected nature. While it is grammatically a conditional in Greek, the reality of p means that most English translations use "though".

greek_protases.p1: εἰ καὶ ὁ ἔξω ἡμῶν ἄνθρωπος διαφθείρεται

greek_apodoses.q1: ἀλλ ὁ ἔσω ἡμῶν ἀνακαινοῦται ἡμέρᾳ καὶ ἡμέρᾳ

english:
p: (if the tent that is our earthly home is destroyed)
q: (we have a building from God)
notes: Though the NLT has "when" here, implying a Factual condition, it is more likely that Paul was leaving the condition open to the possibility of not occurring. Paul writes in more than one of his letters that the return of Christ is not known and some believers may not see death.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν ἡ ἐπίγειος ἡμῶν οἰκία τοῦ σκήνους καταλυθῇ

english:
p: (if we are beside ourselves)
q: (it is for God)
notes:
Greek: εἴτε (usually found in lists)
The conditionals in v.13 together describe an exhaustive set of situations.

greek_protases.p1: εἴτε γὰρ ἐξέστημεν

english:
p: (if we are in our right minds)
q: (it is for you)
notes:
εἴτε
See notes on 15:13a.

greek_protases.p1: εἴτε σωφρονοῦμεν

english:
p: (even though we once regarded Christ according to the flesh)
q: (we regard him thus no longer)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV: "even though"
NIV: "though"
NLT: no condtional
notes:
εἰ καὶ 'if indeed', 'even if', 'although'
This is a concessive conditional in which q is not dependent on the validity of p. Rather, p describes a situation which emphasizes q by virtue of its exceptional and/or unexpected nature. While it is grammatically a conditional in Greek, the reality of p means that most English translations use "though".

greek_protases.p1: εἰ καὶ ἐγνώκαμεν κατὰ σάρκα Χριστόν

english:
p: (Therefore, if anyone is in Christ)
q: (he is a new creation)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if anyone"
NLT: "anyone who"
notes:
εἴ τις 'if anyone'
Paul makes a general statement here that is not referencing a particular person nor a specific probability. He does, however say this to encourage the Corinthian church, whom he did consider to be "in Christ".

greek_protases.p1: ὥστε εἴ τις ἐν Χριστῷ

english:
p: (even if I made you grieve with my letter)
q: (I do not regret it)
english_translations:
ESV, NRSV, NIV: "even if"
NASB: "though"
NLT: no condtional
notes:
εἰ καὶ 'if indeed', 'even if', 'although'
There are 3 occurrences of εἰ και in verse 8. Boyer and Martin both analyze them as 3 separate concessive conditionals, in which  q is not dependent on the validity of p. Rather, p describes a situation which emphasizes q by virtue of its exceptional and/or unexpected nature.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ καὶ ἐλύπησα ὑμᾶς ἐν τῇ ἐπιστολῇ

english:
q: (I do not regret it)
p: (though I did regret it) (ESV)

p: (though I did regret it)
q: (...v.9 yet now I am happy) (NIV)
notes:
See note on v.8a 
There are two interpretations of this conditional; in both, εἰ καὶ is factual and so all 5 English translations use "though".
ESV, NRSV, and NLT interpret "though I did regret it" as contrasting with "I do not regret it". NLT expresses this well: "I am not sorry that I sent that severe letter to you, though I was sorry at first..." 
NRSV, NIV, and Martin interpret this conditional as spanning v.8-9, with conditional 8c being a parenthetical thought in the middle of this one. The NIV's division and punctuation of the clauses in these verses reflects this interpretation well: "Though I did regret it... (9) yet now I am happy..."

greek_protases.p1: εἰ καὶ μετεμελόμην

english:
q: (that letter grieved you)
p: (though only for a while)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV: "though only"
NIV: "but only"
NLT: no condtional or concessive
notes:
See note on v.8a 
In Greek, p comes in the middle of q. A word-for-word translation with p in square brackets is: "I see that that letter [though (if only)] for an hour] it grieved you(pl)."

english:
p: (although I wrote to you)
q: (it was not for the sake  of the one who did wrong, nor the one who suffered the wrong, but in order that your earnestness for us might be revealed to you in the sight of God)
english_translations:
ESV, RSV, NASB: "although"
NIV: "even though"
NLT: no conditional or concessive
notes:
εἰ καὶ 'if indeed', 'even if', 'although'
Because p is factual and is followed by a negative, most English translations use "although" here. NLT expresses the force of this construction well: "My purpose, then, was not to write about who did the wrong or who was wronged. I wrote to you so that in the sight of God you could see for yourselves how loyal you are to us."

greek_protases.p1: εἰ καὶ ἔγραψα ὑμῖν οὐχ ἕνεκεν τοῦ ἀδικήσαντος οὐδὲ ἕνεκεν τοῦ ἀδικηθέντος

greek_apodoses.q1: οὐχ ἕνεκεν τοῦ ἀδικήσαντος οὐδὲ ἕνεκεν τοῦ ἀδικηθέντος ἀλλ ἕνεκεν τοῦ φανερωθῆναι τὴν σπουδὴν ὑμῶν τὴν ὑπὲρ ἡμῶν πρὸς ὑμᾶς ἐνώπιον τοῦ θεοῦ

english:
p: (whatever boasts I made to him about you,
q: (I was not put to shame) (ESV)

p: (if in anything I have boasted to him about you,)
q: (I was not put to shame) (NASB)
english_translations:
NASB, NRSV: "if"
ESV: "whatever"
NIV, NLT: no conditional
notes:
εἴ τι 'if anything', 'whatever'
In p Paul admits that he boasted to Titus about the Corinthian believers and in q he states that this boasting was justified.

greek_protases.p1: εἴ τι αὐτῷ ὑπὲρ ὑμῶν κεκαύχημαι

english:
p: (if the readiness is there)
q: (it is acceptable)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: "if" (2nd person, inverted)
notes: Paul phrases this in a very general way, but he clearly intends to refer to the Corinthians' readiness to give and the acceptability of the gift. As a general principle the probility is neutral and the time is gnomic. But if you translate this as referring specifically to the Corinthians (as in NLT: "Whatever you give is acceptable, if you give it eagerly.") the probility will be likely and the time will be future.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ γὰρ ἡ προθυμία πρόκειται

english:
p: (if some Macedonians come with me and find that you are not ready)
q: (we would be humiliated--to say nothing of you-- for being so confident.
notes: Paul refers to this possible future circumstance and its outcome. P has two parts: 1) some Macedonians coming with Paul, and 2) the Macedonians finding that the Corinthians are not ready. (1) is likely to happen, but (2) is unlikely (or Paul hopes that it is unlikely).

greek_protases.p1: μή πως ἐὰν ἔλθωσιν σὺν ἐμοὶ Μακεδόνες καὶ εὕρωσιν ὑμᾶς ἀπαρασκευάστους

greek_apodoses.q1: καταισχυνθῶμεν ἡμεῖς ἵνα μὴ λέγωμεν ὑμεῖς ἐν τῇ ὑποστάσει ταύτῃ

english:
p: (if anyone is confident that he is Christ's)
q: (let him remind himself that just as he is Christ's, so also are we)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if" 
NLT: no conditional
notes:
P has εἴ τις 'if anyone' but Paul has specific people in mind (his opponents at Corinth), hence NRSV translates: "If you are confident that you belong to Christ, remind yourself of this, that just as you belong to Christ, so also do we."
.

greek_protases.p1: εἴ τις πέποιθεν ἑαυτῷ Χριστοῦ εἶναι

greek_apodoses.q1: τοῦτο λογιζέσθω πάλιν ἐφ ἑαυτοῦ ὅτι καθὼς αὐτὸς Χριστοῦ οὕτως καὶ ἡμεῖς

english:
p: (even if I boast a little too much of our authority...)
q: (I will not be ashamed)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "even if" 
NLT: no conditional
notes: Based on the context, this this can be interpreted as a concessive ("even if") conditional, in which q is not dependent on the truth of p.

greek_protases.p1: ἐάν τε γὰρ περισσότερόν τι καυχήσωμαι περὶ τῆς ἐξουσίας ἡμῶν ἧς ἔδωκεν ὁ κύριος εἰς οἰκοδομὴν καὶ οὐκ εἰς καθαίρεσιν ὑμῶν

english:
square brackets indicate material added in the ESV for naturalness in English:
p1: (if someone comes and proclaims another Jesus than the one we proclaimed,) 
p2: (or [if] you receive a different spirit from the one you received,)
p3: (or [if you accept] a different gospel from the one you accepted)
q: (you put up with it readily enough)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if" 
NLT: "even if" (inverted)
notes: There are three parts to p; although there is only one εἰ 'if' in Greek, most English translations repeat "if".

greek_protases.p1: εἰ μὲν γὰρ ὁ ἐρχόμενος ἄλλον Ἰησοῦν κηρύσσει ὃν οὐκ ἐκηρύξαμεν ἢ πνεῦμα ἕτερον λαμβάνετε ὃ οὐκ ἐλάβετε ἢ εὐαγγέλιον ἕτερον ὃ οὐκ ἐδέξασθε

english:
p: (even if I am unskilled in speaking)
q: (I am not so in knowledge)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB: "even if" 
NRSV, NIV, NLT: "I may (indeed) be... but"
notes:
εἰ δὲ καὶ 'even if'
Paul seems to be accepting the description of himself in p (perhaps ironically), but he states that even so he is certainly not lacking knowledge of the truth.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ καὶ ἰδιώτης τῷ λόγῳ

english:
q: (it is no surprise)
p: (if his servants, also, disguise themselves as servants of righteousness)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if" 
NLT: no conditional ("it is no wonder that...")
notes: Paul gives a harsh warning to the Corinthians and a rebuke to the decievers, linking them with the deceit of Satan himself.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ καὶ οἱ διάκονοι αὐτοῦ μετασχηματίζονται ὡς διάκονοι δικαιοσύνης

english:
p: (but even if you do [think me foolish])
q: (accept me as a fool, so that I too may boast a little)
english_translations:
ESV, NIV, NLT: "even if"
NASB, NRSV: "if"
notes: Greek has two expressions that include conditional particles: εἰ δὲ μή γε 'otherwise' and καν 'even if'. Most English translations express this as "But (even) if you do...".

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ μή γε

greek_apodoses.q1: κἂν ὡς ἄφρονα δέξασθέ με ἵνα κἀγὼ μικρόν τι καυχήσωμαι

english:
q: (you bear it) 
p: (if someone makes slaves of you, 
or [if someone] devours you, 
or [if someone] takes advantage of you, 
or [if someone] puts on airs, 
or [if someone] strikes you in the face)
english_translations:
ESV: "if someone" for first clause, "or" for next four
NASB: "if anyone" for first clause, "anyone" for next four
NRSV: "when someone" for first clause, "or" for next four
NIV: "even...anyone who" for first clause, "or" for next four
NLT: "when someone" only for first clause
notes: In the Greek, each clause listed in p is is introduced by its own ει τις 'if anyone'. Paul presents these as a list of ways in which the "false apostles" (v.13) have taken advantage of the Corinthian believers, so these are factual; note that NRSV and NLT translate p using "when".

greek_protases.p1: εἴ τις ὑμᾶς καταδουλοῖ εἴ τις κατεσθίει εἴ τις λαμβάνει εἴ τις ἐπαίρεται εἴ τις εἰς πρόσωπον ὑμᾶς δέρει

english:
p: (if I must boast)
q: (I will boast of the things that show my weakness)
notes: P is factual because Paul states in 12:1 that it is necessary for him to boast (even though this will do no good).

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ καυχᾶσθαι δεῖ

english:
p: (if I should wish to boast)
q: (I would not be a fool, for I would be speaking the truth)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NLT: "if"
NIV: "even if"
notes: P is non-factual because Paul does not want to boast. However, if he did boast about himself, it would be justified, unlike his opponents who likely were making false claims about themselves.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν γὰρ θελήσω καυχήσασθαι

greek_apodoses.q1: οὐκ ἔσομαι ἄφρων ἀλήθειαν γὰρ ἐρῶ

english:
q: (I was not at all inferior to these super apostles)
p: (even though I am nothing)
english_translations: ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV, NLT: "even though"
notes:
εἰ καὶ 'even if', 'even though'
This is a "concessive conditional," in which q is not dependent on the validity of p. Typically, in concessive clauses, p expressess an unexpectedor extreme idea which emphasizes the point made in q. This hyperbole serves to emphasize Christ’s working in Paul’s weakness.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ καὶ οὐδέν εἰμι

greek_apodoses.q1: οὐδὲν γὰρ ὑστέρησα τῶν ὑπερλίαν ἀποστόλων

english:
p: (if I love you more)
q: (am I to be loved less?)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: "even though"

greek_protases.p1: εἰ περισσοτέρως ὑμᾶς ἀγαπῶν

english:
p: (if I come again)
q: (I will not spare them)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV: "if"
NLT, NIV: no conditional
notes: In 13:1 Paul mentions his third visit to Corinth as if it has already been arranged, so it seems that Paul is using ἐὰν 'if' to mean "when" here. NIV translates this idea as "On my return..." and NLT as "that next time..."

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν ἔλθω εἰς τὸ πάλιν

english:
q: (Or do you not realize this about yourselves, that Jesus Christ is in you?)
p: (unless indeed you fail to meet the test!)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, RSV: "unless indeed"
NIV: "unless, of course"
NLT: "if not"
notes:
εἰ μήτι 'unless'
Q is in the form of a question, and precedes p (UBS Greek, ESV, NRSV all put the question mark after q; e.g. NRSV: Do you not realize that Jesus Christ is in you?)
In some languages, the combination of the inverted order q then p, plus the fact the q is a question may mean that this conditional needs to be restructured. One option is to repeat the final part of q: "Or do you not realize this about yourselves, that Jesus Christ is in you? He is certainly in you, if you have not failed the test."
The phrase "fail the test" is a translation of the Greek word ἀδόκιμοι which can also mean 'not genuine', 'discrdited', or 'not approved'. An alternative translation avoiding a double negative in p is: "Or do you not realize this about yourselves, that Jesus Christ is in you? He is certainly in you, if your faith is genuine."

greek_protases.p1: εἰ μήτι ἀδόκιμοί ἐστε

greek_apodoses.q1: ἢ οὐκ ἐπιγινώσκετε ἑαυτοὺς ὅτι Ἰησοῦς Χριστὸς ἐν ὑμῖν

english:
p: (but even if we or an angel from heaven should preach to you a gospel contrary to the one we preached to you)
q: (let him be accursed)
english_translations:
ESV, NRSV, NIV, NASB: "even if"
NLT: Let God’s curse fall on anyone, including us or even an angel from heaven, who..."
notes: καὶ ἐὰν expresses a concessive conditional. Paul is saying that anyone who preaches a different gospel should be cursed (implied: by God), and that this applies even to Paul or an angel from heaven.

greek_protases.p1: καὶ ἐὰν ἡμεῖς ἢ ἄγγελος ἐξ οὐρανοῦ εὐαγγελίζηται ὑμῖν παρ ὃ εὐηγγελισάμεθα ὑμῖν

english:
p: (if anyone is preaching to you a gospel contrary to the one you received)
q: (let him be accursed)
notes: Given that Paul wrote in v.6 that the Galatians "are turning to a different gospel" the situation in p is factual. Using a conditional sentence allows Paul to curse them indirectly rather than directly.

greek_protases.p1: εἴ τις ὑμᾶς εὐαγγελίζεται παρ ὃ παρελάβετε

english:
p: (if I were still trying to please man)
q: (I would not be a servant of God)
notes: We know that Paul is a servant of Christ, so p cannot be true

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ἔτι ἀνθρώποις ἤρεσκον

english:
p: (if you, though a Jew, live like a Gentile and not a Jew)
q: (how can you force the Gentiles to live like Jews)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV: "if"
NIV: no conditional
NLT: "since"
notes: Paul is reminding Peter that he had been living like a Gentile. The phrase “though a Jew” is embedded within p, and as Groff (2016) Translator’s Notes suggests, can be moved to the start of the sentence if this is more natural.

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ σὺ Ἰουδαῖος ὑπάρχων ἐθνικῶς καὶ οὐκ Ἰουδαϊκῶς ζῇς

english:
p: (but if, in our endeavor to be justified in Christ, we too were found to be sinners)
q: (is Christ then a servant of sin?)
notes: In p, Paul may be referring to the fact that the circumcision faction regarded him and his associates as no better than Gentile sinners, or he may mean that when he and other Jews put their faith purely in Christ, they realized that they too were sinners. The rhetorical question in q is meant to be answered "certainly not!"

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ ζητοῦντες δικαιωθῆναι ἐν Χριστῷ εὑρέθημεν καὶ αὐτοὶ ἁμαρτωλοί ἆρα Χριστὸς ἁμαρτίας διάκονος

english:
p: (for if I rebuild what I tore down)
q: (I prove myself to be a transgressor)
notes: The "building" which Paul describes himself rebuilding or tearing down is the Jewish law.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ γὰρ ἃ κατέλυσα ταῦτα πάλιν οἰκοδομῶ

english:
p: (for if righteousness were through the law)
q: (then Christ died for no purpose)
notes: There is no verb in p, so it is not possible to determine whether this is a first or second class conditional. The non-factual interpretation is the typical meaning of a second class conditional, and Paul has already made it clear that righteousness does not come through the law (see 2:16). First class conditionals are used to present situations as “true for the sake of argument”, which also applies here. The conditional reinforces Paul’s claim that righteousness does not come through the law, and it also functions to rebuke to those in the circumcision faction who insist that keeping the law is still necessary.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ γὰρ διὰ νόμου δικαιοσύνη

english:
NRSV:
Did you experience so much for nothing?
p: (- if it really was for nothing)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB: "if indeed"
NRSV, NIV: "if... really"
NLT: "Surely it was not in vain, was it?"
notes:
Greek: εἴ γε καὶ 'if indeed'
There is no cause-consequence or evidence-conclusion relation between p and q here. Instead, p questions the accuracy of the suggestion that what they experienced or suffered was "for nothing" (ESV "in vain").

greek_protases.p1: εἴ γε καὶ εἰκῇ

english:
p: (for if inheritance comes by the law)
q: (it no longer comes by promise)
notes: The argument here rests on the assumption that inheritence can either come by the law or by the promise, but not by both. The situation stated in q, that the inheritence "no longer comes by promise" is negated in 3:18b: "but God gave it to Abraham by a promise." This shows that the statement "the inheritence comes by the law," that is assumed for the sake of argument in p, is false.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ γὰρ ἐκ νόμου ἡ κληρονομία

english:
p: (for if a law had been given that could give life)
q: (then righteousness would indeed be by the law)
notes: Paul has already stated that righteousness does not come through the Jewish law (2:16) but by faith (3:11), so the premise in p is false: there is no law that can give life.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ γὰρ ἐδόθη νόμος ὁ δυνάμενος ζῳοποιῆσαι

greek_apodoses.q1: ὄντως ἐκ νόμου ἂν ἦν ἡ δικαιοσύνη

english:
p: (and if you are Christ's)
q: (then you are Abraham's offspring, heirs according to promise)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: "now that you belong to Christ"
notes: Paul has just stated (3:28) "you are all one in Christ Jesus," so it is clear that "you are Christ's" is factual. The English connective then translates the Greek connective ἄρα which expresses a consequence or logical conclusion.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ ὑμεῖς Χριστοῦ

greek_apodoses.q1: ἄρα τοῦ Ἀβραὰμ σπέρμα ἐστέ κατ ἐπαγγελίαν κληρονόμοι

english:
p: (and if a son)
q: (then [also] an heir through God)
notes: Paul has just stated "you are no longer a slave, but a son," so it is clear that p is factual. The word also has been added to the ESV translation here to express the sense of καὶ in Greek (see NIV, NRSV, NET).

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ υἱός

english:
p: (if possible)
q: (you would have gouged out your eyes and given them to me)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, RSV, NIV, NLT: "if"
NRSV: "had it been possible"
notes: Like other "if possible" constructions, it signals the unlikeliness (or in this case, impossibility) of the proposition. However in this case, there is a clear q that depends on p for its fulfilment.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δυνατὸν

greek_apodoses.q1: τοὺς ὀφθαλμοὺς ὑμῶν ἐξορύξαντες ἐδώκατέ μοι

english:
p: (if you accept circumcision)
q: (Christ will be of no advantage to you)
notes: For a Gentile to become circumcised is a sign that they were choosing the law over Christ's sacrifice. The 'you' here is plural; probably some of Paul's audience had accepted circumcision and some were considering it.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν περιτέμνησθε

english:
NASB:
p: (if I still preach circumcision)
q1: (why am I still persecuted?)
q2: (then teh stumbling block of the cross has been abolished)
notes: The question "Why am I still being persecuted?" indicates that Paul is being persecuted. Paul assumes that his audience knows that the people who are persecuting him are those who are teaching that circumcision is necessary (first mentioned in 1:7). P has scope over the next clause (introduced by ἄρα 'then') but most English translations (except NASB) translate this with "In that case" or something similar, as a way to refer back to "if I still preach circumcision".

greek_protases.p1: ἐγὼ δέ ἀδελφοί εἰ περιτομὴν ἔτι κηρύσσω

greek_apodoses.q2: ἄρα κατήργηται τὸ σκάνδαλον τοῦ σταυροῦ

english:
p: (but if you bite and devour one another)
q: (watch out that you are consumed by one another)
notes: Paul is probably thinking of the divisions and fighting caused by the false teachers mentioned earlier.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ ἀλλήλους δάκνετε καὶ κατεσθίετε

english:
p: (but if you are led by the Spirit)
q: (you are not under the law)
notes: Paul has instructed his readers to "walk by the Spirit" in v.16, so this is something that is likely but not certain (some people may not follow this instruction).

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ πνεύματι ἄγεσθε

english:
p: (if we live by the Spirit)
q: (let us also keep in step with the Spirit)
notes: ζῶμεν ‘we live’ probably describes how the Spirit is the source of life for a believer, and so the conditional is factual. An alternative interpretation is that living by the Spirit is something that the believer chooses to do, just like “walk by the Spirit” in v.16, in which case p is very likely rather than factual.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ζῶμεν πνεύματι

english:
p: (if anyone is caught in transgression)
q: (you who are spiritual should restore him in a spirit of gentleness)
english_translations:
ESV, NRSV, NIV, NLT: "if"
NASB: "even if"
notes: Paul is not referring to a specific person. NASB "even if" treas the construction ἐὰν καὶ as a concessive conditional

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν καὶ προλημφθῇ ἄνθρωπος ἔν τινι παραπτώματι

greek_apodoses.q1: ὑμεῖς οἱ πνευματικοὶ καταρτίζετε τὸν τοιοῦτον ἐν πνεύματι πραΰτητος

english:
p: (for if anyone thinks he is something, when he is nothing)
q: (he deceives himself)
notes: This may be a saying or proverb meant to warn all the Galatian believers not to become proud; in this case the probility is Neutral and the illocutionary force is Warn.. Alternatively, Paul may have specific people in mind. The Greek expression δοκεῖ τις εἶναί τι ‘thinks anyone to be something’ resembles the words that Paul used in Gal 2:6 to describe influential leaders of the church in Jerusalem, and probably specifically James (see Gal 2:12). This would make the probability Factual (as in 1Co 8:2) and the illocutionary force Rebuke.Possibly both of these interpretations could be valid.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ γὰρ δοκεῖ τις εἶναί τι μηδὲν ὤν

notes: Implied conditional; the Greek has a participle verb μὴ ἐκλυόμενοι ‘not giving up’ rather than a conditional particle.

greek_protases.p1: μὴ ἐκλυόμενοι

english:
NASB:
q: (you did not learn Christ in this way)
p: (if indeed you have heard Him and have been taught in Him, just as truth is in Jesus...)
english_translations:
ESV: "assuming"
NASB: "if indeed"
NRSV: "For surely"
NIV: "when"
NLT: "Since" (see Note)
notes:
Greek: εἴ γε 'if indeed'
Most translations link the conditional in v.21 to the exclamation in v.20. NLT, however, links it to the (implied) command in v.22:
21 Since you have heard about Jesus and have learned the truth that comes from him, 22 throw off your old sinful nature and your former way of life, which is corrupted by lust and deception.
If εἴ γε is connected to v.20, then it either has a genuine conditional meaning (as in NASB) or a non-conditional meaning (as in ESV, NRSV, NIV - see note on Eph 3:2 below). If εἴ γε is connected to v.22, then it has a factual conditional meaning (as in NLT).

greek_protases.p1: εἴ γε αὐτὸν ἠκούσατε καὶ ἐν αὐτῷ ἐδιδάχθητε

greek_apodoses.q1: ὑμεῖς δὲ οὐχ οὕτως ἐμάθετε τὸν Χριστόν

english:
p: (if I am to live in the flesh)
q: (that means fruitful labour for me)
Or
p: (if to live means fruitful work for me)
q: (then I don’t know what to choose)
notes:
There are differences of opinion concerning the scope of the conditional here. In most English translations p = 22a and q = 22b (and 22c is not part of the conditional sentence): e.g. NRSV p [If I am to live in the flesh,] q [that means fruitful labor for me;] and I do not know which I prefer.
In most French translations p = 22a+b and q = 22c: But p [if to live means fruitful work for me] q [then I don’t know what to choose].
If p is 22a only, then the condition is hypothetical with a neutral probability (Paul might continue to live, but it is possible that he will die), but if p is 22a+b, then the condition is factual (Paul knows that by living he can do fruitful work).

greek_protases.p1or: εἰ δὲ τὸ ζῆν ἐν σαρκί
greek_protases.p2or: εἰ δὲ τὸ ζῆν ἐν σαρκί τοῦτό μοι καρπὸς ἔργου

english:
NASB:
p: (if there is any encouragement in Christ, if there is any consolation of love, if there is any fellowship of the Spirit, if any affection and compassion)
q: (make my joy complete by being of the same mind, maintaining the same love, united in spirit, intent on one purpose)
english_translations:
ESV, RSV, NIV, NASB: "if"
NLT: each clause in p is expressed as a rhetorical question
notes: In Greek, εἴ repeated before each "any" in v.1 (see NASB and NIV).

greek_protases.p1: Εἴ τις οὖν παράκλησις ἐν Χριστῷ εἴ τι παραμύθιον ἀγάπης εἴ τις κοινωνία πνεύματος εἴ τις σπλάγχνα καὶ οἰκτιρμοί

greek_apodoses.q1: πληρώσατέ μου τὴν χαρὰν ἵνα τὸ αὐτὸ φρονῆτε τὴν αὐτὴν ἀγάπην ἔχοντες σύμψυχοι τὸ ἓν φρονοῦντες

english:
p: (even if I am to be poured out as a drink offering upon the sacrificial offering of your faith)
q: (I am glad and rejoice with you all)
english_translations: ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV, NLT: "even if"
notes: Greek εἰ καὶ 'even if'; this is a "concessive conditional"; q is asserted as true, and p describes a situation which emphasizes q by virtue of its exceptional nature.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ καὶ σπένδομαι ἐπὶ τῇ θυσίᾳ καὶ λειτουργίᾳ τῆς πίστεως ὑμῶν

english:
p: (if anyone else thinks he has reason for confidence in the flesh)
q: (I have more)
notes: This is a speech act conditional - q is always true, but is only relevant if p is true. However, we know that p is actually true, because Paul has referred in v.2-3 to those who claimed that it was necessary to be circumcised - in other words, those who had "confidence in the flesh".

greek_protases.p1: Εἴ τις δοκεῖ ἄλλος πεποιθέναι ἐν σαρκί

english:
p: (if in anything you think otherwise)
q: (God will reveal that also to you)
notes: We have listed the probability as neutral becuase Paul is writing to "all the saints in Christ Jesus who are in Philippi", which includes those who are "mature" as well as those who "think differently".

greek_protases.p1: καὶ εἴ τι ἑτέρως φρονεῖτε

greek_apodoses.q1: καὶ τοῦτο ὁ θεὸς ὑμῖν ἀποκαλύψει

english:
p: (if there is any excellence, if there is anything worthy of praise)
q: (think about these things)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: expressed as a statment
notes: The two clauses in p are either the last two items in a list of eight things that Paul commands his readers to think about (as in ESV, NASB and NRSV), or they provide a summary and evaluation of the previous six things (as in NIV and NLT).

greek_protases.p1: εἴ τις ἀρετὴ καὶ εἴ τις ἔπαινος

english:
q: v.22 (he has now reconciled in his body of flesh by his death, in order to present you holy and blameless and above reproach before him)
p: v.23 (if indeed you continue in the faith, stable and steadfast, not shifting from the hope of the gospel that you heard)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB: "if indeed"
NRSV: "provided that"
NIV: "if"
NLT: "But you must"
notes:
ει γε 'if indeed'
Elliot: "The particle γε performs its usual emphatic function, strengthening the word to which it is attached, and stresses the conditional nature of the concept."

greek_protases.p1: εἴ γε ἐπιμένετε τῇ πίστει τεθεμελιωμένοι καὶ ἑδραῖοι καὶ μὴ μετακινούμενοι ἀπὸ τῆς ἐλπίδος τοῦ εὐαγγελίου οὗ ἠκούσατε

greek_apodoses.q1: νυνὶ δὲ ἀποκατηλλάγητε ἐν τῷ σώματι τῆς σαρκὸς αὐτοῦ διὰ τοῦ θανάτου παραστῆσαι ὑμᾶς ἁγίους καὶ ἀμώμους καὶ ἀνεγκλήτους κατενώπιον αὐτοῦ

english:
p: (for though I am absent in body)
q: (yet I am with you in spirit)
english_translations:
ESV, NRSV, NIV, NLT: "though"
NASB: "even though"
notes: εἰ καὶ 'even if'; This is a "concessive conditional," in which q is not dependent on the validity of p. In fact, there is a strong contrast between p and q here, indicated by the connective ἀλλὰ 'but' (ESV/NRSV 'yet', NASB 'nevertheless'). Paul highlights the contrast between "in body" and "in spirit" by fronting these before the verb phrases 'I am absent' and "I am with you" respectively.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ γὰρ καὶ τῇ σαρκὶ ἄπειμι

greek_apodoses.q1: ἀλλὰ τῷ πνεύματι σὺν ὑμῖν εἰμι

english:
p: (if with Christ you died to the elemental spirits of the world)
q: (why, as if you were still alive in the world, do you submit to regulations?)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV: "if"
NIV: "since"
NLT: No conditional - statement
notes:
It is true that we have died with Christ (2:11-12) and are not controlled by these "elementary principles of the world" (NASB; see also Gal 4:3-9), and this underlies NIV "since" and NLT "You have died with Christ..."
The Greek has an aorist verb in p: ἀπεθάνετε 'you(pl) died'; ESV, NRSV and NIV translate this as a simple past "you died" but NASB, NLT and NET translate this as a present perfect "you have died". Although this is something that happened in the past, it has ongoing, present time consequences.

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ ἀπεθάνετε σὺν Χριστῷ ἀπὸ τῶν στοιχείων τοῦ κόσμου

greek_apodoses.q1: τί ὡς ζῶντες ἐν κόσμῳ δογματίζεσθε

english:
p: (if then you have been raised with Christ)
q: (seek the things that are above, where Christ is, seated at the right hand of God)
notes:
It is also true that we have been raised with Christ (2:12-13), and this underlies NIV and NLT "since".
The Greek has an aorist verb in p: συνηγέρθητε 'you(pl) were raised with'. Unlike in 2:20, all the English versions mentioned translate this as a present perfect "you have been raised with" focusing on the present time consequences of this.

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ οὖν συνηγέρθητε τῷ Χριστῷ

greek_apodoses.q1: τὰ ἄνω ζητεῖτε οὗ ὁ Χριστός ἐστιν ἐν δεξιᾷ τοῦ θεοῦ καθήμενος

english:
NIV:
q: (bear with each other and forgive one another)
q: (if any of you has a grievance against someone)
notes:
ἐάν τις 'if anyone'
NIV follows the Greek in putting the whole of q before p. ESV, NRSV and NLT split up the two sections of q so that p ("if anyone has a complaint against another") precedes "forgive each other" (NRSV); this makes "Bear with one another" no longer part of q. However, it is likely that "Bear with one another and forgive each other" together constitute q (in the Greek they both come before p).

greek_protases.p1: ἐάν τις πρός τινα ἔχῃ μομφήν

english:
p: (if he comes to you)
q: (welcome him)

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν ἔλθῃ πρὸς ὑμᾶς

english:
q: (for now we live)
p: (if you are standing fast in the Lord)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV: "if"
NIV: "since"
NLT: untranslated/paraphrased
notes: In Greek this is a mixed conditional (εαν + indicative).

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν ὑμεῖς στήκετε ἐν κυρίῳ

english:
NLT:
p: (For since we believe that Jesus died and was raised to life again)
