q: (we also believe that when Jesus returns, God will bring back with him the believers who have died)
english_translations:
ESV, NRSV, NLT: "since"
NASB: "if"
NIV: p and q are statements joined by "and so"
notes: There is an understood "we believe" in q (that the NLT makes explicit). Paul is not saying that there is a cause-effect relationship between what we believe and what God will do, (i.e. if we believe that Jesus died and was raised, then God will bring with him those who have died). Rather, Paul is expressing that if we believe that Jesus died and was raised, then we also believe that God will bring with him those who have died.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ γὰρ πιστεύομεν ὅτι Ἰησοῦς ἀπέθανεν καὶ ἀνέστη

greek_apodoses.q1: οὕτως καὶ ὁ θεὸς τοὺς κοιμηθέντας διὰ τοῦ Ἰησοῦ ἄξει σὺν αὐτῷ

english:
q: (for that day will not come)
p: (unless the rebellion comes first, and the man of lawlessness is revealed, the son of destruction...)
notes:
ἐὰν μὴ 'unless'
Q 'that day will not come' is not in the Greek, but is understood; most translations make this explicit. (Note: 'that day' refers to 'the day of the Lord' mentioned at the end of v.2.)
Paraphrase (to avoid multiple negatives in languages without 'unless' or 'except'): The day of the Lord will come only if the rebellion (against God) comes first, and the man of lawlessness is revealed...

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν μὴ ἔλθῃ ἡ ἀποστασία πρῶτον καὶ ἀποκαλυφθῇ ὁ ἄνθρωπος τῆς ἀνομίας

english:
p: (if anyone is not willing to work)
q: (let him not eat)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB: "if anyone"
NRSV: "anyone"
NIV: "the one who"
NLT: "those"

greek_protases.p1: εἴ τις οὐ θέλει ἐργάζεσθαι

english:
p: (if anyone does not obey what we say in this letter)
q: (take note of that person, and have nothing to do with him, that he may be ashamed)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB: "if anyone"
NRSV, NLT: "those who"
NIV: "anyone who"

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ δέ τις οὐχ ὑπακούει τῷ λόγῳ ἡμῶν διὰ τῆς ἐπιστολῆς

greek_apodoses.q1: τοῦτον σημειοῦσθε μὴ συναναμίγνυσθαι αὐτῷ ἵνα ἐντραπῇ

english:
q: (we know that the law is good)
p: (if one uses it lawfully)
notes:
The main point here is in q: the law is good; p qualifies this. There is a pun here in the use of νόμος 'law' and νομίμως 'lawfully'; some English translations use other expressions: 'legitimately' (NRSV), 'properly' (NIV), 'correctly' (NLT). 
If a conditional would be misleading or unnatural in translation (particularly if it is unnatural for q to precede p) this could be translated in other ways, for example using 'when' (as the NLT does), or expressions such as "so long as / provided that / assuming that it is used lawfully".

greek_protases.p1: ἐάν τις αὐτῷ νομίμως χρῆται

english:
q: (she will be saved through childbearing)
p: (if they continue in faith and love and holiness, with self-control)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NIV: "if"
NRSV: "provided they..." 
NLT: "assuming they..."
notes: The time reference depends on the exegesis of this puzzling and controversial text. It seems to be an extension of the allusion to Genesis 3 from the previous verses (which explains the singular pronoun in 15a).The following universal statement brings God's salvation to that curse upon women in general (hence the switch to the plural pronoun in 15b).

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν μείνωσιν ἐν πίστει καὶ ἀγάπῃ καὶ ἁγιασμῷ μετὰ σωφροσύνης

english:
p: (If anyone aspires to the office of overseer)
q: (he desires a noble task)
english_translations:
ESV: "if anyone"
NASB: "if any man"
NRSV, NIV: "whoever"
NLT: "if someone"
notes: Here and in v.5, Paul is making a general statement about people who aspire to be leaers in the church.

greek_protases.p1: εἴ τις ἐπισκοπῆς ὀρέγεται

english:
p: (if someone does not know how to manage his own household) 
q: (how will he care for God’s church?)
english_translations:
ESV, NRSV: "if someone"
NASB, NLT: "if a man"
NIV: "if anyone"
notes: See note on 1Ti 3:1.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δέ τις τοῦ ἰδίου οἴκου προστῆναι οὐκ οἶδεν

english:
p: (if I delay)
q: ([I write] so that you may know how one ought to behave in the household of God)
Square brackets added to supply implied information
english_translations:
ESV, NRSV, NIV, NLT: "if"
NASB: "in case"
notes: This is a speech act conditional, that is, q is true regardless of p (even if Paul is not delayed, he is still writing these instructions). However, if Paul delays, the fact that he is writing so that Timothy will know these things will be relevant, as in that case Paul won't be present to give this instruction in person. (P "if I delay" does not state the condition that will make q true but rather the situation that will make q relevant.) In Greek, q is introduced by ἵνα 'so that' and "I write" is implied.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν δὲ βραδύνω

greek_apodoses.q1: ἵνα εἰδῇς πῶς δεῖ ἐν οἴκῳ θεοῦ ἀναστρέφεσθαι ἥτις ἐστὶν ἐκκλησία θεοῦ ζῶντος στῦλος καὶ ἑδραίωμα τῆς ἀληθείας

english:
p: (But if a widow has children or grandchildren)
q: (let them first learn to show godliness to their own household and to make some return to their parents)
notes: Paul is making a general statement about the responsibilities of children and grandchildren of widows.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δέ τις χήρα τέκνα ἢ ἔκγονα ἔχει

greek_apodoses.q1: μανθανέτωσαν πρῶτον τὸν ἴδιον οἶκον εὐσεβεῖν καὶ ἀμοιβὰς ἀποδιδόναι τοῖς προγόνοις

english:
p: (if anyone does not provide for his relatives, and especially for members of his household)
q: (he has denied the faith and is worse than an unbeliever)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB: "if anyone"
NRSV: "whoever"
NIV: "anyone who"
NLT: "those who"
notes: This conditional buolds on v.4 and applies the same principal moe generally.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δέ τις τῶν ἰδίων καὶ μάλιστα οἰκείων οὐ προνοεῖ

greek_apodoses.q1: τὴν πίστιν ἤρνηται καὶ ἔστιν ἀπίστου χείρων

english:
q: (Let a widow be enrolled)
p1: (if she is not less than sixty years of age)
p2: (if she has been the wife of one husband)
p3: (if she has a reputation for good deeds)
p5-8 are either an elaboration of 'good deeds' or additional conditions
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV:  "if"
NIV: "unless"
NLT relative clause ("who... must be")
notes:
The syntax of vs.9-10 is confusing. It seems that there are eight requirements for a widow to be put on the list, but the first three are not expressed with a conditional marker ('if she is not' or 'unless she' has been supplied in most English translations). 
In the first condition in v.9, μὴ 'not' combines with ἐλάττων 'less than'. In some languages this verse may be more naturally/clearly rephrased as an affirmative statement: 'A widow is to be put on the list only if she is at least sixty years old / over sixty years old / sixty years old or more.'
The five conditions in v.10 expressed with ει can be understood in two ways. NRSV, ESV, NIV, and Mounce (2000) treat these as an elaboration of the third requisite "having a reputation for good deeds"; in this view, the five conditional clauses in v10 describe five examples of good deeds. NASB translates the five conditions in v.10 as continuing the list started in v.9.

greek_protases.p1: μὴ ἔλαττον ἐτῶν ἑξήκοντα γεγονυῖα ἑνὸς ἀνδρὸς γυνή ἐν ἔργοις καλοῖς μαρτυρουμένη εἰ ἐτεκνοτρόφησεν εἰ ἐξενοδόχησεν εἰ ἁγίων πόδας ἔνιψεν εἰ θλιβομένοις ἐπήρκεσεν εἰ παντὶ ἔργῳ ἀγαθῷ ἐπηκολούθησεν

english:
p: (If any believing woman has relatives who are widows)
q: (let her care for them)
notes: Translator's Notes claims that Paul knew this to be the case, which would make this a factual condition.

greek_protases.p1: εἴ τις πιστὴ ἔχει χήρας

english:
ESV:
q: (Do not admit a charge against an elder)
p: (except on the evidence of two or three witnesses)
NIV:
q: (do not entertain an accusation against an elder)
p: (unless it is brought by two or three witnesses)
notes:
Greek: εἰ μὴ 'if not' is modified by ἐκτὸς 'except'. This phrase is only used two other times and both those cases are conditional (1 Cor 14:5b; 15:2b). 
Paraphrase (to avoid multiple negatives in languages without 'unless' or 'except'): "Listen to/Consider an accusation against an elder only if two or three witnesses confirm it."

greek_protases.p1: κατὰ πρεσβυτέρου κατηγορίαν μὴ παραδέχου

greek_apodoses.q1: ἐκτὸς εἰ μὴ ἐπὶ δύο ἢ τριῶν μαρτύρων

english:
p: (If anyone teaches a different doctrine and does not agree with the sound words of our Lord Jesus Christ and the teaching that accords with godliness)
q: (he is puffed up with conceit and understands nothing)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NIV: "if anyone"
NRSV: "those who" 
NLT: "some people may..."
notes: Translator's Notes claims that Paul knew that there were some people who were teaching false doctrines, making this a factual condition, and says that it could be translated "Whoever..." This reading underlies the use of "those who" in the NRSV. However, the use of a conditional allows Paul to talk about (and to) these people in an indirect, less confrontational way.

greek_protases.p1: εἴ τις ἑτεροδιδασκαλεῖ καὶ μὴ προσέρχεται ὑγιαίνουσι λόγοις τοῖς τοῦ κυρίου ἡμῶν Ἰησοῦ Χριστοῦ καὶ τῇ κατ εὐσέβειαν διδασκαλίᾳ

english:
p: (for since the message declared by angels proved to be reliable, and every transgression or disobedience received just retribution)
q: (how shall we escape if we neglect such a great salvation?)
english_translations:
ESV, NIV: "since"
NASB, NRSV: "for if"
NLT: non-conditional statement
notes: An argument is made by using a rhetorical question (implied response of "we can't") which demands action.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ γὰρ ὁ δι ἀγγέλων λαληθεὶς λόγος ἐγένετο βέβαιος καὶ πᾶσα παράβασις καὶ παρακοὴ ἔλαβεν ἔνδικον μισθαποδοσίαν

greek_apodoses.q1: πῶς ἡμεῖς ἐκφευξόμεθα τηλικαύτης ἀμελήσαντες σωτηρίας

english:
q: (and we are his house)
p: (if indeed we hold fast our confidence and our boasting in our hope)
notes:
Greek: ἐάν[περ]  'if indeed'.
Q expresses a promise; p puts a limit on q, but more importantly it provides an implied exhortation to do p.

greek_protases.p1: τὴν παρρησίαν καὶ τὸ καύχημα τῆς ἐλπίδος κατάσχωμεν

english:
p: today (if you hear his voice)
q: (do not harden your hearts as in the rebellion, on the day of testing in the wilderness, where your fathers put me to the test and saw my works for forty years)
notes: The command lies in q. The probability of this conditional is tricky because when people harden their hearts, they become deaf to God speaking to them. So, despite God speaking, people may or may not hear him.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν τῆς φωνῆς αὐτοῦ ἀκούσητε

greek_apodoses.q1: μὴ σκληρύνητε τὰς καρδίας ὑμῶν ὡς ἐν τῷ παραπικρασμῷ κατὰ τὴν ἡμέραν τοῦ πειρασμοῦ ἐν τῇ ἐρήμῳ οὗ ἐπείρασαν οἱ πατέρες ὑμῶν ἐν δοκιμασίᾳ καὶ εἶδον τὰ ἔργα μου τεσσεράκοντα ἔτη

english:
q: (we have come to share in Christ)
p: (if indeed we hold our original confidence firm to the end)
notes: Greek: ἐάνπερ 'if indeed'; this connective is found only in Hebrews in the NT - here, in 6:3, and in 3:6 in certain manuscripts.

greek_protases.p1: ἐάνπερ τὴν ἀρχὴν τῆς ὑποστάσεως μέχρι τέλους

english:
p: (today if you hear his voice)
q: (do not harden your hearts as in the rebellion)
notes: See note at 3:7.

greek_protases.p1: Σήμερον ἐὰν τῆς φωνῆς αὐτοῦ ἀκούσητε

greek_apodoses.q1: Μὴ σκληρύνητε τὰς καρδίας ὑμῶν ὡς ἐν τῷ παραπικρασμῷ

english:
p: (today if you hear his voice)
q: (do not harden your hearts as in the rebellion))
notes: See note at 3:7.

greek_protases.p1: Σήμερον ἐὰν τῆς φωνῆς αὐτοῦ ἀκούσητε

english:
p: (for if Joshua had given them rest)
q: (God would not have spoken of another day later on)
notes: Elliot mentions that αν has been ommitted in some manuscripts, which is rare for non-factuals.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ γὰρ αὐτοὺς Ἰησοῦς κατέπαυσεν

greek_apodoses.q1: οὐκ ἂν περὶ ἄλλης ἐλάλει μετὰ ταῦτα ἡμέρας

english:
q: (this we will do)
p: (if God permits)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV: "if"
NIV: "God permitting" 
NLT: "God willing"

greek_protases.p1: ἐάνπερ ἐπιτρέπῃ ὁ θεός

english:
q: (yet in your case, beloved, we feel sure of better things—things that belong to salvation)
p: (though we speak this way)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV: "though"
NRSV, NIV, NLT: "even though"
notes:
Greek: εἰ καὶ 'if indeed, even though'; this is a "concessive conditional".
The writer of Hebrews is quite harsh towards the audience in this section. He is softening his criticisms by saying [even though] we speak like this, we expect good things for you. 
The NASB keeps the inverted order q before p, while the ESV, NRSV, NIV, and NLT put p before q (the usual order).

greek_protases.p1: εἰ καὶ οὕτως λαλοῦμεν

greek_apodoses.q1: Πεπείσμεθα δὲ περὶ ὑμῶν ἀγαπητοί τὰ κρείσσονα καὶ ἐχόμενα σωτηρίας

english:
p: (if perfection had been attainable through the Levitical priesthood (for under it the people received the law))
q: (what further need would there have been for another priest to arise after the order of Melchizedek, rather than one named after the order of Aaron?)

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ μὲν οὖν τελείωσις διὰ τῆς Λευιτικῆς ἱερωσύνης ἦν ὁ λαὸς γὰρ ἐπ αὐτῆς νενομοθέτηται

greek_apodoses.q1: τίς ἔτι χρεία κατὰ τὴν τάξιν Μελχισέδεκ ἕτερον ἀνίστασθαι ἱερέα καὶ οὐ κατὰ τὴν τάξιν Ἀαρὼν λέγεσθαι

english:
q: (this becomes even more evident)
p: (if/when another priest arises in the likeness of Melchizedek...)
notes: "This" in q refers to v.14; p is a reference to Jesus (see v.16 and following).

greek_protases.p1: εἰ κατὰ τὴν ὁμοιότητα Μελχισέδεκ ἀνίσταται ἱερεὺς ἕτερος

english:
p: (if he were on earth)
q: (he would not be a priest at all)

greek_protases.p1: εἰ μὲν οὖν ἦν ἐπὶ γῆς

english:
p: (for if that first covenant had been faultless)
q: (there would have been no occasion to look for a second)

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ γὰρ ἡ πρώτη ἐκείνη ἦν ἄμεμπτος

english:
p: (if the blood of goats and bulls, and the sprinkling of defiled persons with the ashes of a heifer, sanctify for the purification of flesh)
q: (how much more will the blood of Christ, who through the eternal Spirit offered himself without blemish to God, purify our conscience from dead works to serve a living God)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV: "if"
NIV: p (v.13) is a statement, q (v.14) has "then"
NLT: non-conditional

greek_protases.p1: εἰ γὰρ τὸ αἷμα τράγων καὶ ταύρων καὶ σποδὸς δαμάλεως ῥαντίζουσα τοὺς κεκοινωμένους ἁγιάζει πρὸς τὴν τῆς σαρκὸς καθαρότητα

greek_apodoses.q1: πόσῳ μᾶλλον τὸ αἷμα τοῦ Χριστοῦ ὃς διὰ πνεύματος αἰωνίου ἑαυτὸν προσήνεγκεν ἄμωμον τῷ θεῷ καθαριεῖ τὴν συνείδησιν ἡμῶν

english:
p: (if he shrinks back)
q: (my soul has no pleasure in him)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB: "if"
NRSV, NLT: "anyone who"
NIV:  "the one who"

greek_protases.p1: καὶ ἐὰν ὑποστείληται

greek_apodoses.q1: οὐκ εὐδοκεῖ ἡ ψυχή μου ἐν αὐτῷ

english:
p: (if they had been thinking of that land from which they had gone out)
q: (they would have had an opportunity to return)
notes: P is proven to be non-factual by v.16.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ μὲν ἐκείνης μνημονεύουσιν ἀφ ἧς ἐξέβησαν

english:
p: (if you are left without discipline, in which all have participated)
q: (then you are illegitimate children and not sons)

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ χωρίς ἐστε παιδείας ἧς μέτοχοι γεγόνασι πάντες

greek_apodoses.q1: ἄρα νόθοι καὶ οὐχ υἱοί ἐστε

english:
p: (if even a beast touches the mountain)
q: (it shall be stoned)
notes:
Greek: κἂν
This is not a typical "concessive conditional." The meaning is not that if an animal even touches (as opposed to, say, stands on) the mountain, it will be stoned; rather, the meaning is that any living being, even an animal (as opposed to a human), will be stoned if it touches the mountain.

greek_protases.p1: Κἂν θηρίον θίγῃ τοῦ ὄρους

english:
p: (if they did not escape when they refused him who warned them on earth)
q: (much less will we escape if we reject him who warns from heaven)

greek_protases.p1: εἰ γὰρ ἐκεῖνοι οὐκ ἐξέφυγον ἐπὶ γῆς παραιτησάμενοι τὸν χρηματίζοντα

greek_apodoses.q1: πολὺ μᾶλλον ἡμεῖς οἱ τὸν ἀπ οὐρανῶν ἀποστρεφόμενοι

english:
NASB (following Greek):
q: (with whom...)
p: (if he comes soon)
q: (...I shall see you...)
notes:
Timothy had been imprisioned but was now free (13:23a). We do not know the outcome of this conditional.
In the Greek, p occurs in the middle of q; most English translations put p before q (NRSV, NIV, NLT) or after q (ESV).

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν τάχιον ἔρχηται

english:
p: (if any of you lacks wisdom)
q: (let him ask God, who gives generously to all without reproach)

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ δέ τις ὑμῶν λείπεται σοφίας

greek_apodoses.q1: αἰτείτω παρὰ τοῦ διδόντος θεοῦ πᾶσιν ἁπλῶς καὶ μὴ ὀνειδίζοντος καὶ δοθήσεται αὐτῷ

english:
p: (for if anyone is a hearer of the word and not a doer)
q: (he is like a man who looks intently at his natural face in the mirror. For he looks at himself and goes away and at once forgets what he was like)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB: "if anyone"
NRSV: "if any"
NIV: "anyone who"
NLT: "if you"

greek_protases.p1: εἴ τις ἀκροατὴς λόγου ἐστὶν καὶ οὐ ποιητής

greek_apodoses.q1: οὗτος ἔοικεν ἀνδρὶ κατανοοῦντι τὸ πρόσωπον τῆς γενέσεως αὐτοῦ ἐν ἐσόπτρῳ

english:
ESV:
p: (if anyone thinks he is religious and does not bridle his tongue but deceives his heart)
q: (this person's religion is worthless)
NIV:
p: (those who consider themselves religious and yet do not keep a tight rein on their tongues)
q: (deceive themselves, and their religion is worthless)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB: "if anyone"
NRSV: "if any"
NIV: "those who"
NLT: "if you"
notes:
In Greek, the verbs 'bridle' (or 'control') and 'deceive' are participle verb forms. ESV, NASB and NRSV include both of these participle verbs in p; NIV and NLT include 'deceive' in q (NLT: [If you claim to be religious but don’t control your tongue,]p [you are fooling yourself, and your religion is worthless.]q)
This idea of controlling the tongue is continued in 3:1-12.
The idea of a worthwhile religion (1:27) is carried on in 2:14-25.

greek_protases.p1: Εἴ τις δοκεῖ θρησκὸς εἶναι μὴ χαλιναγωγῶν γλῶσσαν αὐτοῦ ἀλλὰ ἀπατῶν καρδίαν αὐτοῦ

english:
p: (for if a man wearing a gold ring and fine clothing comes into you assembly, and a poor man in shabby clothing also comes in, and [if] you pay attention to the one who wears the fine clothing ans say, "you sit here in a good place," while you say to the poor man, "you stand over there," or, "sit down at my feet")
q: (have you not then made distinctions among yourselves and become judges with evil thoughts?)
english_translations:
ESV, NRSV: "if" in v.2 and v.3
NASB: "if" once in v.2
NIV, NLT: "suppose" in v.2 and "if" in v.3
notes:
In Greek, ἐὰν 'if' occurs once at the start of v.2 and has scope over the whole of vv.2-3. NASB follows the Greek in this. ESV and NRSV repeat "if" at the start of v.3 (and in fact NRSV also repeats "if" before "a poor person" in v.2). NIV and NLT only have "if" at the start of v.3 but begin v.2 with "suppose".
"James’ goal is to help the reader realize that behaving along the lines of the scenario in the conditional frame is indeed showing partiality and not something else. This command is clearly laid out in v.1 and is practically illustrated in vv.2-4 to make sure that no one misses the point." (Runge 2010)

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν γὰρ εἰσέλθῃ εἰς συναγωγὴν ὑμῶν ἀνὴρ χρυσοδακτύλιος ἐν ἐσθῆτι λαμπρᾷ εἰσέλθῃ δὲ καὶ πτωχὸς ἐν ῥυπαρᾷ ἐσθῆτι ἐπιβλέψητε δὲ ἐπὶ τὸν φοροῦντα τὴν ἐσθῆτα τὴν λαμπρὰν καὶ εἴπητε Σὺ κάθου ὧδε καλῶς καὶ τῷ πτωχῷ εἴπητε Σὺ στῆθι ἢ κάθου ἐκεῖ ὑπὸ τὸ ὑποπόδιόν μου

greek_apodoses.q1: οὐ διεκρίθητε ἐν ἑαυτοῖς καὶ ἐγένεσθε κριταὶ διαλογισμῶν πονηρῶν

english:
p: (if you really fulfill the royal law according to the Scripture, "you shall love your neighbour as yourself,")
q: (you are doing well)
notes: NRSV and NLT invert the order of p and q.

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ μέντοι νόμον τελεῖτε βασιλικὸν κατὰ τὴν γραφήν Ἀγαπήσεις τὸν πλησίον σου ὡς σεαυτόν

english:
p: (but if you show partiality)
q: (you are committing sin and are convicted by the law as transgressors)
notes: This contrasts with v.8.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ προσωπολημπτεῖτε

greek_apodoses.q1: ἁμαρτίαν ἐργάζεσθε ἐλεγχόμενοι ὑπὸ τοῦ νόμου ὡς παραβάται

english:
p: (if you do not commit adultery but do murder)
q: (you have become a transgressor of the law)
notes: This illustrates the point of v.10 (whoever keeps the whole law but fails in one point has become guilty of all of it). It can be understood as 'Even if you do not commit adultery, but if you commit murder, you have still broken the law.'

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ οὐ μοιχεύεις φονεύεις δέ

english:
q: (what good is it)
p: (if someone says he has faith but does not have works?)

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν πίστιν λέγῃ τις ἔχειν ἔργα δὲ μὴ ἔχῃ

english:
p: (if a brother or sister is poorly clothed and lacking in daily food, and one of you says to them, "go in peace, be warmed and filled," without giving them the things needed for the body)
q: (what good is it?)
notes: The structure of this onditional is similar to 2:2-4.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν ἀδελφὸς ἢ ἀδελφὴ γυμνοὶ ὑπάρχωσιν καὶ λειπόμενοι τῆς ἐφημέρου τροφῆς εἴπῃ δέ τις αὐτοῖς ἐξ ὑμῶν Ὑπάγετε ἐν εἰρήνῃ θερμαίνεσθε καὶ χορτάζεσθε μὴ δῶτε δὲ αὐτοῖς τὰ ἐπιτήδεια τοῦ σώματος

english:
q: (faith by itself)
p: (if it does not have works)
q: (is dead)
notes: It may not be natural to keep p embedded within q; it may be necessary to restructure as: 'If faith is not accompanied by works, it is dead.' Or: 'Faith alone without works is dead.'

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν μὴ ἔχῃ ἔργα

greek_apodoses.q1d: οὕτως καὶ ἡ πίστις … νεκρά ἐστιν καθ ἑαυτήν

english:
p: (and if anyone does not stumble in what he says)
q: (he is a perfect man, able also to bridle [control] his whole body)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB: "if anyone"
NRSV, NIV: "anyone who"
NLT: "if we"

greek_protases.p1: εἴ τις ἐν λόγῳ οὐ πταίει

greek_apodoses.q1: οὗτος τέλειος ἀνήρ δυνατὸς χαλιναγωγῆσαι καὶ ὅλον τὸ σῶμα

english:
p: (if we put bits into the mouths of horses so that they obey us)
q: (we can guide their whole bodies as well)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV: "if"
NIV: "when"
NLT: non-conditional statement

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ τῶν ἵππων τοὺς χαλινοὺς εἰς τὰ στόματα βάλλομεν εἰς τὸ πείθεσθαι αὐτοὺς ἡμῖν

greek_apodoses.q1: καὶ ὅλον τὸ σῶμα αὐτῶν μετάγομεν

english:
p: (but if you have bitter jealousy and selfish ambition in your hearts)
q: (do not boast and be false to the truth)

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ ζῆλον πικρὸν ἔχετε καὶ ἐριθείαν ἐν τῇ καρδίᾳ ὑμῶν

greek_apodoses.q1: μὴ κατακαυχᾶσθε καὶ ψεύδεσθε κατὰ τῆς ἀληθείας

english:
p: (if you judge the law)
q: (you are not a doer of the law, but a judge)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV: "if"
NIV: "when"
NLT: non-conditional statement (but "if" is used in the previous clause)
notes: Judging the law' in the verse is referring back to the first part of the verse where James says, "the one who speaks against his brother or judges his brother, speaks evil against the law and judges the law."

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ νόμον κρίνεις

greek_apodoses.q1: οὐκ εἶ ποιητὴς νόμου ἀλλὰ κριτής

english:
p: (if the Lord wills)
q: (we will live and do this or that)
notes: James wants his audience to realize that God is in control, not them.

greek_protases.p1: Ἐὰν ὁ κύριος θελήσῃ

greek_apodoses.q1: καὶ ζήσομεν καὶ ποιήσομεν τοῦτο ἢ ἐκεῖνο

english:
p: (if he has committed sins)
q: (he will be forgiven)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NIV, NLT: "if"
NRSV: "anyone who"
notes:
κἂν 'even if'
Boyer says there is no indication of probability.

greek_protases.p1: κἂν ἁμαρτίας ᾖ πεποιηκώς

english:
p: (if anyone among you wanders from the truth and someone brings him back)
q: (let him know that whoever brings back a sinner from his wandering will save his soul from death and will cover a multitude of sins)
notes: The focus is on the "someone brings him back" section, not the "if anyone wanders"

greek_protases.p1: ἐάν τις ἐν ὑμῖν πλανηθῇ ἀπὸ τῆς ἀληθείας καὶ ἐπιστρέψῃ τις αὐτόν

greek_apodoses.q1: γινωσκέτω ὅτι ὁ ἐπιστρέψας ἁμαρτωλὸν ἐκ πλάνης ὁδοῦ αὐτοῦ σώσει ψυχὴν αὐτοῦ ἐκ θανάτου καὶ καλύψει πλῆθος ἁμαρτιῶν

english:
p: (though now for a little while, if necessary)
q: (you have been grieved by various trials)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB: "if necessary"
NRSV: "even if" (applied to q)
NIV, NLT: no conditional
notes: The condition acknowledges the trials the audience have suffered while also confirming that they were necessary. The idea of the trials being necessary is expressed in various ways in English: "you have had to suffer various trials" (NRSV), "you may have had to suffer..." (NIV), "you must endure many trials" (NLT).

greek_protases.p1: ὀλίγον ἄρτι εἰ δέον

english:
p: (and if you call on him as Father who judges impartially according to each one's deeds)
q: (conduct yourselves with fear throughout the time of your exile...)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV: "if"
NIV: "since"
NLT: no conditional
notes: The fact that our heavenly Father "judges each person's work impartially" (that is, "He will judge or reward you according to what you do" - NLT) is the reason why we should live in reverent fear; p is therefore the reason for q, and in some languages a connective such as 'because' may be more natural than a conditional.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ πατέρα ἐπικαλεῖσθε τὸν ἀπροσωπολήμπτως κρίνοντα κατὰ τὸ ἑκάστου ἔργον

greek_apodoses.q1: ἐν φόβῳ τὸν τῆς παροικίας ὑμῶν χρόνον ἀναστράφητε

english:
q: (like newborn infants, long for the pure spiritual milk, that by it you may grow up into salvation...)
p: (if you have tasted that the Lord is good)
english_translations:
ESV, NRSV: "if indeed"
NASB: "if"
NIV, NLT: "now that"
notes: There are various interpretations of where q starts. It could be argued that 2:1 is also a part of q, as in NASB: "putting aside all malice and all deceit and hypocrisy and envy and all slander, like newborn babes..." At the other extreme, NLT includes only the last clause in q: [Cry out for this nourishment,]q [now that you have had a taste of the Lord's kindness.]p Most English translations, however, treat the whole of v.2 as q.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ἐγεύσασθε ὅτι χρηστὸς ὁ κύριος

greek_apodoses.q1: ὡς ἀρτιγέννητα βρέφη τὸ λογικὸν ἄδολον γάλα ἐπιποθήσατε ἵνα ἐν αὐτῷ αὐξηθῆτε εἰς σωτηρίαν

english:
NRSV:
q: (for it is a credit to you)
p: (if, being aware of God, you endure pain while suffering unjustly)

NIV::
q: (it is commendable)
p: (if someone bears up under the pain of unjust suffering because they are conscious of God)
notes: Note that "being aware of God" (ESV "mindful of God") is parenthetical and is not he main clause in p. That is, the meaning is NOT "it is commendable, if a person is aware of God" NOR "if a person is aware of God, they will endure pain while suffering unjustly." Rather, the meaning IS "it is commendable if a person endures pain while suffering unjustly, because they are aware of God." This may need to be rephrased to keep the relations clear in some languages, e.g. "if a person endures pain while suffering unjustly, because they are aware of God, that is commendable."

greek_protases.p1: εἰ διὰ συνείδησιν θεοῦ ὑποφέρει τις λύπας πάσχων ἀδίκως

english:
q: (what credit is it)
p: (if, when you sin and you are beaten for it, you endure?)
notes: This conditional forms a contrastive pair with v.20b. Together these have a chiastic structure: q1, p1, p2, q2. NRSV changes the order to p1, q1, p2, q2, which might be more natural in some languages: [If you endure when you are beaten for doing wrong,]p1 [what credit is that?]q1 [But if you endure when you do right and suffer for it,]p2 [you have God’s approval.]q2

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ἁμαρτάνοντες καὶ κολαφιζόμενοι ὑπομενεῖτε

english:
p: (but if when you do good and suffer for it you endure)
q: (this is a gracious thing in the sight of God)
notes: See note on v.20a.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ἀγαθοποιοῦντες καὶ πάσχοντες ὑπομενεῖτε

english:
so that 
p: (even if some do not obey the word)
q: (they may be won without a word by the conduct of their wives, when they see your respectful and pure conduct)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NLT: "even if"
NIV: "if"
notes: Greek: καὶ εἴ 'even if'; this is a "concessive conditional."

greek_protases.p1: καὶ εἴ τινες ἀπειθοῦσιν τῷ λόγῳ

greek_apodoses.q1: διὰ τῆς τῶν γυναικῶν ἀναστροφῆς ἄνευ λόγου κερδηθήσονται

english:
q: (who is there to harm you)
p: (if you are zealous for what is good)?
notes: The entire conditional is a rhetorical question witth the assumed response being 'no one.'

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν τοῦ ἀγαθοῦ ζηλωταὶ γένησθε

english:
p: (but even if you should suffer for righteousness' sake)
q: ([you will be] blessed)
english_translations: ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV, NLT: "even if"
notes:
Greek: εἰ καὶ 'even if'; this is a "concessive conditional." 
In Greek "you" here is plural. There is no verb in q so English translations have supplied "you are" or "you will be" before "blessed".
Boyer (1982b: 171) suggests that this could be an example of a class 4 conditional as the verb in p is in the optative mood.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ καὶ πάσχοιτε διὰ δικαιοσύνην

english:
q: (for it is better to suffer for doing good...)
p: (...if that should be God's will...)
q: (...than for doing evil)
notes:
P is a parenthetical clause in the middle of q; it can be made explicit as "if it is God's will that you should suffer" (see also NRSV: "For it is better to suffer for doing good, if suffering should be God’s will, than to suffer for doing evil.") In some languages it may be more natural to place p at the beginning of the sentence: "if it is God's will that you should suffer, then it is better to suffer for doing good than to suffer for doing evil."
Boyer (1982b: 171) suggests that this could be an example of a class 4 conditional as the verb in p is in the optative mood.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ θέλοι τὸ θέλημα τοῦ θεοῦ

greek_apodoses.q1d: κρεῖττον γὰρ ἀγαθοποιοῦντας … πάσχειν ἢ κακοποιοῦντας

english:
p: (whoever speaks)
q: (as one who speaks oracles of God)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV: "whoever"
NIV: "if anyone"
NLT: no conditional
notes: Greek: εἴ τις 'if anyone'

greek_protases.p1: εἴ τις λαλεῖ

english:
p: (whoever serves)
q: (as one who serves by the strength that God supplies)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV: "whoever"
NIV: "if anyone"
NLT: no conditional
notes: Greek: εἴ τις 'if anyone'

greek_protases.p1: εἴ τις διακονεῖ

greek_apodoses.q1: ὡς ἐξ ἰσχύος ἧς χορηγεῖ ὁ θεός

english:
p: (if you are insulted for the name of Christ)
q: (you are blessed, because the Spirit of God rests upon you)
notes: In Greek "you" here is plural.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ὀνειδίζεσθε ἐν ὀνόματι Χριστοῦ

greek_apodoses.q1: μακάριοι ὅτι τὸ τῆς δόξης καὶ τὸ τοῦ θεοῦ πνεῦμα ἐφ ὑμᾶς ἀναπαύεται

english:
p: (yet if [anyone suffers] as a Christian)
q: (let him not be ashamed, but let him glorify God in that name)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: no conditional 
(NIV and NLT have "if you suffer" in v.15)
notes: In Greek there is no verb in p; the verb 'suffer' from v.15 is understood, so English translations have supplied "anyone suffers", "any of you suffers", or "you suffer".

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ ὡς Χριστιανός

greek_apodoses.q1: μὴ αἰσχυνέσθω δοξαζέτω δὲ τὸν θεὸν ἐν τῷ ὀνόματι τούτῳ

english:
p: (if it begins with us)
q: (what will be the outcome for those who do not obey the gospel of God)
notes: 'It' refers to judgment; see NLT: "And if judgment begins with us, what terrible fate awaits those who have never obeyed God’s Good News?"

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ πρῶτον ἀφ ἡμῶν

greek_apodoses.q1: τί τὸ τέλος τῶν ἀπειθούντων τῷ τοῦ θεοῦ εὐαγγελίῳ

english:
p: (if the righteous is scarcely saved)
q: (what will become of the ungodly and the sinner?)
notes: Quoted from Proverbs 11:31

greek_protases.p1: εἰ ὁ δίκαιος μόλις σῴζεται

greek_apodoses.q1: ὁ ἀσεβὴς καὶ ἁμαρτωλὸς ποῦ φανεῖται

english:
p: (for if God did not spare angels when they sinned, but cast them into hell and committed them to chains of gloomy darkness to be kept until the judgment; if he did not spare the ancient world, but preserved Noah, a herald of righteousness, with seven others, when he brought a flood upon the world of the ungodly; if by turning the cities of Sodom and Gomorrah to ashes he condemned them to extinction, making them an example of what is going to happen to the ungodly; and if he rescued righteous Lot, greatly distressed by the sensual conduct of the wicked (for as that righteous man lived among them day after day, he was tormenting his righteous soul over their lawless deeds that he saw and heard)
q: (then the Lod knows how to rescue the godly from trials, and to keep the unrighteous under punishment until the day of judgment)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: no conditional
notes:
Most English translations supply 'if' before each new example in verses 4, 5, 6 and 7, but the Greek only has ει once at the beginning of v.4.
Although this long sentence reminds the readers of events where God demonstrated his wrath and judgement, it is intended to reassure the audience that God will protect the righteous.

greek_protases.p1: Εἰ γὰρ ὁ θεὸς ἀγγέλων ἁμαρτησάντων οὐκ ἐφείσατο ἀλλὰ σειραῖς ζόφου ταρταρώσας παρέδωκεν εἰς κρίσιν τηρουμένους καὶ ἀρχαίου κόσμου οὐκ ἐφείσατο ἀλλὰ ὄγδοον Νῶε δικαιοσύνης κήρυκα ἐφύλαξεν κατακλυσμὸν κόσμῳ ἀσεβῶν ἐπάξας καὶ πόλεις Σοδόμων καὶ Γομόρρας τεφρώσας καταστροφῇ κατέκρινεν ὑπόδειγμα μελλόντων ἀσεβέσιν τεθεικώς καὶ δίκαιον Λὼτ καταπονούμενον ὑπὸ τῆς τῶν ἀθέσμων ἐν ἀσελγείᾳ ἀναστροφῆς ἐρρύσατο βλέμματι γὰρ καὶ ἀκοῇ ὁ δίκαιος ἐγκατοικῶν ἐν αὐτοῖς ἡμέραν ἐξ ἡμέρας ψυχὴν δικαίαν ἀνόμοις ἔργοις ἐβασάνιζεν

greek_apodoses.q1: οἶδεν κύριος εὐσεβεῖς ἐκ πειρασμοῦ ῥύεσθαι ἀδίκους δὲ εἰς ἡμέραν κρίσεως κολαζομένους τηρεῖν

english:
p: (for if, after they have escaped the defilements of the world through the knowledge of our Lord and Savior Jesus Christ, they are again entangled in them and overcome)
q: (the last state has become worse for them than the first)
notes: This is classified as factual because v.19 states, "they themslves are slaves of corruption."

greek_protases.p1: εἰ γὰρ ἀποφυγόντες τὰ μιάσματα τοῦ κόσμου ἐν ἐπιγνώσει τοῦ κυρίου καὶ σωτῆρος Ἰησοῦ Χριστοῦ τούτοις δὲ πάλιν ἐμπλακέντες ἡττῶνται

greek_apodoses.q1: γέγονεν αὐτοῖς τὰ ἔσχατα χείρονα τῶν πρώτων

english:
p: (If we say we have fellowship with him while we walk in darkness)
q: (we lie and do not practice the truth)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV, NLT: "if"
(NLT partially inverts)
notes:
The conditionals in ch.1 form contrastive pairs: 1:6 "if we... walk in darkness" vs. 1.7 "if we walk in light", 1:8/10 "if we say we have no sin/have not sinned" vs. 1:9 "if we confess our sins". As far as possible, these should be translated using the same conditional construction. Runge (2010) comments on these verses:
"The opening chapter of 1 John has a series of conditional frames that allow the writer to quickly switch from one state of affairs to another. Each clause, by changing the condition for the main clause that follows, provides a new perspective on what it means to have fellowship with Jesus. There is noticeable contrast between the clauses based on the semantics of the content, but it is heightened through the use of frames to juxtapose opposite conditions with their correlating consequences. ... The parallel syntax and wording of vv. 6, 8, and 10 help to insure that the reader connects these verses."

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν εἴπωμεν ὅτι κοινωνίαν ἔχομεν μετ αὐτοῦ καὶ ἐν τῷ σκότει περιπατῶμεν

greek_apodoses.q1: ψευδόμεθα καὶ οὐ ποιοῦμεν τὴν ἀλήθειαν

english:
p: (But if we walk in the light, as he is in the light) 
q: (we have fellowship with one another, and the blood of Jesus his Son cleanses us from all sin)
english_translations: ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV, NLT: "but if"
notes: See note on 1:6.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν δὲ ἐν τῷ φωτὶ περιπατῶμεν ὡς αὐτός ἐστιν ἐν τῷ φωτί

greek_apodoses.q1: κοινωνίαν ἔχομεν μετ ἀλλήλων καὶ τὸ αἷμα Ἰησοῦ τοῦ υἱοῦ αὐτοῦ καθαρίζει ἡμᾶς ἀπὸ πάσης ἁμαρτίας

english:
p: (If we say we have no sin) 
q: (we deceive ourselves, and the truth is not in us.)
notes:
See note on 1:6. Runge (2010) writes:
"Verse 8 establishes that there is no room for denying that we have sin. This raises the question of how we should respond to sin in light of the fact that it is universal. Verse 9 provides the answer using another conditional frame."

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν εἴπωμεν ὅτι ἁμαρτίαν οὐκ ἔχομεν

greek_apodoses.q1: ἑαυτοὺς πλανῶμεν καὶ ἡ ἀλήθεια οὐκ ἔστιν ἐν ἡμῖν

english:
p: (If we confess our sins) 
q: (he is faithful and just to forgive us our sins and to cleanse us from all unrighteousness)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV: "if"
NLT: "but if"
notes:
See note on 1:6.
Although q is encouraging, Haas et al. (1994) and Marshall (1978a) agree that p has the force of an exhortation or command.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν ὁμολογῶμεν τὰς ἁμαρτίας ἡμῶν

greek_apodoses.q1: πιστός ἐστιν καὶ δίκαιος ἵνα ἀφῇ ἡμῖν τὰς ἁμαρτίας καὶ καθαρίσῃ ἡμᾶς ἀπὸ πάσης ἀδικίας

english:
p: (If we say we have not sinned) 
q: (we make him a liar, and his word is not in us.)
notes:
See note on 1:6.
Kruse (2000) claims that this verse is essentially a restatement of 1:8, although there is a crucially different nuance here. 
Quotative thesis 2 revisited. 1:8-10 form a chiasm.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν εἴπωμεν ὅτι οὐχ ἡμαρτήκαμεν

greek_apodoses.q1: ψεύστην ποιοῦμεν αὐτὸν καὶ ὁ λόγος αὐτοῦ οὐκ ἔστιν ἐν ἡμῖν

english:
p: (if anyone does sin) 
q: (we have an advocate with the Father, Jesus Christ the righteous.)
notes: Greek καὶ ἐάν sometimes expresses a "concessive conditional", but no major English translations use the concessive construction "even if"; καὶ here is simply connecting 1a and 1b, and in English "but" is an appropriate translation.

greek_protases.p1: καὶ ἐάν τις ἁμάρτῃ

greek_apodoses.q1: παράκλητον ἔχομεν πρὸς τὸν πατέρα Ἰησοῦν Χριστὸν δίκαιον

english:
NIV:
q: (We know that we have come to know him) 
p: (if we keep his commands)
notes:
Smalley (1984) and Haas et al. (1994) claim that the introductory phrase ἐν τούτῳ γινώσκομεν "by this we know" is commonly used in 1 John to introduce a conclusion; this is how the NIV and the NLT render the verse. While Haas et al. (1994) argue that ἐν τούτῳ γινώσκομεν marks p as being factual, Marshall (1978a) disagrees and argues that John stated it as an undetermined (i.e. neutral) conditional in order to invite his readers to reflect on whether they are fulfilling that condition. This is the interpretation we have followed.
While the overall function of this conditional is to encourage, Haas et al. (1994) and Persson (2000) note that there is also an implied exhortation in p.
(NIV also has a conditional in 2:5, but most other English versions have 'whoever'. The Greek in v.5 is ὃς ἂν 'whoever'.)

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν τὰς ἐντολὰς αὐτοῦ τηρῶμεν

greek_apodoses.q1: Καὶ ἐν τούτῳ γινώσκομεν ὅτι ἐγνώκαμεν αὐτόν

english:
p: (If anyone loves the world,) 
q: (the love of the Father is not in him.)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NIV: "if anyone"
NRSV: "those who"
NLT: "when"
notes:
This conditional provides a reason for the command in 2:15a "Do not love the world or the things in the world.".
John is not saying that loving the world causes a person not to love the Father or express the Father's love, rather he is saying that loving the world shows (is evidence) that a person does not have the love of the Father. As Stott (1988) notes, it is another "test" or "sign" of whether a person is following Christ.

greek_protases.p1: ἐάν τις ἀγαπᾷ τὸν κόσμον

greek_apodoses.q1: οὐκ ἔστιν ἡ ἀγάπη τοῦ πατρὸς ἐν αὐτῷ

english:
p: (if they had been of us,) 
q: (they would have continued with us)
notes: The context of 2:19a,c makes it clear that p is false.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ γὰρ ἐξ ἡμῶν ἦσαν

english:
p: (If what you heard from the beginning abides in you,) 
q: (then you too will abide in the Son and in the Father.)
notes:
The probability of this conditional is Very Likely because 2:20 and 2:27 both indicate that John's audience are following what they have been taught. 
Smalley (1984) and Haas et al. (1994) note that the fronted pronoun ὑμεῖς 'you(pl)' that starts 2:24a indicates that the audience's obedience isbeing contrasted with the liars mentioned in v.22.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν ἐν ὑμῖν μείνῃ ὃ ἀπ ἀρχῆς ἠκούσατε

greek_apodoses.q1: καὶ ὑμεῖς ἐν τῷ υἱῷ καὶ ἐν τῷ πατρὶ μενεῖτε

english:
p: (If you know that he is righteous,) 
q: (you may be sure that everyone who practices righteousness has been born of him)
notes: In 2:1 John has stated that Jesus Christ is righteous, and so this conditional is factual (which is why NLT uses "since").

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν εἰδῆτε ὅτι δίκαιός ἐστιν

greek_apodoses.q1: γινώσκετε ὅτι πᾶς ὁ ποιῶν τὴν δικαιοσύνην ἐξ αὐτοῦ γεγέννηται

english:
NASB
q: (Do not be surprised, brethren,) 
p: (if the world hates you)
notes: Smalley (1984) and Haas et al. (1994) argue that this is a factual conditional, and this interpretation also underlies the use of "that" rather than "if" in the ESV and NRSV translations.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ μισεῖ ὑμᾶς ὁ κόσμος

english:
NIV:
p: (If our hearts condemn us) 
q: (we know that God is greater than our hearts)
or
ESV:
p: (whenever our heart condemns us)
q: (God is greater than our heart)
or
NRSV:
q: (we will know that we are from the truth and will reassure our hearts before him)
p: (whenever our hearts condemn us)
english_translations:
ESV, NRSV: "whenever"
NASB: "in whatever"
NIV: "if"
NLT: "even if"
notes:
Stott (1988:148) describes verses 19-20 well when he states that "its general sense is clear, but it is grammatically confused, and from the earliest days commentators have had difficulty in interpreting it." There are two issues: 1) does p begin ὅτι ἐὰν "that if" or ὅ τι ἐάν "whenever"? 2) Does p modify the following clause (giving the order p, q) or does it modify v.19 (giving the order q, p)? These options are reflected in the NIV, ESV and NRSV translations.
1) The UBS text has ὅτι ἐὰν "that if" (this interpretation is also favoured by Kruse (\2000), but many scholars think that the text should read ὅ τι ἐάν meaning "whenever" (Smalley 1984; Marshall 1978a; Stott 1988; Haas et al. 1994; Jobes 2014). Both of these interpretations are possible. Many languages have a construction that can mean both "if" and "when" depending on the context, and such a construction would be appropriate here. 
2) Stott (1988) and Marshall (1978) state that this verse is intended to comfort a believer who will inevitably have feelings of guilt, and so p modifies the following clause (giving the order p, q). This seems the most liely interpretation to us as well.
Taken together, we feel that NIV and ESV provides the best models.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν καταγινώσκῃ ἡμῶν ἡ καρδία

greek_apodoses.q1: ὅτι μείζων ἐστὶν ὁ θεὸς τῆς καρδίας ἡμῶν

english:
p: (if our heart does not condemn us)
q: (we have confidence before God)
notes: This conditional presents the alternative to v.20.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν ἡ καρδία μὴ καταγινώσκῃ ἡμῶν

english:
p: (if God so loved us)
q: (we also ought to love one another)
notes: P refers back to the past events described in 4:9-10 and so this is a factual conditional; many English translations express this with "since".

greek_protases.p1: εἰ οὕτως ὁ θεὸς ἠγάπησεν ἡμᾶς

english:
p: (if we love one another)
q: (God abides in us and his love is perfected in us)
notes: This conditional follows from v.11 and assumes that the audience do in fact love one another. Q expresses both a promise and a motivation for loving one another, and so the whole conditional sentence strengthens the exhortation in v.11.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν ἀγαπῶμεν ἀλλήλους

greek_apodoses.q1: ὁ θεὸς ἐν ἡμῖν μένει καὶ ἡ ἀγάπη αὐτοῦ ἐν ἡμῖν τετελειωμένη ἐστιν

english:
p: (If anyone says, “I love God,” and hates his brother)
q: (he is a liar)
english_translations:
ESV, "if anyone"
NASB, NLT: "if someone"
NRSV: "those who"
NIV: "whoever"
notes: Greek: ἐάν τις 'if anyone'.

greek_protases.p1: ἐάν τις εἴπῃ ὅτι Ἀγαπῶ τὸν θεόν καὶ τὸν ἀδελφὸν αὐτοῦ μισῇ

english:
p: (If we receive the testimony of men)
q: (the testimony of God is greater)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV: "if"
NIV: rephrased as statement
NLT: "since"
notes: Stott (1988) states that the background for this verse is the Jewish practice of accepting the testimony of two or three witnesses, which seems likely given the previous reference to three witnesses. Others take it to refer to the general human practice of trusting the word of other people (Marshall 1978a). Either way, p is assumed to be true, and the implication is that we should also accept the testimony of God.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ τὴν μαρτυρίαν τῶν ἀνθρώπων λαμβάνομεν

greek_apodoses.q1: ἡ μαρτυρία τοῦ θεοῦ μείζων ἐστίν

english:
p: (if we ask anything according to his will)
q: (he hears us.)
notes: This conditional is very similar to John 14:14. The Greek word τι 'anything' indicates that this is a promise that is always true; this underlies the NLT and NET translation "whenever we ask for anything". The phrase ἐάν τι can also mean 'whatever'.

greek_protases.p1: ἐάν τι αἰτώμεθα κατὰ τὸ θέλημα αὐτοῦ

english:
p: (if we know that he hears us in whatever we ask)
q: (we know that we have the requests that we have asked of him)
notes:
See note on v.14b. This verse is still describing the consequences of 5:13. Because v.14 promises that God wil hear us we know this, and so p is true.
The Greek of this construction is slightly unusual because it employs ἐὰν + an indicative verb, which combines the class 3 connective with the class 1 verb form. Elliott (1981:84, 86) describes this as an irregular class 1; Boyer mentions this verse in footnotes (1982b:164; 1983:175) but never clearly states what class he considers it to be.
(P also contains the embedded phrase ὃ ἐὰν αἰτώμεθα "whatever we ask" which is listed as a non-conditional occurrence of ἐὰν below.)

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν οἴδαμεν ὅτι ἀκούει ἡμῶν ὃ ἐὰν αἰτώμεθα

greek_apodoses.q1: οἴδαμεν ὅτι ἔχομεν τὰ αἰτήματα ἃ ᾐτήκαμεν ἀπ αὐτοῦ

english:
p: (If anyone sees his brother committing a sin not leading to death)
q: (he shall ask, and God will give him life—to those who commit sins that do not lead to death)
notes: The Greek ἐάν τις 'if anyone' is followed by an the verb αἰτήσει which can be interpreted either as an assertion 'he will ask' (ESV, NASB) or as an imperative 'let him ask' or 'he should ask' (NET). Because this strongly implies a command, some translations (NRSV, NIV, NLT) change 'anyone' to 'you' (NRSV: "If you see your brother or sister...")

greek_protases.p1: ἐάν τις ἴδῃ τὸν ἀδελφὸν αὐτοῦ ἁμαρτάνοντα ἁμαρτίαν μὴ πρὸς θάνατον

greek_apodoses.q1: αἰτήσει καὶ δώσει αὐτῷ ζωήν τοῖς ἁμαρτάνουσιν μὴ πρὸς θάνατον

english:
p: (If anyone comes to you and does not bring this teaching,)
q: (do not receive him into your house or give him any greeting)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NIV, NLT: "if"
NRSV: "anyone who"
notes:
Greek: εἴ τις 'if anyone'.
Smalley (1984) points out that the NT as a whole and the apostle John in particular commends hospitality as a virtue and a necessary part of the Christian life. But John issues this warning in the circumstance of anticipating heretical apologists welcomed into the houses and churches of the faithful. For these reasons, this command seems to be bound to this particular context and is not a gnomic assertion.

greek_protases.p1: εἴ τις ἔρχεται πρὸς ὑμᾶς καὶ ταύτην τὴν διδαχὴν οὐ φέρει

greek_apodoses.q1: μὴ λαμβάνετε αὐτὸν εἰς οἰκίαν καὶ χαίρειν αὐτῷ μὴ λέγετε

english:
p: (if I come,) 
q: (I will bring up what he is doing, talking wicked nonsense against us)
notes: Smalley (1984), Haas et al. (1994), Persson (2000), and Marshall (1978a) argue that given the intent to visit expressed in v14, this conditional is presented as a confident prediction with only the time yet to be decided.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν ἔλθω

greek_apodoses.q1: ὑπομνήσω αὐτοῦ τὰ ἔργα ἃ ποιεῖ λόγοις πονηροῖς φλυαρῶν ἡμᾶς

english:
p: (if not)
q: (I will come to you and remove your lampstand from its place)
english_translations:
ESV, NRSV, NIV, NLT: "if...not"
NASB: "or else"
notes:
Greek: εἰ δὲ μή 'if not', 'otherwise' with an elided (understood) verb. 
This phrase presents the alternative to "repent, and do the works that you did at first" in the previous clause; NIV and NLT make this explicit: "If you do not repent."
Both condtionals in v.5 share the same q. The p of v.5b comes before q, and the p of v.5c comes after q.

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ μή

greek_apodoses.q1: κινήσω τὴν λυχνίαν σου ἐκ τοῦ τόπου αὐτῆς

english:
q: (I will come to you and remove your lampstand from its place)
p: (unless you repent)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NRSV: "unless"
NIV, NLT: untranslated (in 2.5b)
notes:
Greek: ἐὰν μὴ 'unless'
See note on 2.5b. Because NIV and NLT have "If you do not repent" in 2.5b, they do not repeat this here.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν μὴ μετανοήσῃς

greek_apodoses.q1: ἔρχομαί σοι καὶ κινήσω τὴν λυχνίαν σου ἐκ τοῦ τόπου αὐτῆς

english:
p: (if not)
q: (I will come to you soon and war against them with the sword of my mouth)
english_translations:
ESV, NRSV: "if not"
NASB: "or else"
NIV: "otherwise"
NLT: "or"
notes:
Greek: εἰ δὲ μή 'if not', 'otherwise' with an elided (understood) verb. 
This phrase presents the alternative to 'repent' in the previous clause (similar to v.5b).

greek_protases.p1: εἰ δὲ μή

greek_apodoses.q1: ἔρχομαί σοι ταχύ καὶ πολεμήσω μετ αὐτῶν ἐν τῇ ῥομφαίᾳ τοῦ στόματός μου

english:
q: those who commit adultery with her I will throw into great tribulation)
p: (unless they repent of her works)
notes:
Greek: ἐὰν μὴ 'unless' (i.e. 'if not')
V.21 mentions 'repent' twice, so "unless they repent of her deeds" is meant to reinforce this.

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν μὴ μετανοήσωσιν ἐκ τῶν ἔργων αὐτῆς

greek_apodoses.q1: ἰδοὺ βάλλω αὐτὴν εἰς κλίνην καὶ τοὺς μοιχεύοντας μετ αὐτῆς εἰς θλῖψιν μεγάλην

english:
NASB:
p: (if you do not wake up) [ESV: if you will not wake up]
q: (I will come like a thief, and you will not know at what hour I will come to you)
english_translations: ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV, NLT: "if... not"
notes: Greek: ἐὰν μὴ 'unless' (i.e. 'if not')

greek_protases.p1: ἐὰν οὖν μὴ γρηγορήσῃς

english:
p: (If anyone hears my voice and opens the door)
q: (I will come in to him and eat with him, and him with me)
notes: There is a promise in q, but also an implied exhortation to "open the door" in p.

greek_protases.p1: ἐάν τις ἀκούσῃ τῆς φωνῆς μου καὶ ἀνοίξῃ τὴν θύραν

greek_apodoses.q1: καὶ εἰσελεύσομαι πρὸς αὐτὸν καὶ δειπνήσω μετ αὐτοῦ καὶ αὐτὸς μετ ἐμοῦ

english:
NASB:
p: (if anyone wants to harm them)
q: (fire flows out of their mouth and devours their enemies)
english_translations: ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV, NLT: "if anyone"

greek_protases.p1: εἴ τις αὐτοὺς θέλει ἀδικῆσαι

greek_apodoses.q1: πῦρ ἐκπορεύεται ἐκ τοῦ στόματος αὐτῶν καὶ κατεσθίει τοὺς ἐχθροὺς αὐτῶν

english:
NASB:
p: (If anyone wants to harm them)
q: (he must be killed in this way)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB: "if anyone"
NRSV, NIV, NLT: "anyone who"
notes: Greek: ει + subjunctive

greek_protases.p1: εἴ τις θελήσῃ αὐτοὺς ἀδικῆσαι

english:
p: (if anyone has an ear)
q: (let him hear)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB: "if anyone"
NRSV, NLT: "anyone (who)" 
NIV: "whoever"
notes: Similar to the commandment given to each of the seven churches (2:7, 11, 17, 29; 3:6, 13, 22): ὁ ἔχων οὖς  'the one having an ear' (ESV: "he who has an ear").

greek_protases.p1: Εἴ τις ἔχει οὖς

english:
p: (if anyone is to be taken captive)
q: (to captivity he goes)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NIV: "if anyone"
NRSV: "if you"
NLT: "anyone who"
notes: Quoted from Isaiah 33:1, Jeremiah 15:2; 43:11; q restates and affirms p.

greek_protases.p1: εἴ τις εἰς αἰχμαλωσίαν

english:
p: (if anyone is to be slain with the sword)
q: (with the sword must he be slain)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NIV: "if anyone"
NRSV: "if you"
NLT: "anyone"
notes: The NASB and NRSV translate p as an active statement ("if anyone kills") rather than a passive one ("if anyone is to be killled"), following Genesis 9:6.

greek_protases.p1: εἴ τις ἐν μαχαίρῃ ἀποκτανθῆναι

english:
ESV:
q: (so that no one can buy or sell)
p: (unless he has the mark)
NASB:
p: (no one will be able to buy or to sell)
q: (except the one who has the mark)
english_translations:
ESV, NIV: "unless"
NASB: "except"
NRSV: "who does not" 
NLT: "without"
notes:
Greek: εἰ μὴ 'except'
Paraphrase (to avoid multiple negatives in languages without 'unless' or 'except'): "A person can buy or sell only if he has the mark."

greek_protases.p1: εἰ μὴ ὁ ἔχων τὸ χάραγμα

greek_apodoses.q1: μή τις δύνηται ἀγοράσαι ἢ πωλῆσαι

english:
p: (if anyone worships the beast and its image and receives a mark on his forehead or on his hand)
q: (he also will drink the wine of God's wrath...)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB, NIV: "if anyone"
NRSV: "those who"
NLT: "anyone who"

greek_protases.p1: Εἴ τις προσκυνεῖ τὸ θηρίον καὶ τὴν εἰκόνα αὐτοῦ καὶ λαμβάνει χάραγμα ἐπὶ τοῦ μετώπου αὐτοῦ ἢ ἐπὶ τὴν χεῖρα αὐτοῦ

greek_apodoses.q1: καὶ αὐτὸς πίεται ἐκ τοῦ οἴνου τοῦ θυμοῦ τοῦ θεοῦ τοῦ κεκερασμένου ἀκράτου ἐν τῷ ποτηρίῳ τῆς ὀργῆς αὐτοῦ καὶ βασανισθήσεται ἐν πυρὶ καὶ θείῳ ἐνώπιον ἀγγέλων ἁγίων καὶ ἐνώπιον τοῦ ἀρνίου

english:
p: (and if anyone's name was not found written in the book of life)
q: (he was thrown in to the lake of fire)
english_translations:
ESV, NASB: "if anyone's name"
NRSV, NIV, NLT: "anyone whose name"

greek_protases.p1: καὶ εἴ τις οὐχ εὑρέθη ἐν τῇ βίβλῳ τῆς ζωῆς γεγραμμένος

greek_apodoses.q1: ἐβλήθη εἰς τὴν λίμνην τοῦ πυρός

english:
p: (if anyone adds to them)
q: (God will add to him the plagues described in this book)
english_translations: ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV, NLT: "if anyone"
notes: The conditionals in 22:18-19 together warn of the consequences of changing anything that John has written in this book.

greek_protases.p1: ἐάν τις ἐπιθῇ ἐπ αὐτά

greek_apodoses.q1: ἐπιθήσει ὁ θεὸς ἐπ αὐτὸν τὰς πληγὰς τὰς γεγραμμένας ἐν τῷ βιβλίῳ τούτῳ

english:
p: (and if anyone takes away from the words of the book of this prophecy)
q: (God will take away his share in the tree of life and in the holy city, which are described in this book)
english_translations: ESV, NASB, NRSV, NIV, NLT: "if anyone"
notes: See note on v.18.

greek_protases.p1: ἐάν τις ἀφέλῃ ἀπὸ τῶν λόγων τοῦ βιβλίου τῆς προφητείας ταύτης

greek_apodoses.q1: ἀφελεῖ ὁ θεὸς τὸ μέρος αὐτοῦ ἀπὸ τοῦ ξύλου τῆς ζωῆς καὶ ἐκ τῆς πόλεως τῆς ἁγίας τῶν γεγραμμένων ἐν τῷ βιβλίῳ τούτῳ
